PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 73 citizens), Bolkus (from 25 citizens), Bourne (from 200 citizens), Walsh (from 70 citizens) and Watson (from 25 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1. (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
3. will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in the Parliament assembled, should:
1. By Act, ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
2. Take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act relating to the Industry Training Agents' Guidelines.
Motion (by Senator Reid) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Private Senator's Bill seeks to amend the guidelines made pursuant to the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990. The purpose of the Bill is to remove the arbitrary size limits of the prescribed categories under which an organisation can apply to become a Registered Industry Training Agent (RITA) and to replace them with a `general statement' criteria.

This Bill replaces the numerical test with a general statement that an industry association, professional or trade association is ``a body that is generally recognised within the relevant industry, profession or trade as representing its interests''.
The amendment falls within the stated intention of the Government that the guidelines be reviewed after a period of operation to determine legitimate modifications.

The Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 and the Training Guarantee Act 1990 were passed in May 1990. These Bills initiated the Training Guarantee Scheme which requires that employers with an annual payroll of $200,000 or more (indexed to AWE) spend, either directly or by the imposition of a levy, at least a minimum amount on eligible workforce training every year. The minimum training rate is one per cent in the years 1990-91 and 1991-92 and 1.5 per cent from July 1992.

Part 10 and Section 43 of the Act make provision for the establishment of industry training agents. These Registered Industry Training Agents can issue a training advisory certificate to an employer stating that certain training activities and types of expenditure are ``eligible''.

These certificates are binding on the Commissioner for Taxation who administers the scheme. Without a certificate issued by a RITA, businesses will not be able to ascertain whether their training programs are ``eligible'' before they incur expenditure. Instead, they will need to rely on self assessment which will be monitored by random audits carried out by the Taxation Office.

The criteria for registration of an Industry Training Agent, the conditions which they must meet and provisions for cancellation of registration are set out in the Industry Training Agents' Guidelines 1990.

The Guidelines (Clause 5) state that a person may only be registered as an agent if the person (a) is included in one of the categories specified in clause 6 and (b) meets the criteria specified in clause 7.

The problem is that the arbitrary numerical test used in Clause 6 as the sole test for selection as a Registered Industry Training Agent (or RITA) renders many recognised professional and industry organisations ineligible to become Registered Industry Training Agents. This is a particular problem in the smaller States.

If an industry association wishes to register as the RITA but does not propose to carry out functions of an agent in every State and Territory, it is required (under Category B: Industry Association) to represent at least (i) 200 employers in the relevant industry in each State or Territory in which the body proposes to carry out the functions of an agent; or (ii) employers who employ at least 10,000 employees in each State or territory in which the body proposes to carry out the functions of an agent.

Similarly, for a professional or trade association to be eligible to register as a RITA, but does not propose to carry out functions of an agent in every State and Territory, it is required (under Category D: Professional or trade association) to represent at least 200 employers in the relevant profession or trade in each State or Territory in which the person proposes to carry out the functions of an agent.

The arbitrary numerical limits of this category mean that to be eligible to be a RITA in a State, a professional organisation must have at least 200 members. In the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and even Tasmania, organisations such as Real Estate Institutes, Law Societies, professional associations of doctors, dentists, medical specialists, accountants and many other associations that are widely recognised as representing their profession or industry, but may represent fewer than 200 employers, may find that they are not eligible to qualify as a RITA.

For example under Category D, which outlines eligibility for professional and trade groups, such organisations as the ACT and Northern Territory Law Societies, are effectively precluded from applying because they do not represent 200 employers in the legal profession in their respective states. These bodies, in spite of the fact that they are respected and recognised professional associations and regardless of their quality, speciality and convenience to employers, are left to apply under the coverall Category E, but only where no other body has already successfully been registered as a RITA for that profession. In this particular case, the national body (The Law Council of Australia) has already applied and been registered as a RITA so the small-state law societies are also ineligible to apply under Category E of the present guidelines. Therefore they cannot become RITAs.

It would appear that the Legislation was not intended to render these organisations ineligible. A letter to the Shadow Minister's Office from the office of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training dated 11 January 1991, states that ``the Government is well aware that organisations such as Law Societies in the smaller States and Territories will not meet the size criteria under category D. In these situations, it would be quite extraordinary if organisations such as these organisations were not eligible under Category E.

There is no question that organisations such as the Law Societies of the ACT, NT and Tasmania, the Real Estate Institutes of the smaller states etc fulfil all of the qualifications for registration as an industry training agent specified in Clause 7 of the Guidelines:
They
(a) have the qualifications or expertise in training; and
(b) have a knowledge of the industry to which the application relates, including its training needs and its infrastructure; and
(c) have a knowledge of, and a commitment to, the Act and its objects; and
(d) have an involvement in, and a commitment to, the improvement of training in the industry to which the applicant relates; and
(e) have financial resources, facilities and premises of a standard that will enable the person to carry out the functions of an agent efficiently.

Yet because of an arbitrary number inserted in the guidelines, they are ineligible to register as an Industry Training Agent. Hence this Bill replaces the numerical test with a general statement that an industry association, professional or trade association is ``a body that is generally recognised within the relevant industry, profession or trade as representing its interests''.

This ``general statement'' used to replace the numerical test in this Bill is of the same kind as the provision for a ``general representative'' already incorporated in the 1990 Guidelines. Category E: Subclause 6.6 (e) allows for A ``general representative''-a person or a body . . . who is capable of carrying out the duties of an agent for an industry or a group of employers.

It seems reasonable that if an organisation is already an acknowledged registered industry association and fulfils the qualifications for registration as an industry training agent under Clause 7 of the Guidelines, then there should be no need for an arbitrary numerical ``test'' for selection as a Registered Industry Training Agent.

It is true that the option of using a national body is available to many organisations in this position but this creates difficulties for those State bodies in, for example, the Northern Territory or Tasmania, that are physically remote from their national bodies. In addition, a national organisation may have a good understanding of general issues but not be fully aware of local conditions and differences. For example, in real estate, the ACT has a unique leasehold system for land. It is axiomatic that the industry organisation at the local level is in a better position to respond to local needs and to be better able to certify relevant training for that state, region or city.

There is an also an unjustified implication that industry organisations below a certain size are somehow unworthy to become RITAs and cannot be trusted to be seriously or professionally perform the duties required of a RITA.
Accordingly, the guidelines should be amended to remove these anomalies.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
HEALTH INSURANCE (PATHOLOGY SERVICES) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Health Insurance Act 1973 in order to validate certain recommendations made by the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee relating to the payment of Medicare Benefits that were not given legal effect through failure to make necessary Ministerial determinations.

The Act provides for the establishment of the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee to advise the Minister about the contents of the table in the Schedule to the Act. This table is known as the Medical Benefits Schedule and is used as the basis for determining the amount of benefits payable under Medicare. A determination made by the Minister on the basis of the Committee's recommendation to vary the Schedule requires formal steps to be take to give legal effect to it. For a period of time these steps were in fact not taken, although Medicare Benefits Assessment Advices were issued, which reflected the advice of the Committee during that period. Such advices were acted upon by the Health Insurance Commission, the public and most pathologists. There is no reason to doubt that the relevant Ministers would have taken steps to legally formalise the determinations had the matters been placed before them.

It is obvious that there was a legislative intent in the Act that the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee would be the source of expert advice and would make a recommendation on any amendment to the Medical Benefits Schedule, including the list of pathology services in the Schedule.

The development in the late 1970s of an assay method known as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, or ELISA, as a means of detecting and estimating antigens and antibodies, combined with automation techniques, resulted in considerable savings in the time and cost of doing such estimations. For example it is possible to estimate antibodies in 96 samples in about 1 to 2 minutes using the ELISA test compared with 1 to 2 hours using another comparable technique known as radioimmunoassay. In addition the reagents for ELISA are inexpensive and have a long shelf life.

These properties of ELISA made it an extremely attractive method to pathologists as a means of determining a range of antigens and antibodies. The absence of an item for ELISA in the pathology tables of the Schedule and its increasing use by pathologists was the impetus for recommendations by the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee to add the test to items 2294 and 2295 in the Medical Benefits Schedule.

In 1984, acting on the recommendation of the Committee, the Department issued a Medicare Benefits Assessment Advice which specified items 2294 and 2295 for the assay method ELISA. Subsequent advices arising from other recommendations of the Committee were issued from time to time for these items, generally in order to increase the benefits payable for the service.

The defective amending of items 2294 and 2295 by the use of Medicare Benefits Assessment Advices was thought to have been overcome in 1987 when the Pathology Services Advisory Committee made recommendations to the then Minister, Dr Blewett. These recommendations lead to the Minister making determinations under section 4A of the Act to amend the then Pathology Services Table.

As a result of a Federal Court decision in late 1988, the Pathology Services Advisory Committee recommendations were set aside for procedural deficiencies and the Medicare Benefit Assessment Advices defects again became an issue.
A judgement of the Federal Court in 1990 held that ELISA tests for Rubella antibodies fell within item 1345, which is a pathology service attracting a far higher benefit than items 2294 and 2295.

The wording of pathology items in the Schedule reflects the highly technical nature of a large number of the methods used in pathology. The fact that a test procedure, especially a new procedure, may be interpreted to fit the description of a particular item does not necessarily mean that it is the appropriate item for that test. In fact the vast majority of pathologists did not use item 1345 for ELISA testing because they acknowledge that it was not the correct item.

Further litigation has raised the prospect that pathologists may be able to claim the difference between the fee paid for a test, the level of which was determined by an advice, and the level of fee payable under item 1345. The possible consequences of this situation are that every person who has been paid for ELISA testing under items other than item 1345 over the past six years will be entitled to recover the difference from the Health Insurance Commission.

Since amounts paid for ELISA testing represent reasonable remuneration, as determined by an expert advisory committee, the amendments in this Bill are sought in order to give effect to what was thought to be the position at the time, and that was accepted and acted upon by both the vast majority of pathologists, the Health Insurance Commission and the public as being the actual right to payment in respect of these tests.

The effect of not making the Medicare Benefits Assessment Advices legally effective will be to create a major danger to revenue by giving pathologists a possible substantial windfall gain of about 100 million dollars.

I must emphasize that the purpose of this Bill is to validate the Medicare Benefits Assessment Advices dealing with the ELISA test so that claims and payments made in accordance with them will become valid and proper and to bring the legislation into line with the general practice in fact adopted at that time; all other rights to benefits under the Schedule will be preserved and unaffected by this Bill.

I now come to the amendments. The proposed amendments to items 1345 and 1346 are consequential, and designed to reduce the risk of argument that, notwithstanding the validation of the advices of Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee, there is still an obligation to pay under item 1345. The effect of the amendment would be to exclude from item 1345 the quantification of those antigens and antibodies which would be covered by the new items 2294(3), 2294(4), 2295(3) and 2295(4) when performed by the ELISA method.

It is also proposed to provide for two rules about the application of the Schedule. These provide a means of dealing with the proposition that because of the general wording of some of the items in the Schedule, the potential exists for a particular test to fall within the literal definition covered by more than one item.

Amendments are proposed in order to validate the various Medicare Benefits Assessment Advices with respect to ELISA for the Schedules in existence at various times between 1 March 1984 and 1 August 1989.

Proposed transitional provisions are included in the Bill to preserve the rights to additional payment to persons who, because of the validation of the advices would be underpaid, and to exclude liability for any additional windfall benefits to pathologists in excess of the amounts specified in the advices.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the debate on the Bounty (Citric Acid) Bill 1991 last being adjourned, I put before the Senate the example of the case of Kodak, which bears an obvious parallel to the initiative under consideration before the Senate. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) implied that that was the case which proved the rule, and I said that it would now seem to be the case that broke the rule. I was going on to allude to the allegation that the Minister, on being asked, `How did Kodak obtain the grant?', replied, `Well, God said it would.' When further pressed, he said, `Of course, it's in God's electorate as well'.

SPEECH.PARA: The parallel to Kodak has already been seized upon by the media. The Australian Financial Review of 21 March 1991 reported that the bounty proposed by this Bill caused allegations `of another Kodak style bail out', as it will assist the only Australian manufacturer of citric acid-Sirius Biotechnology Ltd-and protect the million dollar investment made in the development of the product by its major shareholders and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. What kind of signals, after Kodak and the like, is the Government sending to foreign-owned businesses in Australia through making further payments of this type? Are we soon to see queues of multinationals outside ministerial offices seeking access to Government benefits in return for retaining their production bases in Australia? The list of economic concerns associated with this Bill is long indeed.

The coalition believes that there is insufficient evidence that the competitive position of Sirius could not have been sufficiently enhanced to the extent of the bounty payments by other reductions in the domestic cost structure affecting its performance. I am talking about areas such as micro-economic reform, cost factors, productivity factors and efficiency factors within the Australian work force. Then the question arises as to why the company could not source manufacturing support or financial support from domestic investment sources if its commercial potential is so obvious.

The Government's response that it is simply offsetting domestic and international price distortions disguises the fact that the operation of the local market is so profoundly distorted in its own right that it is incapable of supporting strategically located industries within a medium to long term profit outlook. Despite the Government's stance, the bounty is then, in effect, a traditional protection measure. Put simply, the company is not coming off a tariff onto a bounty. Therefore, the application of the bounty is a clear retreat from the Government's stated theoretical policy direction in respect of lowering protection. Regardless of the arguments concerning the strategic importance of the technology embodied in the company's production process, the imposition of the bounty represents an increase in the aggregate amount of protection in the economy. I referred previously to the $7.27m of taxpayers' funds that will be invested in this bounty over the next few years to a multinational company.

Finally, it is worth noting that the bounty will be applied to the production of citric acid for sale in both the export and domestic markets. I understand that Bunge Industrial Ltd, the recipient of the $7.27m of taxpayers' funds, will attempt to access the Japanese market. While the bounty does not discriminate between local and export prices and is therefore not in clear breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, its application compromises the firm free trading stance the Government has adopted in international trade negotiations. It is an aberration.

I say in conclusion that the Sirius bounty is a symptom of the failure of the Government's economic policies, its failure to make Australia an attractive place to invest and do business. It is a one-off solution to a multifaceted problem. Bunge is prepared to invest some millions of dollars in Sirius, but is clearly not prepared to bear the whole risk. If the prospects of return are so slim that even a massive company such as Bunge, a multinational company, is not prepared to commit itself entirely, why should Australian taxpayers and other firms be expected to pay? Why should we single out one company such as this for support at taxpayers' expense?

Handouts here and there to firms which manage to get the Government's ear are not the solution. Indeed they will eventually become part of the problem. The Government must send the right signals to the business sector, both local and foreign-owned. That means a consistent message, consistent policy direction-predictability in policy direction-not attempting to pick winners here and there to the disadvantage of some other manufacturers or industry within the community.

The signal must be that the Government is committed to building the economic environment and reforming the economy to the point where it makes good sense for businesses to invest locally and maintain their production facilities here in Australia. That means balancing the equation, looking at areas of micro-economic reform, looking at reform in the labour market and the like-areas with which the Government to date has only tinkered at the edges; areas that are essential and important for the long term economic development of this country.

We need a Government which is committed to carrying out reforms which will allow all industries to derive benefit, rather than being selective and benefit being given only to some industries. On all those counts, this Bill fails.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Bounty (Citric Acid) Bill 1991. In so doing, I agree with certain features of the remarks which Senator Olsen has just made but I disagree very strongly with the conclusions that he draws from some of his statements. It is certainly no secret that Australia is an incredibly ingenious country when it comes to scientific research. When we look at the number of scientific papers published per head of population in this country, we find that we are among the world leaders. Where we have often failed in the past-and I think everybody recognises this-is in the translation of those very good ideas into industries which can stand in the marketplace and continue indefinitely into the future and be profitable, effective and address important matters of production, social issues and various other things.

SPEECH.PARA: In attempting to support a piece of industrial development where Australia has developed new technology in terms of selecting an organism which is best able to ferment material to citric acid-work for which I understand Nancy Millis of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee has been substantially responsible in collaboration with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)-and in supporting the development of the actual fermentation technology and helping to bridge the gap between what happens in the laboratory and what happens at the pilot stage, and the gap between that and the large scale application of that in a profitable way, I think everybody recognises that we have often failed in the past.

As I see it, this Bill, which seeks to provide a bounty for citric acid production by this process, addresses that particular problem fairly and squarely. To that extent, the Australian Democrats have no difficulty whatsoever with the proposal. It is absolutely appropriate for government to attempt to help those new developments in Australia bridge that gap which everybody recognises we have had difficulty with in the past.

However, I will pick up on several points which Senator Olsen has raised, but I will draw some different conclusions. It is interesting to note, for instance, that the initial bounty of $700 per tonne, which relates to the production of citric acid, if applied to fermentation for the production of alcohol, would amount to some 88c per litre. That amount is considerably more than the current cost of petrol at the bowser-which I think in Canberra is running at 64.7c or thereabouts at the present time. From all my readings, that would make alcohol a far more than competitive fuel compared with petrol.

It raises the interesting question of whether some support for fermentation technology with a view to producing alternative fuels might not be an area also worth investigating. Certainly, other countries have gone down that road. In view of the difficulty we have in getting rid of our wheat at the present time because of the depressed world market, one could imagine a decentralised industry in rural centres in which farmers would be able to ferment part of their wheat crop and produce local fuel, thus creating local employment and making them independent of the importation of fuel from outside their areas. Of course, in the process it would also make Australia increasingly less dependent upon fuel imports from other countries.

One can agree, to some extent, with Senator Olsen's remarks in relation to selecting particular industries. One can imagine other industries which may also benefit from like bounties to the advantage of the whole economy. This raises the general proposition that I now want to develop. The defect that I find with this legislation is not that the Government is, to use Senator Olsen's term, picking winners but that it is doing that in a rather ragged and arbitrary manner. It seems to me that the Government has developed no coherent view of where Australia is likely to be 20 or 40 years into the future. In attempting to pick winners, as it does with this type of legislation, the Government is merely saying, `This is new technology. This looks good. We will support this technology and hope like hell that some time in the future it will become profitable and it will become beneficial, in a purely economic sense, to Australia'. But the Government has no clear idea of where the production of citric acid or, indeed, any other organic starting materials might slot into a future overall economy and an overall social structure.

Senator Olsen asked the rhetorical question: why does the Government not support other industries? Why does it not support ceramics? One thinks of the solid oxide fuel cell which is being developed by CSIRO, and, indeed, I reflect Senator Olsen's concern: why does the Government not support that leading edge technology? In terms of where we would need to position Australia, it seems to me that one could make a better case for supporting the solid oxide fuel cell than one could for supporting the fermentation of materials to citric acid because it addresses fairly and squarely the very substantial improvements in the efficiency of energy production and the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions which, it seems to me, quite clearly need to be taken into account in where we position Australia 20, 30 or 40 years down the track.

I have pointed out on several previous occasions that one can approach the future in a number of ways. One can approach the future in a utopian way. One can have some kind of idealistic view of what the future might hold that is not founded on any substantial information database and without any concept of the reality of one's present circumstance. We have seen a number of occasions in world history where that has been attempted: the utopian ideal often finishes in bloody revolution because one attempts to impose, very often by force of military intervention, one's utopian view of the world on society. One can also use a totally utilitarian and pragmatic approach. One sees many of the entrepreneurial people in Australia adopting precisely that approach in order to exploit whatever seems to be at hand to their immediate benefit without any thought whatsoever for what that does to the social fabric and to society being led in various directions.

One can use a laissez faire, gradualist approach to the future, and it seems to me that this is the approach upon which the present Bill is based. In other words, one has a general belief that this sort of technology may well improve the economy, but precisely where it fits in, precisely how it is going to operate, and precisely what sort of society it helps to bring into existence is unknown. So one allows it to operate in a random fashion and then attempts, with all goodwill, to try to sort out the social discontinuities and so on that that process produces.

The fourth approach-and the approach that I think we should be using-is the comprehensive approach, which attempts to take into account all the factors which are evident at the present time, all the factors which indicate the possible options which are open before us for the future and which will help us to build a better world. Taking all those factors into account, one then attempts to direct the sorts of technology, the sorts of social institutions, the sorts of political institutions, the economic models and so on towards that goal; and that is not by any means a function exclusively of government.

One of the disappointments-and I have expressed this before-I had with the creation of the organisation, Commission for the Future, was that it did not follow the Swedish model and that it did not operate in a way which would open up very widely for the community the long term options facing Australia. This would have helped the Australian community to decide which option it was seeking to pursue. This could then have been related back to government; we could say, `Well, if this is where we need Australia to be positioned 25 or 40 years on, these are the sorts of things we need to put in place at the present time'.

Unfortunately, the Australian Commission, with a few rare exceptions, has not operated that way. It has been strongly predicated on a particular view of the future and a process by which the Australian society can be coerced into what government seems to see as that inevitable and desirable future.

So, while this may appear discursive, I am saying that, while we support this particular piece of legislation because it does address an immediate and very evident problem-the problem being that Australia very often has failed to bridge that important gap between research development and the full economically viable industrial development of the results of that research in the past; and it is desirable that government intrude, address that problem and provide bounties or whatever other assistance it can to help that situation-nonetheless, the Government should not be doing this in a somewhat arbitrary way. I believe that this Bill is to some extent arbitrary in that it is not based on a clear idea of where that necessarily leads Australian industrial development and how it will slot in some time in the future.

I enjoin the Government to take a much wider view of this approach to Australia's industrial development; to open up much more generously to public scrutiny the options which lie before us for the future, the constraints which are so clearly evident in terms of the environment and other matters and the constraints which the political process itself places on these developments; to open up to public scrutiny the consequences of pursuing certain patterns of industrial development so that people have a clearer idea of the sort of world in which their children are likely to live if certain developments go forward; and then, from that democratic ferment, to attempt to derive a clearer view of precisely which industries should attract this sort of help.

We have no problem whatsoever with government intruding to provide the necessary help. We are just somewhat concerned that at the present time that help is being provided in a somewhat arbitrary fashion. To that extent, I repeat, I agree with Senator Olsen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. As Minister, I am sort of jammed between two versions of purity: one from Senator Olsen, which was invented by Australian economists in the 1960s; and the other from Senator Coulter, which has not quite been refined yet but is nonetheless an alternative example of a new period.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a few comments about the contents of this Bill and why we have it. Essentially, the contents perhaps raise some somewhat new issues, but, first of all, at the risk of saying that the Government is sending good money after bad, let me say that there has been a substantial government research commitment in respect of this industry, in biotechnology, and in particular in this process which is manifesting itself at Sirius Biotechnology Ltd. I think the amount involved is in excess of $1m.

The Sirius operation is important to a lot of biotechnologists, not just because of the investment which has taken place already in research done at University of Melbourne in this area through the grants for industrial research and development scheme, but also for a variety of reasons which I want to come to in a moment.

Senator Olsen raised a number of issues about Bunge Industrial Ltd and its involvement in this process. Bunge has been involved with Sirius since 1984, with substantial capital injections being made to that company in excess of $7m, and the current takeover by Bunge of this company will cost Bunge an additional $4m. To benefit from the bounty, Bunge will have to invest an additional $7m to $10m in plant expansion to reach optimum output levels.

The alternative for Bunge is worth considering. It could have essentially bought this technology and commercialised it overseas. The easy way to get a short term return would have been to acquire the Sirius operation, close it down and license the technology overseas, where it would be able to take advantage of cheaper input costs and tariff protection on outputs than those which exist in Australia.

The two essential problems of Sirius are, firstly, high domestic costs for its key inputs and their alternatives and, secondly, the degree of subsidy attracted by its competitors internationally. Senator Olsen gave us a lecture about purity. I think he should give it overseas on one of his parliamentary trips because the fact is that the subsidies which are available on input costs to this industry in Europe and elsewhere are huge. We have the alternative problem of high domestic costs for key inputs, particularly for sugar and wheat. The problem exists with sugar largely because Senator Olsen's political allies in this chamber, members of the National Party of Australia, would not allow this Government to reduce the levels of assistance for sugar.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you were content for the first five years to leave them where they were.
—No, Senator. That was the ultimate decision, following pressure from the National Party.
—But you did not move them between 1983 and 1988.
—Senator Olsen's governments were in power for 30 years before that. They did not do anything.
—That does not discount the point you had five years in which you did not act.

—Senator Olsen is chastising us for being slow over five years; I am chastising his governments for being slower over 30 years. I do not know who wins that argument, but perhaps he should exert some counter pressure on his National Party colleagues in respect of the current Industry Commission inquiry into the levels of assistance provided for the sugar industry and any result which emerges from that. It is true that CSR Ltd was prepared to supply Sirius with sugar at prices less than those offered to many other Australian sugar users. That would have been an example of industry picking the winners.

SPEECH.PARA: The price that was offered was still above the price of sugar on international markets, so Sirius switched to a wheatbased substrate glucose. This input cost is substantially less than that for sugar-approximately $450 a tonne, but still some $150 a tonne above the subsidised price available to competitors internationally for this technology.

I want to make a few other points. I have referred to Bunge's investment history in connection with this company, the alternatives that it could have adopted, and the fact that there was substantial public sector investment in the research. Putting these three things together, the Government's desire to retain the technology and production in Australia led shamelessly to this bounty Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you guarantee it?
—By the way, this is a production bounty. It is not paid unless the production levels are right.
—How do you guarantee it today in Australia?

—I do not think we guarantee it. We cannot nail a company's feet to the floor. It was the early settlers who were not allowed to leave this country. We do not impose those sorts of conditions at this time.
—It does not meet one of your objectives.

—There are always a few risks in this business, as the senator ought to know. The other important point that Senator Coulter might have touched on but did not because he was diverted is that there is a distinct possibility of this company developing other technologies in the biotechnology area. We believe that the high level of investment by Bunge will drive Sirius to commercialise other applications of fermentation technology. Currently under development at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and Melbourne University, for example, is the food gums project, which is a very high value added processed food additive. This has all been explained to me, but I do not have sufficient recollection or skill to explain it again in technical terms. However, there is no doubt that it is a very high value added process.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of other product applications, including other organic acids, amino acids and enzymes used industrially. None of these products which are in the fermentation family, as it were, will attract bounty. They all have higher and more stable income streams than does citric acid. What it is hoped is being established in Sirius is a small research related production facility, dependent on fermentation technology, which has definite linkages with the research community and which, if it is productive in the way in which the bounty is couched, will attract the bounty.

The charge against us made by Senator Olsen and others is one of inconsistency-that what we should be doing is concentrating on micro-economic reform to help Sirius. I am reminded that when the Kodak bounty was provided, one of Senator Olsen's colleagues went to Kodak and gave the people there a lecture. He said, `What you want is reform on the waterfront. That will make Kodak a successful export company in Australia'. They listened somewhat aghast, I was told, and said, `We have never had anything imported across the waterfront or exported across the waterfront. All our business internationally in this respect-and we are a very big exporter-is done by air.' So they listened to this lecture about these things with some degree of amusement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that he would have mentioned internal transport costs and labour market costs as well as the waterfront. You are being rather selective, Minister.
—It was not reported to me that those things were mentioned. That was the stage when waterfront reform was the flavour of the particular month in which the visit was made.
—Industrial relations reform is twice as important.

—I thank the senator. We may be able to quote him at some stage. I am just making the point that all these things are important but not necessarily relevant to all businesses, particularly those such as by Sirius. What is relevant and important to that company is the cost of the inputs, which are very high by world standards for a variety of reasons. First there is no subsidy because of the positions adopted by this Government and by previous governments. Secondly, there are high input costs owing to tariffs and other assistance measures for those industries. We are enjoined not to be selective. There are particular circumstances in which selectivity is appropriate in this particular legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Coulter rightly identified the problems of innovation and marketplace weakness that we have in Australia. He mentioned the ceramics industry. There are all sorts of government measures of general application which did not apply to Sirius, such as the tax incentive for research and development and so on. They did not apply to Sirius but they have applied to things such as ceramics. Ztec, as it is called, was produced in funded laboratories of the Commonwealth essentially and then later in conjunction with ICI Australia Ltd. A pilot plot was built with the assistance of the research and development tax incentives. There are a number of measures of general application which were applicable to, for instance, the ceramics industry and would be again applicable where there is a significant company involved, but which are not applicable to a company such as Sirius. The sort of consistent assistance which is available to those smaller companies in respect of research and development is very much through a grants system of which the Sirius technology has been a beneficiary.

I realise that there are difficulties in respect of this legislation which can be pointed at, but there is a strong case for the legislation based on the history of this business in Australia, the research involvement which has taken place and the alternatives. The alternatives are to wait for a number of years until the input costs of an industry such as this decrease and become the same as those in the rest of the world; or alternatively to wait until some government subsidises such industries to the extent that the Europeans and others do. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this morning to speak on the Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill has been introduced in a rather hurried fashion so that the Government is able to avoid further liability due to its inefficiency in making changes to the medical benefits schedule in relation to pathology services. The Bill will replace four pathology service item numbers with new item numbers carrying lower rebates, backdated to the date of the Government's announcement of its intention in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is worth while to provide the Senate with an historical overview of the events that have led to the necessity for this Bill. There has been one blunder after another and a lot of inaction on the Government's part. Hopefully, this time the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) will get it right. Between the years 1984 and 1989, the Department of Community Services and Health issued medical benefits assessment advices based on advice from the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee (MBAC) and the Pathology Services Advisory Committee (PSAC), which purported to make amendments to schedule 1 or schedule 1a of the Health Insurance Act 1978. The PSAC provided advice and made representations to the Minister on pathology services in the medical benefits schedule and the appropriate fee structure.

The Government introduced a reduction in the fees payable by the Health Insurance Commission to pathologists performing certain tests. Specifically, the Government intended to reduce the benefits payable for enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) services which provide a cheaper and quicker way of conducting certain pathology tests. The determination was an attempt to reduce the scheduled fee for a test that had become simpler due to scientific and technological advances. The determination was based on advice from MBAC and PSAC. The difficulty arose due to ineffective advice supplied to the Minister, which had the effect of rendering the determinations invalid. However, the determinations were acted upon for some time by the Department, medical practitioners and the general public. Payments were made in accordance with the advices.

An attempt was made in 1987 by the Government to rectify the mistakes by issuing a new determination. The procedures involved here were challenged in the Federal Court of Australia and were found to be defective. Again, the pathology schedule was in a mess. Justice Gummow of the Federal Court found that there was a serious omission of information supplied by the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, which was used to determine the new schedule. The judge found that the Committee had no supporting evidence which enabled it to justify the reduction in benefits. He said that the Committee's reason for the reduction fell short of provision to the Minister of all relevant financial and other information relating to the recommendation.

The Government believed that the situation was rectified when amendments passed in 1989 meant a new table had force due to the Minister's regulation making power. However, the new table did not validate the changes made from 1984; it simply had effect from 1 August 1989. Again, the Minister had failed to resolve the problem. Another problem appeared when it was realised that, as well as being subject to a specific item in the table, ELISA services could also be charged under another, more general item in the table. The benefits available under the general item were higher than those available under the more general item.

The 1990 Federal Court case Peverill v. Health Insurance Commission upheld the right for pathology service providers to use either item where a service could fall within either. Dr Peverill was awarded $1.7m in back payments and it is likely that he will receive a further $7m. This case dramatically increased the likelihood that litigation would be used by other pathology service providers to have services performed, while there were two items covering the service available, recompensed at the higher rate even though most were originally charged under the lower rate.

It has been estimated that the total cost to the taxpayer nationwide could have been in the vicinity of $100m. I understand it is for this reason, and an imminent court decision, that the Government has at last decided to bring into this place a piece of legislation and list it immediately for debate. One does wonder what on earth the Government has been doing up until putting amendments to the Act in 1989 and why it has not acted on this issue earlier.

The effect of this Bill is to validate the advices and correct the defects in the schedules of the principal Act-that is, the Health Insurance Act 1973-so that claims and payments made in accordance with them become valid and proper. The Bill also provides appropriation for that excess to rectify what was otherwise a breach of section 83 of the Constitution. Payments had been made without parliamentary appropriation as Parliament had only appropriated money for amounts properly payable under the Act as it was then. The Bill provides new item numbers and rebates and the Opposition will not be opposing this. It is about time that the Government closed this loophole.

The pathology profession, represented by the Australian Association of Pathology Practices and the Royal Australian College of Pathologists, also supports this piece of legislation. The profession has no difficulty with the legislation, as it merely legitimises what virtually everyone was doing. The area of pathology is obviously one that causes the Government a great deal of problems. An article in the Australian on 22 February this year captured the problem in its heading: `Pathology Overuse a Threat to Medicare'. The article was in response to the release of the Deeble report entitled Medical Services through Medicare, the second background paper in the Macklin inquiry.

The most alarming figure was that the use of pathology services per person had grown by 42.6 per cent in five years. Recorded pathology services totalled $32.08m in 1988-89. In 1989-90 the recorded figure was $24.15m, a reduction of some 25 per cent. Looking at this figure on its own, one would perhaps be encouraged by the declining usage in pathology services if it meant an increase and improvement in public health. However, pathology benefits increased in 1989-90 by 7.5 per cent. This highlighted a disturbing trend of declining usage yet increasing cost.

The 1989-90 annual report of the Department of Community Services and Health indicated a reduction of 14.5 per cent in the number of pathology services, with a 9.9 per cent increase in the value of pathology services processed. There would appear to be some problem with the figures recorded for pathology services being understated due to a number of factors. An adjustment of these figures shows that the problem may not be as serious, although adjustments to figures on the basis of what did not happen must be treated with a degree of scepticism.

Rates of growth have differed substantially between health services. For all services the trend rate of growth was 4.2 per cent per person per annum, but for medical services other than pathology it was only 3.2 per cent. Pathology use per person increased at more than twice that rate at 4.7 per cent. Many figures could be quoted to support those which I have already mentioned, including figures that show the increasing pattern of growth in diagnostic services.

There can be no denial by the Government that it has a major problem with pathology. A major problem with the system is that of bulkbilling. There has been a 65 per cent increase in the number of services bulkbilled. As we have seen in the area of medical services, the presence of bulkbilling results in overservicing.

Lately I have heard some stories from a couple of people who, because of their businesses, frequent doctors' surgeries. They have been told stories of people who happened to be waiting at a bus-stop near a particular doctor's surgery when they decided to pop in to have a chat and fill in the time. This is not a one-off case, but just one example. This is not a free chat, it is a chat which has a service provision and is charged. These people do this because it does not cost them anything. The absence of any price signal is a great way to ensure that services are overused. I do not think we would find the same overuse of dentists' services or people visiting the local vet who happened to be on the corner because we know how much it costs to use those services.

The Australian public has been hoodwinked by this Government into believing that the 1.25 per cent of its income that goes towards Medicare covers the cost of health. It does not, and that should be reiterated so that every member of the Australian public realises that as a taxpayer, he or she pays for this overuse and that it is not covered by the 1.25 per cent. Until people use medical services appropriately and not abuse them, they will be paying an undue price for public health in Australia.

The same applies to pathology services. The presence of bulkbilling inevitably leads to the overuse of the service. If the Government were consistent and introduced some price signal, like it did with the concessional pharmaceutical payment, the level of service usage might look quite different. Even if the full fee were abatable, the existence of a price signal would have the effect of reducing the current tendency to overuse the system.

The Government has missed out on a golden opportunity to address the general problems in the pathology area. But we have become used to the lack of action on the part of this Government, particularly in this area. It has lost a valuable opportunity to crack down on rorts in the system and examine those elements of the system where cost containment needs to be more effectively policed.

As I said, the Opposition will be supporting the Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1991. But it is again another attempt by this incompetent Government to fix what it has attempted to remedy before but with little success and at quite considerable cost to the taxpayer if, in fact, the court rules for an additional $7m for this doctor who is currently involved in obtaining some sort of recompense through the loophole. I again add that we are amazed at the Government and the Minister's lack of action in not correcting this loophole earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1991 without amendment. Indeed, we hope that it will pass speedily through this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill corrects a major error which has been made by the Government in relation to payments for pathology services under Medicare. The Health Insurance Act 1973 set up the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee which advises the Minister for Social Security about the contents of the medical benefits schedule in the Act. This schedule is used as the basis for assessing the benefits payable under Medicare. The Act envisages that the committee will make recommendations about varying the schedule to the Minister, who will then make a determination about the amount payable. Medicare benefits assessment advices will then be issued by the Department of Social Security and payments will be made in accordance with these advices.

The Minister's determination requires certain formal steps to be taken before it has legal effect. Unfortunately, for some time these steps were not taken, with the result that ministerial determinations made during the period are technically legally invalid. Despite this, Medicare benefits assessment advices were issued by the Department and were relied upon by the Health Insurance Commission, the general public and the vast majority of pathologists.

The major problem is the oversight that occurred in relation to a testing method called enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). While the majority of pathologists have been claiming for ELISA using the categories listed in the advices, one particular pathologist has successfully taken action in the Federal Court of Australia in order to use a different category which attracts a far higher benefit. The Federal Court has held that ELISA tests for a specific type of antibody-rubella-fall within this latter category, thus raising the prospect that the pathologist may now be able to claim the difference between the fee paid for the test-that is, under the legally invalid advices-and the higher fee payable under the category determined by the Federal Court.

As Senator Patterson has said, this Bill is to bring legislation into line with the general practice adopted by most pathologists. The Government has argued that if it does not make the advices legally valid, pathologists would potentially be able to claim an amount up to $100m from the Government. Indeed, as has already been said, this view is supported by the Australian Association of Pathology Practices, which represents pathologists in private practice. The association accepts the need to rectify what it sees as a technical oversight and believes that the aspects of retrospectivity are justified in these circumstances. The association believes that the vast majority of pathologists throughout Australia are unperturbed by the Bill and that the fight against it is being led by a very small number of pathologists who are determined to make significant financial gain from what is really a technical error.

Although the Australian Democrats are generally opposed to retrospective legislation, this Bill should not necessarily be seen as containing a retrospective element. It was clear that Parliament's intention was that provisions of the Health Insurance Act 1973 would be properly observed and that pathologists would claim under the categories listed in the advices from time to time. Basically this legislation should be viewed, therefore, as correcting a technical error rather than retrospectively introducing any new conditions or subsequently altering a particular situation.

As members of Parliament we also have some obligation to consider the financial implications for the Government and for taxpayers. Although it is unlikely that the full $100m could be claimed, it seems quite likely that a potential exists for an enormous claim to be made-and this must not be ignored. It should also be noted that pathology services are the most significant factor in escalating health care and Medicare costs and that it would simply not make sense to force the Government to pay out millions of dollars to pathologists at the expense of other health services, particularly at a time when government is in fact seeking ways to curtail the costs of pathology services to the public purse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Medicare statistics show that pathology utilisation is increasing at a faster rate than other medical services. Paradoxically, rebates have fallen by 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years. This means that pathology services have become more efficient in providing services at lower unit costs, but the demand is rising at a rate which is putting unacceptable pressures on the health care budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The ageing population and medical and social reasons account for some of the increase, but the basic cause is bulkbilling, which puts no restraint either on the patient who requests the test or on the doctor who has no financial constraint in ordering the tests. In the case of the entrepreneurial clinics there is actually a financial incentive to increase the number of tests performed. The cost of pathology has been increasing at 12 per cent per annum, although the number of patients being tested has been increasing at only 3 per cent per annum. It is interesting that 88 per cent of that increase has occurred in bulkbilling clinics. Those are facts that cannot be escaped; they are on record. These figures demonstrate once again the basic flaw in Medicare, which is bulkbilling.

On the other hand, the Government actually claims that one of the measures of success of Medicare is the increasing number of doctors who are bulkbilling their services and an increasing number of patients who are demanding bulkbilling. It surely must be obvious to the bureaucracy at least, if not the Government, that some constraint has to be put on both the patients and the providers of pathology services. In fact, the Government has actually done this in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) is present because he has done that with the introduction of copayment in relation to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, even introducing it to pensioners where they have to put up the $2.50 in copayment for pharmaceuticals. Yet the Government turns a blind eye to the fact that this is occurring in relation to medical services and does not introduce copayment in this regard.

This Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill is necessary to close retrospectively a loophole that was exploited by only one pathologist in the country who was smarter than both the Government and the bureaucracy because he saw the loophole. Considering our convict background, there could those amongst us who would say, `Well, good on him; one individual has outsmarted the Government and the bureaucracy'. I suppose there is hope for us all if we are up against that sort of monolith.

That pathologist has benefited to the extent of $1.7m. The rest of the pathologists in Australia, who are perfectly ethical in this regard, recognise that they could have exploited the loophole. If they did, it would cost all of us, as taxpayers, up to $100m. The pathology profession is not prepared to do that. The loophole needs to be closed. The root cause of this loophole and the exploitation it has made available is bulkbilling. Until bulkbilling is eliminated and patient copayments introduced, entrepreneurs will continue to exploit the system.

The Bill is also necessary because the Government was sloppy in its management of changes to the Medicare schedule. There is a delay in decision making in relation to new items and there is a failure to understand the technical aspects of these changes. Although a minor symptom, it is a sign of the failure of the socialist inspired bureaucratic juggernaut-Medicare-that is now out of control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are speaking on health legislation. There seems to be a never ending array of legislation having to come through this Parliament to close loopholes. I shall speak very briefly because this piece of legislation does just that. However, I do ask when the Government will get its act together to be able to abide by the legislation it gets through the Parliament. The situation has been put very clearly by my colleagues, Senator Patterson, Senator Lees and Senator Herron, who have already spoken on this issue. They pointed out very clearly that the legislation and the determination by the then Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, did not see eye to eye and that, in taking advice from the Medical Benefits Advisory Committee, the Minister made his determination without taking the appropriate steps that were needed to abide by the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1986 the Government determined that the Medicare schedule fee for some pathology services should be reduced because, with new technology, some of the tests that were done when the Medicare schedule was first set up had become automated and therefore, it was very much cheaper for the pathologists to perform them. The pathologists agreed with the Government and they suggested that the Minister should alter the schedule.

As I say, the Government made an awful hash of it. Three years later in 1989, in trying to rectify the position, it again made an awful hash of it and the loophole was not closed. As Senator Herron said, only one pathologist in Australia took advantage of the loophole that he discovered and was awarded $1.7m in back payments and is attempting to claim an additional $7m. Both the Royal Australian College of Pathologists and the Australian Association of Pathology Practices have said, `This loophole must be closed'. Indeed, one of the senior pathologists in the College said to me, `Well, if it is not closed and I was unethical enough, I would get an additional $3m. Why isn't the Government acting?'. As has already been stated, if all pathologists decided to abide by the law they would be entitled to in the vicinity of $100m of taxpayers' money. Because it is an ethical profession, it has approached the Minister and said, `For heaven's sake, get it through the Parliament and get it through quickly'. The Government has mucked around and fudged for years. At last it is coming up with legislation to close that loophole.

Unfortunately, the Opposition will be supporting retrospective legislation. It should not be necessary. This side of the chamber does not like passing retrospective legislation. However, this legislation has to be made retrospective to 14 March 1986. That is the only method of closing that loophole, so shielding the taxpayer from otherwise legally collected fees.

As Senator Herron has pointed out, and pointed out very rightly, the Government, for philosophical reasons only, will not acknowledge that the main problem with Medicare and the reason for the blow-out in the cost of Medicare is the `overservicing' of doctors by patients. Senator Patterson gave a very good example of people going to the doctor just to have a chat. This is the result of bulkbilling. They go to have a chat because it does not cost them a cent. Many elderly patients consider that it is the social outing of the week to visit the doctor and to have a chat about their general health. Of course, they are not charged one cent.

We must keep emphasising-I am very sure people do not realise this-that the Medicare levy covers just one-third of people's health costs. Most people think that they pay their levy, therefore they have paid for their health costs and they do not need to pay another cent. That is not right; that is totally wrong. It is a myth that the Government keeps putting forward. Indeed, at the last election Labor supporters held up placards saying, `You already pay for your health through the levy; do not let there be any alteration.' When I asked them where they got their information I was told from their local member. It is not true. The levy pays for a very small section of that health care. The majority of it comes straight from Consolidated Revenue, from the normal taxes paid by Australian citizens. The levy is a furphy. The levy that goes to Medicare is a very small area of tax. We must emphasise that and tell people that this is so, otherwise this myth will continue.

As Senator Patterson has already said, even though we do not like passing retrospective legislation, the Opposition will be supporting this Bill and supporting it for one reason only, that is, the sheer incompetence of the Government in not getting its legislation right over the past five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the debate on the Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1991. I find it extraordinary that Senator Walters should berate the Government for not getting it right over the past five years, when the Opposition quite clearly has no idea of the proper construction of a health policy to enable all Australians to secure proper health services at a reasonable cost to them and to the rest of the community. That was the debacle in the presentation of the health policies of the Opposition in the last two elections which, I think, almost ensured that Labor would be re-elected. I find it extraordinary that Senator Walters should be ranting against Medicare when it has received the strong endorsement of the Australian people election after election.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not expect to be involved in a partisan exchange of views across this chamber. In fact, I acknowledge the common heritage that Senator Herron and I have as descendants of Irish forebears. It may be that our convict past as Australians does give us some grudging admiration for those who beat the system. But in this instance there is clearly a need to protect the revenue from claims which could be made by pathologists resulting from a very unfortunate series of events which, I agree, should not have occurred.

This Bill protects the revenue from claims for increased benefits for pathology services which have already been remunerated on the basis of a rate for those services determined by an expert committee. Indeed, if the Senate were not prepared to pass this legislation, the great bulk of Australians, being taxpayers, would face a payment of some $100m into the pockets of pathologists.

I pay a tribute to pathologists around Australia who, through their various colleges, associations and professional bodies have indicated-this is admirable and commendable-that they think it would be most unprofessional for them to insist on taking advantage of a loophole which has emerged in the administration of this very complex area of determining the remuneration schedules in relation to the provision of pathology services.

It is a fact that there were technical defects in the way the relevant determinations were made and, therefore, they were invalid. But they were made in good faith and I do not think anyone has questioned that. They were acted on by the Health Insurance Commission and, as I say, by Australian pathologists in the conduct of their professional obligations.

But it has been open to certain pathologists to claim, through the courts, substantial amounts of money as remuneration for the services concerned and in that way they have distinguished themselves from their colleagues who do not think that is either fair or appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's only one, I believe.

—There you are-Senator Walters assures me that only one has seen fit to stand against the Royal Australian College of Pathologists and the Australian Association of Pathology Practices which have indicated that they think this ought not to be taken advantage of.

SPEECH.PARA: The tests referred to in the Bill have been rebated under Medicare since 1984. It became apparent in 1988 that invalid determinations had been made in that period. It was thought, with the introduction of the new pathology table in 1988, that the matter had been remedied. However, the advice of the Pathology Services Advisory Committee, a necessary precondition for making the regulation governing rebates for this test, was found invalid by the Federal Court on definitional grounds in late 1988. The effect of this decision was for the rebate for this test to be determined again under the 1986 table. In early 1989 the industry and the Department in consultation developed a new table which went through Parliament and came into effect on 1 August 1989. This is the table which is in force now, is valid and has been valid since it came into effect.

This Bill will make sure that pathologists cannot go back and claim the difference between one invalid superseded item on the pathology schedule and a higher paying superseded item. I believe that the retrospective element in this Bill has obviously, with some reluctance, given the way in which the Senate generally responds to retrospectivity in Bills, been seen to be necessary. I believe that the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, using its usual criteria, would find it to be necessary. Other rights to claim for services provided under Medicare will, of course, be protected. I believe that the chamber and the whole Parliament are acting very responsibly in deliberating on this problem. I commend the Bill for speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up from where the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) left off. The measures outlined in this Bill result from action taken by a committee which was established to examine the level of pathology services in Australia. I would be grateful if the Minister could tell the Committee of the Whole the terms of reference of that committee. Is it an ongoing committee and is it examining other areas of pathology services in Australia?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am told that the Pathology Services Advisory Committee was abolished by this Parliament as a result of legislation passed in 1989. The Pathology Services Table Committee has absorbed those functions. I do not have the terms of reference of that committee with me at the moment but I can certainly provide them to the honourable senator. It is obviously a continuing committee. I believe that it would have matters before it on a regular basis.

—I have raised this matter to indicate that other areas of pathology services need examination. The Department of Community Services and Health has provided certain figures to me relating to Medicare payments for related services to those provided under item 6469 of the medical benefits schedule. These are official figures. I was given the actual detail of services performed on the same day as services provided under item 6469, which is a Medicare abortion item. I think it is important for the Committee to know that in addition to payments under the abortion items, an extra 34 per cent in Medicare payments were made to the top five abortionists in New South Wales for related services performed on the same day as the abortions were performed; an extra 7.6 per cent in Victoria; and an incredible 44 per cent and 49.7 per cent respectively in Queensland and Western Australia. Those figures seem to be quite incredible-an extra 34 per cent in New South Wales, an extra 7.6 per cent in Victoria, an extra 44 per cent in Queensland and an extra 49.7 per cent in Western Australia. Some explanation is certainly needed.
—What about South Australia?

—I do not have the figures for South Australia because they are submerged largely in the payments for public hospitals there. These are the 1989 figures which were supplied to me by the Department some time ago. I have not got the latest figures but, as you will appreciate Mr Temporary Chairman, they do require explanation. I appreciate that it is ranging a little from the measure here, but it does relate to pathology services with which we are dealing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Pathology Services Tabling Committee has a fairly comprehensive set of terms of reference and I will provide them, although I have not got them before me. Officers tell me that the sort of concern that Senator Harradine has could be the subject of consideration and deliberation by that Committee. I am further advised that the Committee can act on a request for a matter be looked at from any person, so I am sure that if Senator Harradine, with his august status as a senator for Tasmania in this place, were to put the matter before that Committee it would look at it. I am assuming that it falls within its terms of reference, but that is the best prima facie advice from the officials.
—I ask whether, in fact, there has been an examination of this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to the knowledge of officials here.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 April, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1991. The purpose of this Bill is to amend the principal Act, thus increasing duty on uranium concentrate exported from the Alligator Rivers area. It provides the approximate cost recovery for the Office of the Supervising Scientist, a body established by the previous coalition government to undertake environmental monitoring and research activities in the Northern Territory. The increased rate of duty reflects the Commonwealth's position that the costs associated with protecting the environment from the potential adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne, as far as practicable, by the industry carrying out that mining activity and not by the taxpayer. The Office of the Supervising Scientist carries out the Commonwealth's responsibilities in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The original rate of 11c a kilogram for the period 1980-81 to 1985-86 was set on the assumption that other mines would operate in the area. These have been held up by the quite hypocritical and stupid three-mines policy of the present Labor Government. Under the terms of this Bill the duty on uranium concentrate exported from the Alligator Rivers region will be increased, effective from 21 February 1990, from the current $1.15 a kilogram to $1.30 a kilogram. The duty is raised only on operating mines in the area and is certainly a discriminatory tax because it is applied only to one company, Energy Resources of Australia Ltd, which operates the Ranger mine, as the Nabarlek stockpile is effectively exhausted.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist provides support to other organisations, and is of potential benefit to mines which will begin operation in the future. It is a classic case of the Government's user pays policy being implemented for overkill.

I point out that it is the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia to transfer the functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) and the university college or appropriate agencies in the Northern Territory. We have, in fact, accepted the recommendations of Professor Geoff Taylor's review, but on the Government's part, to date, there has been absolutely no action.

Energy Resources of Australia has requested the disbandment of the Office of the Supervising Scientist on the grounds that its research is inappropriate and irrelevant to the company's needs. That company is being forced, as well as paying for the Office of the Supervising Scientist, to fund a research organisation which has failed in its intended task.
