On occasions, it has had to use outside agencies such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and ANSTO to perform necessary research that the Office of the Supervising Scientist has failed to perform properly.

The Australian Labor Party is yet again agonising over its uranium policy. If it was not so serious, it would be hilarious. For the good of the nation let us hope that after this agonising there will be some sense coming out of the Labor Party. We cannot accept the cynical logic that went on with the decision on Coronation Hill. We cannot continue with the troglodyte attitudes of those in the Labor movement who will not face the reality that Australia must export to survive, export to recoup our debt and export to maintain any semblance of the standards to which we have become accustomed in Australia.

The three-mine uranium policy is one of the most archaic, stupid and defenceless policies with which this Government still persists. I can see the Minister on duty, Senator Richardson, coming into the chamber and I am sure he agrees with that. The only reason it remains is because of the factional fighting within a divided Labor Party. It is a quite illegitimate product of consensus politics.
It is fascinating to trace the history of the Labor Party on uranium. As long ago as 1957 its foreign policy platform noted:

We urge . . . that nuclear research to hasten the application of atomic power for industrial purposes be encouraged in the development of Australia. Further, we demand the protection and safeguarding of Australia by the retention here of basic raw materials and the necessary manufacturing and industrial processing rights, so as to ensure this country's selfsufficiency in a time of emergency . . .

Obviously, that was put in because people had no inkling at that stage of the total reserves that we have, not only of uranium but also other energy products. Honourable senators will recall that back in the 1950s there was a ban on the export of iron ore because the great Pilbara region had not been explored. Over the following years uranium was discovered in sufficient quantities overseas for Australia's reserves to decline in importance to the nuclear arms race of the 1950s and 1960s, and future exports would have to serve the developing nuclear power industry.

In July 1973 the Minister for Minerals and Energy, Rex Connor, put an embargo on uranium. It was considered to be vindicated on commercial grounds by the significant increase in uranium prices worldwide since the start of that year. Labor then approved a strong pro-nuclear policy similar to that of 1971. In October 1974, with world prices skyrocketing, it became obvious that the price was only one of the reasons for the embargo. The ambition then was for a 100 per cent government-owned uranium enrichment plant, a central government-owned uranium mill in the Northern Territory and a government partnership with mining companies.

In part, Mr Connor-who was affectionately known around Australia as the strangler-was right and in part he was wrong. He was right with his vision that what we needed to do with a great resource, where we had 30 per cent of the world's resources of uranium, was to go to the value added stage-not only just to sell the product overseas as uranium, but also to enrich it.

It is a commonly held view that if we had got into that, the increase in our export income today would be of the order $1 billion a year. Where Mr Connor was wrong-and it seems that this Government has not learnt from this-is that he was promoting its ownership and operation by the Government. Of course, it never got off the ground.

Following 1974, we saw a broad change in the ALP's uranium policies which reflected increasing interest in environmental matters. In November 1976, despite strong rank and file opposition to uranium exports, a five point resolution of the now Treasurer, Mr Keating, and Senator Button was passed in Caucus. It was opposed by Mr Uren, Dr Cass, Dr Cairns and former Senators Mulvihill and Gietzelt, and it read as follows:
(1) That existing contracts for uranium mining should be honoured, provided that no new mining developments are permitted to take place.
Quite apparently at that time, the loony Left were in control of the Labor Party. The resolution went on:
(2) That the Labor Party should continually press for stricter international safeguards and controls over the handling of nuclear materials.
(3) That it be made clear that the next Labor Government will not be bound to honour any future contracts entered into by the present Government.

Talk about sabotage of an industry. What a marvellous thing for a Labor opposition that at any future election could come into government to say! What a wonderful thing to say to future customers: `If you order now the uranium you require for your power station, we will not guarantee to honour it in the future'! That is the quickest way I know to frighten customers into going to other overseas suppliers. The resolution continued:

(4) That if, in government, the Labor Party is satisfied that the hazards associated with nuclear power have been eliminated and satisfactory methods of waste disposal developed the question of uranium mining be reconsidered in the context of full public debate.
(5) The ALP condemns the Government-
the coalition Government of the day-

for their haste in announcing decisions on the mining of uranium, without giving the Australian community time in which to debate this highly important subject, thereby disregarding the commission of inquiry's final recommendations.

Mr Keating's proposal to the July 1977 ALP National Conference that this resolution should stand together with a two-year moratorium was rejected, and a much tougher policy was presented by Mr Dunstan and Mr Holding. It said:
A Labor Government would:
(a) declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia-
that is, stop it altogether-
(b) repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium; and
(c) Not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium pursuant to agreement entered into contrary to Labor's policy.

It seems that the Labor Party has moved a step forward from that, and I notice that the Australian Democrats are still in that time warp. Given that attitude, it is no small wonder that the uranium industry has cause for concern. It would appear that Mr Hayden, speaking on an amendment to the Atomic Energy Act in 1978, reinforced the industry's cause for concern when he said:
Labor in Government will not be constrained by this Government's-
the coalition Government's-

permissive uranium policy. We give fair warning to the companies, their financiers and potential customers that Labor will treat uranium responsibly. We will implement our policy of preventing the exploitation of Australian uranium while it poses unsolved threats to the environment, human health and welfare and to international security.

On attaining office in March 1983, the Federal Labor Government revoked all negotiating licences of uranium companies and by July 1984, at the ALP National Conference, the so called three-mine policy was firmly framed. Nabarlek, Ranger and Roxby Downs would continue and any new mines would be prohibited.

Pressure is now on the Government to review its uranium policies. The National Secretary of the ALP, Bob Hogg, admitted in September last year that the policy is contradictory and in need of revision. I can recall Senator Cook saying in this place two or three years ago that a committee had been formed and the matter was being reviewed and that we could expect some news on it fairly shortly.

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has canvassed the possibility of increasing uranium mining. As I said before, the pity is that factions in a disintegrating Labor Party are still calling the shots. We have had the fascinating example in recent days of two Ministers breaking ranks with Cabinet solidarity and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) calling them to order and saying to them, `You can debate this, but only within the forum of the Labor Party'. It is quite apparent that people such as Mr Hand have ignored that rebuke from the Prime Minister. That is not surprising because the Prime Minister himself is currently on the ropes and, I presume, it is only a matter of time before he will depart for greener pastures.

The three-mine policy has led to a situation where Australia, with the world's largest assured low-cost uranium source, has only 10 per cent of the world market; yet we have 30 per cent of the world's reserves. On the other hand, Canada has 30 per cent of the market and only 10 per cent of the world's reserves. It seems to me that the Canadians have beaten us to the punch over a long period in this area. They have the advantage of being able to offer, through their Candu project, the power station and the source of uranium to go with it. This is an opportunity which we may have missed in Australia. I hope we have not; I hope it is not too late for us to move into the enrichment area. Had we taken the opportunity to develop our own technology some 10 or 15 years ago, or perhaps even earlier, we would now be in a similar position to the Canadians. The Canadians are laughing all the way to the bank.

It is no good saying, as I am sure Senator Coulter will when he rises to speak, that we should not continue to supply uranium for nuclear power stations. We have to recognise the real world out there. France generates 60 to 70 per cent of its electricity from uranium. I notice that Japan has 41 operating nuclear power stations and is building another 10. A little country such as Switzerland has five, the United States (US) has 112 and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has 47. Those countries represent the real world out there, and there is a reason for that.

Countries decide to purchase uranium and build nuclear power stations because it is economic to do so and because they are bereft of sources of energy. I can recall many years ago being told by the anti-uranium lobby that I should take note that the countries who were buying uranium were interested only in making bombs. That is just not true; it is absolutely incorrect. The countries that buy uranium do not have an indigenous source of energy and therefore they look to countries such as Australia, Canada and other places to purchase that energy, whether it be coal, uranium or whatever.

Korea provides an interesting example. It has no source of indigenous energy and it buys coal from Australia. It generates about 40 per cent of its power from nuclear energy. According to the figures, 3,000 tonnes of uranium is equivalent to 30 million tonnes of coal. It is all right for us to sit here in armchairs and pontificate about these things, but the countries that need to generate power for their people will look to the most efficient way to do it. Those countries have a balance-a percentage of their energy sources from coal and a percentage from uranium. One advantage of uranium is that it is a clean way of producing electricity.

Australia must protect itself to capture the proper market share when demand increases, as it inevitably will. We export our uranium under stringent international safeguards which allow the use of uranium only for peaceful purposes. We must do away with the present quite jaundiced policy which erodes our reputation as a fair trading nation and stymies once again enhancement of badly needed export income.

It is a great tragedy that the Federal Labor Government has procrastinated for so long and is not prepared to stand up to its responsibilities in this area. It is no oversight that the much vaunted recent industry statement by the Prime Minister, so ludicrously entitled Building a Better Australia, made no mention whatsoever of the three-mines policy or any envisaged changes to it.

During the 1970s-and most of us in this place had children growing up in that period of time-there was a great move to threaten our young people. Teachers and irresponsible people in the community seeking short term brownie points espoused the dangers of uranium. I know that there were some genuine people about, too, but I think that they were caught up in the general momentum. Young people were told by teachers that they would not make 21 years of age because they would be blown up by some nuclear bomb before then.

Everyone knows that one of the great emotions in this world is fear-particularly, fear of the unknown. Radiation cannot be seen and, hence, there is a fear of the unknown. I know that kids were going around who had lost hope and who thought, `We are going to blow ourselves up; we will not make 21'. Of course, it did not happen. So the same group of people are now moving to a different arena and scaring people about the greenhouse effect, the ozone layer and so on. Time will tell whether they are correct.

Certainly it was a great tragedy that the splitting of the atom-a great discovery-was treated in the way that it was, because it can be a wonderful servant of humanity, provided it is properly controlled and provided that safety measures are taken. It is like anything else; I do not know of anything in society which does not have some danger associated with it. I suppose if we took the view of these people about danger we would stop driving motor cars. My understanding is that more people are killed per year in motor accidents in Australia than there were Australians killed during the whole of the Vietnam war. I think we have to get some sort of balance in all of this.
One of the most extraordinary claims made by those in the Labor Party who oppose the mining of uranium is that there is no market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolute rubbish.

—It is absolute rubbish, as Senator Tambling says. Will these people never learn? I have heard it all before. That was the argument used by the Whitlam Government when it prevented coal mines being developed by the use of export controls. That was the very same argument. We have this feeling of deja vu. When the Whitlam Government was thrown out and the curtain was lifted, a number of large mines were developed which increased our exports by some $20m or $30m per year. Without them, this country would be bankrupt today. The arguments are identical, just the product is different.

SPEECH.PARA: Even one of the proponents of uranium mining in the other place, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), remarked that while he supported uranium mining there was no urgency as there was no market until 1995. With that attitude, there will never be a market. Anyone with an inkling of an understanding of a major project, such as a power station, would know that not one spade of soil would be turned until a source of supply for the material to fuel the power station was secured. People are not that irresponsible; they are not going to commit millions of dollars to build something unless there is a source of supply. Apparently this Government has no understanding of the real world. When we hear remarks such as that from people, we realise just how out of touch they are with what happens on the international scene. Is it any wonder that we are staggering under a burden of an ongoing current account deficit and an absolute mountain of foreign debt which we cannot ignore?

The Opposition will not oppose this legislation, but we will seek to amend it. I invite those people from the Labor Party who have given their consideration to the issue of uranium, including members of the Right, to take the opportunity to vote the way their Prime Minister has spoken and vote for this amendment. Government members will be moving swiftly towards their conference debate. They will be enhancing their changes in their conference debate towards a proper and timely decision-namely, the abolition of Labor's three-mine policy.

Before I move the amendment, I would like to refer to the accidents that have occurred in nuclear power stations, to which I am sure Senator Coulter will refer. In recent days we have seen the tragedy of those young people from Chernobyl who are visiting Australia. No-one would deny that it is a great tragedy. But I think the point has to be made that it is from these sorts of tragedies that we will learn how to correct the building of these power stations in order to prevent these sorts of accidents from occurring in the future. Tragedies have occurred over the years-we have had plagues, pestilence and a whole range of things-and this was one such tragedy. All experts in the field have commented that the Chernobyl power station reactor was of a design that would not have been built or licensed in the West.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one in the United States.

—If there is such a station in the US I think one of the lessons of that accident is that they will be looking at it pretty carefully. There are 112 nuclear power stations in the United States-hence my remarks earlier. For goodness sake, let us look at the real world. Nuclear power exists; it is a major source of energy for a lot of people and without it electricity would not be able to be generated at a cost they could afford. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``,but the Senate calls on the Government to review the whole legislative and policy framework applying to the uranium industry, with a view to lifting the Government's `three mines' policy concerning the export of uranium, noting:
(a) the huge potential loss of export income; and
(b) the damaging effect on Australia's international reputation as a fair and responsible trading nation;
caused by the continuation of the `three mines' policy''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express very considerable disgust at what I have just heard, but certainly no surprise. It seems that, even more than the Government, the Opposition is driven by greed-by dollar signs-and whatever will turn a profit is acceptable, no matter what the risks. The nuclear industry is a filthy industry. Its record of deceit, damage and extreme adverse impact on human health is an absolute disaster and one which I will review in the time which I have in front of me.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one point upon which I agree with Senator Parer-I think it is a point of logic rather than a point of fact-and that is, that the Government's three mines-policy is inconsistent. But the solution to that is not to open more mines; the solution to that inconsistency is to phase out those mines which we already have. I believe that one could make a very substantial case on good, sound economic grounds as to why that would be to the long term economic benefit of this country, as well as addressing those very serious problems of human health and safety and environmental damage.

I come from a background of research science from the late 1950s through to the 1980s when I was elected to the Senate. I admit that through the 1940s, most of the 1950s and into the late 1960s I held precisely the same views as Senator Parer has just espoused.

It seemed that indeed one could utilise this marvellous form of energy and, as was enunciated in President Eisenhower's Atoms for Peace program-in 1953, I think-that nuclear power would be so cheap that it could be provided to consumers unmetered. The concerns over safety and so on and the difficulty of managing this inherently very complex technology had not yet been perceived.

But by the late 1960s, working in a research laboratory in areas which related to the dangers of chemicals for human health and seeing the parallels between that and radiation, I began to collect a dossier on nuclear energy and on the emerging concerns over the safety of that industry. By 1972 I had formulated the view that the nuclear industry was one industry which simply should not be developed and should not be relied upon for the development of power; that there were indeed too many inherent, inevitable, inescapable, adverse consequences associated with this industry that made it totally unacceptable in a civilised world that had concern for the long term survival of human kind.

In 1972 I formulated a policy document which was adopted by the Conservation Council of South Australia; in 1972 it was adopted by the Town and Country Planning Association of South Australia, of which I was then the Secretary; and in 1973, when I was elected to the Council of the Australian Conservation Foundation, it was the very first policy that I put before that body. That policy was adopted and remains today the policy not only of the Australian Conservation Foundation, but also of most conservation bodies throughout this country that have considered the question of the safety and the ethics of mining and exporting uranium.

In relation to that history and looking at this industry over that very long period, all I can say is that nothing that I have seen-absolutely nothing-since adopting that policy very deliberately and after great consideration in 1972 has caused me to shift from that position; everything I have seen has confirmed that those fears which were then becoming evident were justified and that this was an industry that was indeed totally unacceptable.

The Bill we are considering seeks to increase the tariff on uranium exports from the Kakadu region, the Northern Territory region, with a view to supporting the Office of the Supervising Scientist. I have no difficulty with that except that, if I saw the opportunity, I would seek to amend this tariff to make it far more substantial, as I have on previous occasions. Indeed, the tariff nowhere near picks up the total costs of this industry, either to the Australian community or to the world community.

Turning specifically to the economics of this industry, I think it is important to develop arguments which are based on the way in which, since the turn of the century when radiation was first identified and used for a range of purposes, the allowable levels of exposure of the human population have been progressively reduced. In other words, as more information has come to light, so we have discovered that radiation is a great deal more damaging to human health than we hitherto thought.

As I recall the situation-while I have lectured on this, I do not have my lecture notes in front of me-between the early years of this century and 1926 when the International Commission of Radiological Protection (ICRP) was first formed, there were no standards. It was believed that radiation was a fairly benign physical phenomenon. One had people, particularly patients with cancers and a range of skin diseases and other things, being exposed to very high levels of radiation. Indeed, many of the people who worked with radiation in those earlier years died as a consequence of that radiation exposure simply because the hazards were not recognised.

I think I am right in saying that the ICRP came into existence in 1926. I recall that the first standard that was struck was 15 rads-that is the old unit-of exposure per week. Putting that into the units which are used these days, that corresponds with 7,500 millisieverts of radiation per year. The present recommendation of the ICRP is 20 millisieverts per year. That gives the Senate some indication as to how, as more information comes to light, the allowable level of radiation which is regarded as acceptable-it is not necessarily safe; every international body accepts that there is no safe level of exposure to radiation; the size of the risk simply relates to the size of the exposure-has progressively reduced. The acceptable level is now 20 millisieverts whereas, in those early years, it was 7,500 millisieverts. For a very long time, through the 1950s until quite recently, the acceptable level was 5 rads-rems is the more correct term-per year; that, of course, is 50 millisieverts. As I have said, the ICRP is now recommending a reduction to 2 millisieverts.

There are several things that one needs to observe about this. Apart from the fact that as more information comes to light it tends to confirm that radiation is a great deal more damaging to human health than we formerly thought, the processes by which the allowable levels are reduced are very long and tedious. By the late 1970s, many reputable scientists had observed that due to the numbers of cancers occurring in certain areas-women who had been treated by way of mammographic investigation; people who had been exposed to radiation for a range of other medical conditions; patients with tuberculosis who had had a large number of chest X-rays and so on-the standards which then applied, namely, 50 millisieverts per year, were simply too high. The impact of that amount of radiation on human health was quite unacceptable. Yet it has taken until now for the ICRP to recommend that reduction.

Even before that reduction has come into effect, we have evidence-published last year in the British Medical Journal-that with respect to the exposure of male workers to radiation and the impact of that exposure on the offspring of those male workers, in terms of the incidence of leukaemia, it is indicative that even the level of 20 millisieverts needs to be very substantially reduced.

I will mention what this study showed. It began as a study of the children of workers at Sellafield in the United Kingdom where built next-door was not only the first civil nuclear power station-initially built for the production of plutonium for UK test weapons that were actually tested in Australia, but it later became a nuclear power station-but also a reprocessing works. Even the nuclear industry recognises that reprocessing is, to use its own words, `The dirty end of the nuclear business'.

Looking at the incidence of leukaemia among the children of these workers, the study found that with levels above 100 millisieverts total exposure-I point out that if the present ICRP recommendation of 20 millisieverts per year is accepted, one would have only to work in that environment for five years to get that total exposure-there was between a sixfold and eightfold increase in the incidence of leukaemia among the offspring.

That led to a study of a number of other nuclear establishments in the United Kingdom where the cumulative exposure to radiation was much less than at Sellafield. As I say, Sellafield has the reprocessing plant which is a very dirty-and accepted as such-industry. The study looked at the children of workers at Dounreay and Aldermaston. I stress that the cumulative exposure at Aldermaston for the workers was only 7.8 millisieverts. In other words, that would be about four months of work at the maximum allowable level; it is about a third of the year of exposure. At 7.8 millisieverts total exposure, the increased incidence of leukaemia in those children was 40 per cent above background. In other words, the level which has yet to come in under the ICRP recommendation is already being recognised as being probably far too excessive and will produce a great deal of ill health.

If we turn to Australia and look at the exposure of workers, say, at Roxby Downs, we find that some of the miners at Roxby Downs are currently being exposed to levels above 20 millisieverts per year. At the Sellafield end of the scale, some five or six years of exposure in that mine could potentially increase the incidence of leukaemia in their children by a factor of six to eight.

This evidence is totally ignored by Senator Parer. It is the evidence which, I believe, will lead progressively to a shutdown of the nuclear industry around the world. Either governments and communities around the world must ignore this evidence and expose their nuclear workers to these unacceptably high levels and suffer the consequences because they are greedy and do not accept that there are alternatives-and there are-or, by accepting these levels, these risks, these dangers, they will reduce the allowable levels of exposure. The nuclear industry will find it quite incapable of operating under these far more stringent standards and will face a progressive shutdown. Where does that leave all of the lovely loot that Senator Parer spoke of which is to come from opening up these new mines? It would be an economic disaster.

I refer to the points that I made in an earlier speech today. We need to look further down the track to see what is likely to happen and to make our decisions on the facts, to use Senator Parer's words, `on the real world', not on airy-fairy ideas that we can open up these mines and, miraculously, the money will simply flow in.

Senator Parer mentioned the Chernobyl disaster. Let me remind the Senate that some time before the fire at Chernobyl, Dr B. Semenov, who was the Director of Nuclear Safety at the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna, published a long scientific article in the IAEA Journal pointing out the inherent safety of the RBMK 1,000 reactor-the Chernobyl type reactor-saying that it was absolutely impossible for the Chernobyl type accident to happen. That is the organisation on which people like Senator Parer rely for assertions that this industry can be made safe-when the Director of Nuclear Safety can make a demonstrably false assertion such as that.

There has been in recent days, particularly with the visit here by the children from Chernobyl, speculation regarding the total impact of that disaster. I would reiterate, as I have previously, that when the Russians went to the IAEA meeting in August of the year in which that nuclear reactor caught fire, their own assessment to the IAEA of the expected number of cancers which would arise as a consequence of that disaster, in western Russia alone, was 40,000. John Gofman, the person who has written one of the best textbooks on the question of radiation exposure and human health, has estimated that the total number of cancers arising throughout western Europe as a consequence of the Chernobyl disaster would be of the order of one million cancers.

Of course, it is absolutely true that even a million cancers arising in a population of that size would be quite undetectable, because there is nothing about the cancers, be they leukaemias or anything else, which arise from radiation exposure which are unique. In every respect they are identical to any other cancer, and no cancer bears a tag on it saying, `caused by radiation'. Given the background incidence of cancer, that some 25 per cent of all populations in Western countries get cancer at some time in their lives and some 20 per cent of all populations-and this is typical of Australia-will die of cancer, that increase of a million cancers spread over perhaps 40 years throughout western Europe would remain completely undetectable. Nonetheless, one can predict, on the known relationship between radiation exposure and the incidence of cancer, that those cancers will be caused, and it is another area in which the nuclear industry has been incredibly deceptive in saying that there is no evidence of harm.

There is no evidence of harm, very often, because, firstly, people have not looked-they have not kept the proper epidemiological data on which one might base a study; and secondly, even if one looks, very often one can hide behind the claim that there is no evidence of harm because the background incidence is so high, because there is a very long latency-it takes anything from 5 to 40 years before the cancers will show themselves-and because there is no identification and there is nothing unique about cancers caused by radiation.

In addition to those matters, one needs also to consider the relationship between the so-called civil nuclear industry-the `peaceful' use of nuclear power-and the military uses of nuclear energy. Again, I find it absolutely remarkable that Senator Parer should talk about the safety which is placed upon the nuclear industry by such things as the Non-Proliferation Treaty and, in the case of those nations which are non-signatories, such as France, the bilateral agreements which are drawn up between Australia and those countries. Those agreements are bits of paper. They have no force whatsoever when the processed uranium, in whatever form, is already in the foreign country.

We have recently seen the massive bombardment of Iraq which was substantially supported by the argument that if Iraq was not quickly subdued it may develop a nuclear weapon. From where did Iraq get its nuclear capability? The French were building a nuclear power station in Baghdad. The Israelis, years ago, recognised the link between the civil use of that nuclear power and the potential which it gave Saddam Hussein to develop nuclear weapons. They went in before that nuclear power station had any fuel in it and exercised a pre-emptive strike. Firstly, the Israelis knew that had they struck the nuclear power station once the fuel was in it, the spread of radiation would have been a disaster-possibly including for themselves if the wind was in the right direction. Secondly, if they had not struck then, there was a clear possibility that, by using a civil nuclear power station and simply taking the fuel out a bit earlier when there was, more or less, the right isotope mix of plutonium, Saddam Hussein could have developed nuclear weapons.

Who supplies France with uranium? Unfortunately, Australia supplies France with uranium. It is quite conceivable that, had that nuclear program which Saddam Hussein was attempting to run progressed further, Australian uranium could have been in bombs which Saddam Hussein manufactured and used in the Gulf war.

Before that we saw the Iraq-Iran war. Before that war broke out, the Germans were not only building six nuclear power stations in Iran, but also actually providing the reprocessing facilities which would have allowed the Iranians to extract the plutonium and make weapons. It is fortunate for us-and I point out the arbitrariness of the sequence of events-that that war broke out and the Germans stopped providing that material for the Iranians. To attempt to argue that there are not demonstrably significant links between the civil use of nuclear facilities and the military uses is to fly in the face of very recent and very obvious evidence.

I would like to make two final points. Again in recent days one has seen assertions that nuclear energy is a way of addressing the greenhouse problem. There has been a great deal of work done on this and the appropriate way of looking at this is precisely the way that economists look at benefits from alternative investments. If one is going to invest a given number of dollars in various ways to address the problem of the greenhouse effect, one should be looking at how best to derive the maximum amount of benefit, in terms of greenhouse gas emission reductions, that one derives for the expenditure of those dollars.

It is abundantly clear from all the studies that to spend a dollar on a nuclear power station, instead of spending a dollar on the energy efficiency improvements which can be made and for which we already have the technology-the technology being safe-is, in fact, to increase the level of greenhouse gas emissions, simply because one can derive a greater benefit from spending that money on efficiency improvements. Those efficiency improvements are not only to be had in the developed world, where we have a profligate use of energy, but they are as much to be made in developing and Third World countries.

For instance, China uses approximately four times as much energy as Japan to derive the same dollar increase in its gross domestic product. It does it in a very environmentally damaging way. But without any further development of generating capacity, China could very substantially improve its position by improving the efficiency with which it uses the energy that is already available to it.

I think the figures work out something like this: in terms of greenhouse emission reductions it is seven times more economically efficient to spend money on energy efficiency than it is to spend money on nuclear power stations. Those who ignore this fact and pretend that somehow or other one is going to make a substantial improvement in regard to the greenhouse effect by going down the nuclear road, if that line is accepted, are simply ensuring that one will have a very small nuclear program and still a very large greenhouse gas emission problem.

The final point that I would make is that, in considering the question of uranium mining in Australia, which is the subject of this Bill, Senator Parer has raised the question of whether more mines should be opened. One should be looking at alternative ways in which the investment which would be necessary to open those mines might make a better profit. It is not simply sufficient to point out that if one exports X thousand tonnes of yellowcake, one will get Y million dollars in benefit. What one needs to do is to consider, if one spends Z amount of dollars, which one has to do to make that investment, what will be the benefit if one invested those Z dollars somewhere else.

I think it is quite clear that there are many opportunities. Again, this goes to the substance of an earlier speech which I made today. There are many opportunities in Australia to spend our dollars a great deal more wisely in terms of where we need to go and where we must go to produce a great deal more environmental benefit and, indeed, a great deal more longer term profit than simply by opening more mines. That seems to me to be quite clear.

In summary, I return to this point: given the very substantial reductions which have already occurred in allowable radiation exposure of workers and the very probable further and very substantial reductions, I believe the nuclear industry is indeed on its way out and we should not proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1991 proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980 to incorporate into that Act a proposal to increase the duty on exported uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers Region in the Northern Territory from $1.15 to $1.30 as from 21 February 1990, as incorporated in clause 3 of the Bill. The levy, which applies only to exports of uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers Region of the Northern Territory, is imposed partially to offset the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities undertaken by the Commonwealth to protect the Alligator Rivers Region. The increase required has arisen in part because only one mine is now operating in that area. When the rate was originally set it was envisaged that several uranium mines would be operating by now.

SPEECH.PARA: Between 1980 and 1987 it was the intention of the Government in setting the levy to recover about 50 per cent of the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities by the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region associated with uranium mining operations in the region. In 1988 the Government announced that the then levy of $1.02 per kilogram, which came into effect during 1987, would be extended to recover about 75 per cent of those costs. The explanatory memorandum to the 1989 amendment to increase the levy to $1.30 contains the following statement:

The increase in the level of the levy reflects the . . . costs associated with protecting the environment from potential adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne as far as is practicable by the industry carrying out those operations, and not the ordinary taxpayer.

By and large the levy falls on the shoulders of one company, Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA), the operators of the Ranger uranium mine. Energy Resources of Australia submitted to the inquiry into mining and minerals processing in Australia, undertaken by the Industry Commission, that the levy might appear to be an example of the user-pays principle. However, none of the buyer-seller relationship applies. I should add that the duty is raised only on operating mines in the region.

The Office of the Supervising Scientist provides services to other organisations. Therefore, the funding structure for the Office of the Supervising Scientist should comprise appropriate payments from all users. ERA has also stated that, because the Office of the Supervising Scientist has failed to produce any practices and procedures of value to the environmental management of the Ranger mine, Energy Resources of Australia has had to bear the additional costs of having to develop those standards, practices and procedures relevant to environmental management and rehabilitation of the region. This has been at enormous cost to Ranger uranium mine, which has contributed largely to environmental protection in the area, often at costs that far exceed those of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The current annual expenditure by Ranger uranium mine on preserving the environment around the mine site is approximately $5m. Over the past 11 years, the operation of Ranger uranium has spent over $50m on environmental preservation of the area.
I noted with interest an editorial in the Northern Territory News dated Saturday, 10 November 1990, which referred to this important fact relating to the Office of the Supervising Scientist. I quote:
To be sure, they make big holes in the ground and they use substances and chemicals which are pollutants.
But, at least nowadays, their environmental standards are very high and they take extreme precautions to ensure that their operations are within the bounds of tolerance.
When they finish, they invariably rehabilitate the land, often leaving it better than it was before they started.
Beyond those simple facts is another.
It is that without mining we could not maintain our living standards, much less improve them.
It therefore comes down to whether we are prepared to see our standards plummet so that no unsightly big holes are made by mechanical bilbies.
Most reasonable people would say that mining is an industry upon whose health depends our wealth.

The Industry Commission report that has been looking at this matter recommended that the responsibilities of the Office of the Supervising Scientist be transferred to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation and the Northern Territory University, or appropriate agencies in the Northern Territory. This is a view which I have held for some time and a number of my colleagues have certainly ensured that it is the policy of the Liberal and National parties. It has certainly been an area that we have promoted actively in this Parliament and in our parties.

On a number of occasions, the former Minister, Senator Richardson, has sought to discredit Ranger uranium mine in order to influence the Australian Labor Party committee which is currently looking at uranium policy of the Government. His motive, of course, is to secure the green vote at the cost of Australia's economic prospects in the 1990s.

I ask the serious question: why is neither Senator Richardson nor any other member of the Australian Labor Party participating in this debate today? There is only the Minister listed at the end of the debate in order to provide the cursory summary. I acknowledge that Senator Coulter and I have extremely different views on this matter, but I acknowledge his courage in coming in here and putting his differing view. Similarly, I acknowledge that Senator Vallentine, who again holds a very different viewpoint from my own, will be participating in this debate. Not one member of the Labor Party has got the courage to come in here and put his or her view, yet this issue is fundamental to this year's National Conference of the Labor Party and to where the Government is taking this country. There are thousands of jobs for Australians at stake in this industry. There are important environmental impacts, as Senator Coulter has recognised.
Debate interrupted.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to my question yesterday concerning Government grants to unions and the union fighting fund, and in particular to the evidence given to the WA Inc. royal commission by Senator Beahan on 4 April 1991, in answer to a summons to produce documents, that he believed that `the union fighting fund had as co-signatories Terry Burke and Peter Cook'. Is that the case and, if so, when did the Minister cease to be a signatory to that fund; was the fund used to channel funds from non-union sources to Australian Labor Party (ALP) election campaigns; and has the Government subsequently made grants to any unions which provided contributions to the fund?
—Order! I do not think that there is very much ministerial responsibility in that question, but I invite Senator Cook to give any answer that he so wishes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that Senator Hill is continuing in this scurrilous, dishonourable and disreputable line of questioning. It is not at all surprising because that is indeed the smarmy way in which Senator Hill asks these questions. Let me answer those questions that he has asked.
—They are scurrilous all right. You ought to use that word!
—They are scurrilous; Senator Panizza is absolutely right.
—How about your mates down there?

—These questions are directed to me, if I might say so, and, in that context, they are scurrilous. The last question I regard as particularly outrageous, and let me answer it full on and up front. The implication of this question is that some unions may have donated to a fighting fund, and if they did the only fighting fund that I am aware of is a fighting fund of which I was a trustee or supporter-I am not quite sure what my capacity was, to be precise-when I was a member of the Australian Labor Party administrative committee in Western Australia in 1982 and 1983. That was a fighting fund of the Labor Party to remove from office the Fraser Government. I am proud of my association with fund raising in the union movement for that purpose, but the implication of this question is that unions that may have donated to that somehow now have received favours in the form of payments by this Government. That is an implication which is foul indeed and it is not an implication which is in any way true.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not remember which unions may have donated to the trade union fighting fund or which factory gate meetings of workers in 1982 and 1983 may have donated to that fund. It was back in 1982 and 1983 and, although I have a good memory, I do not have a memory that is that perfect. Certainly there were no strings on the donations. The donations were made specifically for the political purposes of removing the Liberals from office in Western Australia and federally. As I have said, the innuendo is disgraceful. Some unions have received funds from this Government. I do not happen to know which donated to the fund and I do not happen to know whether they are the same organisations.

There have been a number of government programs under which unions may qualify for grants. Two of them that come to mind are the union rationalisation program and the workplace reform program. Both programs, and indeed all programs of this Government involving unions, have been announced either in Budgets or formal statements by this Government. The funds allocated to them are set out in statements by the Government and are subject to scrutiny of Estimates committees in terms of the management and direction of those funds.

While it may be true that some honourable senators opposite have tried to pretend that this Government directs funds to unions-I have in memory a statement by, I think, Senator Short-in a way which is not meant for the purpose, no-one opposite has ever bothered to ask or make a public statement about how much money this Government gives to employer organisations for the same purposes, and I might say - -

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: the Minister is inferring in his answer that somehow employer groups are associated with the Liberal Party of Australia in the same way that the Australian Labor Party is associated with the trade union movement. The Labor Party is the political wing of the trade union movement and, therefore, I ask the Minister to withdraw that imputation.
—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: what we have just seen from Senator Bishop is a malicious and deliberate abuse of Standing Orders.
—Why don't you tell your Minister to give honest answers?

—There is nothing in Standing Orders that she has raised in that matter. She has got up and debated the point, and I think she should be warned that, if that continues, she will be dealt with appropriately. Senator Bishop knows that she cannot intervene and bring up debating points in the middle of Question Time.
—Order! I agree totally with the Minister. I call Senator Cook.
—Mr Deputy President, I ask that Senator Baume be requested to withdraw the imputation he just made against me, which is foul indeed.
—I withdraw.

—I was asked whether any money was allocated to this fighting fund from non-union sources. That was a question from Senator Hill. That is certainly not the case to my knowledge and it would certainly be against and absolutely the reverse of the custom and practice of that. Any allegations of that nature, one of which was made by the journalist Max Walsh in a column this week and last, is a falsity, and I declared that yesterday. I have asked the Sydney Morning Herald to retract that statement or allegation. I am taking legal advice on that point in the event that the newspaper does not retract it.

ANSWER.PARA: When did it cease? I am not sure whether the ALP's trade union fighting fund has been wound up or whether it continues. I must say that I hope it continues. I would like to be actively supporting it and asking and encouraging unions to donate to it because I think there is a real reason to prevent Senator Hill's lot from ever getting into power.

What did Michael Beahan say to the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters? I am glad that Senator Hill has obviously read, at last, the transcript of what Senator Beahan said, which was not the position when he made the allegations in his question yesterday. But I have here a letter that Senator Beahan sent to the editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, which I shall seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard, and from which I wish to quote, about the article that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald and its author, Maximilian Walsh. I quote:

. . . he claims that, in evidence to the WA Royal Commission, I indicated that I was excluded from the administration of two accounts, the Leaders Fighting Fund and the Union Fighting Fund. In fact, I said precisely the opposite. The transcript reads `As I remember the two accounts that I was associated with or had knowledge of at the time were the Union Fighting Fund and the Leaders Fighting Fund . . . .'
Senator Beahan goes on to make a series of points:

Firstly, and as indicated, the Union Fighting Fund in WA was known to me. It was run as part of the Party's normal internal accounts and was, as such, subject to the scrutiny of various Party bodies and was officially audited.
The allegation yesterday by Senator Hill was that this was a secret fund. This is a statement which scotches that completely. I do not expect an apology but I point that out. The letter continues:
Secondly, no employer money was ever deposited in the Union Fighting Fund. It was a fund established to attract exclusively Union donations towards the 1983 State election.

Thirdly, all funds raised for the 1983 election campaign were spent on that campaign. None was used for the purposes alleged in the article. This was why the account was set up and run under union supervision.
Fourthly, records of the Union Fighting Fund have been submitted to the Royal Commission as requested by them.

Finally, whatever allegations are made against the Leaders Fund, regarding lack of Party control (and some fairly wild and unsubstantiated ones have been made), no such allegations can be directed either at the Union Fighting Fund or at Senator Cook.

This is just another example of innuendo being reported as fact in the hysteria surrounding the Royal Commission. I have come to expect it from inexperienced juniors, it is disappointing that a person of Mr Walsh's standing should be gullibly caught up in it.
I think that answers all of the questions put to me by Senator Hill. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.

As a long-standing reader of the Max Walsh column and admirer of his journalistic professionalism and objectivity, I was disappointed at the sloppiness and inaccuracy of two recent articles in which Mr Walsh appears to be trying to fit a number of discrete, unrelated and obviously unchecked facts into a pre-determined view on the role and power of unions.

I refer to articles in the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday 8 and Monday 15 April. In the April 8 article he claims that, in evidence to the WA Royal Commission, I indicated that I was excluded from the administration of two accounts, the Leaders Fighting Fund and the Union Fighting Fund. In fact, I said precisely the opposite. The transcript reads ` `As I remember it the two accounts that I was associated with or had knowledge of at the time were the Union Fighting Fund and the Leaders Fighting Fund . . . .''

He then went on to assert, through some obscure and convoluted logic that the significance of the union fighting fund is that it somehow leads to union control, both state and federally over the Labor Party, and that this is by implication unacceptable. In the process he off-handedly implicates the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Peter Cook.
In the April 15 article he links the Union Fighting Fund with the alleged channelling of employer money into union campaigns in and outside WA.

Apart from the oversimplification of the whole question of the relationship between the union movement and the Labor Party, Mr Walsh's arguments bear no relation to the facts surrounding the existence of the union fighting fund-facts which Mr Walsh should have checked before making such serious allegations.

* Firstly, and as indicated, the Union Fighting Fund in WA was known to me. It was run as part of the Party's normal internal accounts and was, as such, subject to the scrutiny of various Party bodies and was officially audited.
* Secondly, no employer money was ever deposited in the Union Fighting Fund. It was a fund established to attract exclusively Union donations towards the 1983 State election.

* Thirdly, all funds raised for the 1983 election campaign were spent on that campaign. None was used for the purposes alleged in the article. This was why the account was set up and run under union supervision.
* Fourthly, records of the Union Fighting Fund Account have been submitted to the Royal Commission as requested by them.

* Finally, whatever allegations are made against the Leaders Fund, regarding lack of Party control (and some fairly wild and unsubstantiated ones have been made), no such allegations can be directed either at the Union Fighting Fund or at Senator Cook.

This is just another example of innuendo being reported as fact in the hysteria surrounding the Royal Commission. I have come to expect it from inexperienced juniors, it is disappointing that a person of Mr Walsh's standing should be so gullibly caught up in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question because the reply does not quite answer all the questions. The first question was whether the Minister and Terry Burke were signatories to the account. The Minister says he was a trustee. Presuming he was a signatory, when did he cease to be a signatory to the account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that I may have been a trustee but I am not sure in what capacity I was associated with it. I personally do not have any records of whatever funds there might have been at that time.
—Don't they give you access?

—The records are the legitimate records of the Australian Labor Party; they are not my records. Dealing with the interjection, they are not my records; they are records of the Labor Party, and it is therefore not surprising that I should not have them because it is entirely appropriate that the Labor Party, as the legitimate organisation, should hold them. The ALP has advised me that all of its records relating to income for it have been made available to the Royal Commission. Therefore, in my view, it is up to the Royal Commission to examine the records and act on them if it wishes.

ANSWER.PARA: I am unable to be precise because I have no clear recollection of the capacity in which I was associated with such a fund and whether Mr Burke was a co-signatory as well. I do have a clear recollection that I did as much as I possibly could do to raise money, through the union movement and at factory gate meetings of workers around the State of Western Australia, for contributions to that fund to dislodge the Fraser Government and, at that time, the Liberal Government in Western Australia-and I would do it again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Does the Government share Senator Powell's optimism about the coalition's commitment to support the proposed disclosure legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said yesterday, the Government does not believe that the Opposition's commitment to disclosure legislation is genuine. It is a commitment riddled with so many qualifications and loopholes and its record on disclosure is so lamentable that only the most trusting soul would believe that the coalition is sincere in its support for disclosure. The coalition has actually clouded its statement in a smokescreen of so-called fairness and equity.

—Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: under standing order 73 the Minister cannot be asked for an expression of opinion. As I understand the question, this was an expression of opinion on Senator Powell's comment and I wonder what relevance this has to this particular Minister.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Macdonald has drawn attention to a long-standing standing order. If you want to so rule, we will have a very quick Question Time.
—The practice of the President has been to be quite lenient in this area.

—Opposition senators, as I was saying, have attempted to cloud the need for full disclosure legislation with a smokescreen of fairness and equity, as they call it. Their attitude to disclosure is essentially disclosure at the least possible inconvenience to their party machine. That is not the way disclosure operates and not the way it should operate. The reality is that if there is conflict between the interests of the party machine and the public, then the public interest should prevail. That was a principle that was expressed by Commissioner Roden in the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption report on the investigation into north coast development. He had this to say on the proposition of what should be the primary interest:

ANSWER.PARA: If there is a conflict between the public interest and the convenience of the major political parties, the public interest must be allowed to prevail.
So the principle behind this statement is that convenience should be subjugated to the interests of the public.

Secondly, if one looks at the statement only, it shows that Opposition senators obviously have their eyes closed to other comments coming from Liberal Party spokespeople. On the same day as Dr Hewson announced his so-called commitment to disclosure, the Federal President of the Liberal Party, Mr Ashley Goldsworthy, had this to say:
The party organisation still remains to be convinced that it is possible to draft legislation to meet the fairness and equity test.

That is a very basic precondition. The Liberal Party remains to be convinced that it is possible to meet the test that it lays, a test which is totally irrelevant to governments framing disclosure legislation.

Not only that, when one looks at the statement itself one finds so many qualifications in it that it is made worthless. The coalition's commitment in this area relates solely to disclosure of political donations. It neither relates to disclosure of political expenditure nor to income statements from political parties or third party organisations. Where does the Liberal Party stand on this basic issue? Without that sort of disclosure there cannot be effective disclosure legislation or transparency in the way the corporate sector interrelates with political parties. It is necessary for this sort of full disclosure of income and expenditure statements to enable expenditure cross-checks, particularly when third party organisations and front organisations are involved.

There is also not one reference in the Liberal Party's statement to the spot auditing power of the Australian Electoral Commission. That is not surprising, but there cannot be effective disclosure legislation unless there are effective spot auditing provisions. In terms of the Liberal Party's record, we have to remember that it was in 1984, when the Australian Electoral Commission sought to conduct the spot audit on electoral parties' accounts, that the Liberal Party refused to accede to the request. It refused and confronted the Electoral Commission with legal advice. As a consequence, it rendered the spot audit provisions of the Act as they now exist inoperative. There is no commitment to spot auditing in Dr Hewson's statement.

What we have is a Liberal Party position that does not recognise that disclosure is not designed to be at the convenience of political parties, but that it is designed for the convenience of the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't lie.

—Since Senator Parer has raised that point, I will go back to spot auditing and what his members on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters had to say about what is probably the most effective instrument in ensuring full disclosure. It is an amazing quote:

ANSWER.PARA: The purposes of such spot audits, as expressed by the Commissioner, would be to enable the Australian Electoral Commission to say with a clearer conscience and more confidence that everything appears to be satisfactory.
What does the Liberal Party say about that? I will continue:
This is not sufficient reason to trifle with free democratic processes.

This is very much the conflict between those on this side of the Parliament and those on the other side. If one does not think that the interests of ensuring that the Electoral Commission can say with a clearer conscience and more confidence that everything appears to be satisfactory in the electoral process, then we can see very much where the Liberal Party is coming from. That is a quotation from Senator Short and Messrs Wooldridge and Cobb.

The statement also contains other qualifications which confirm our scepticism on this side. The Liberal Party talks about preventing discrimination against donors to governments or political parties and discrimination against donors by governments or third parties. This perpetuates the myth which has been perpetrated by the Liberal Party of some sort of safety valve. In putting this concept forward, the Liberal Party has not been able to produce one example of such discrimination or an instance of one other country in the world whose disclosure laws include such a provision.

We go on to the further qualification-and the statement is riddled with them-that we need to have a level playing field between the parties regarding taxation. That has been seen for what it is-an irrelevant furphy. All donations from whatever source will need to be equally disclosed.

We have a deliberate fraud by the Opposition Leader brought about because he cannot control his backbenchers, nor can he control Messrs Cobb and Goldsworthy. It is a fraud on the people and it is a fraud on this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Standing Orders make it clear that it is not open to any member of this chamber to impugn the integrity of a member of parliament in that way. I call on you to direct the Minister to withdraw any suggestion of deliberate fraud on the part of Dr Hewson-a very serious allegation. I can well understand his desperation in wanting to score points but this is an entirely separate proposition. An allegation of fraud is about as serious as one can get. I invite you to ask the Minister to withdraw.
— I shall ask Senator Bolkus to consider that request.

—In the interests of debate in the Senate, I withdraw. Let me say, when we couple the bold statement of Dr Hewson that they reserve the right to ultimately vote against the legislation with the bold words of Mr Goldsworthy's statement that he believes it is not possible to draft legislation to meet their test, we see that the Australian public have been conned by the Opposition.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the National Assembly of Pakistan, led by Mr Gohar Ayub Khan. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome them to the Senate and trust that their visit to Australia will be informative and enjoyable.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to evidence given by Laurie Connell at the WA Inc. royal commission yesterday in which he stated that when Mr Burke was Ambassador-designate to Ireland and the Holy See and before he had gone there but after he ceased to be Premier, Mr Burke approached Mr Connell to be a guarantor for a WA Inc. deal concerning the carve up of the Bell Group. I ask: is it appropriate for an ambassador-designate to be actively involved in political affairs? Will the Minister raise this matter with Mr Burke during his forthcoming three weeks leave? Will the Minister now concede that the mounting series of allegations made against Mr Burke at the royal commission require him to stand down from his post?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to respond to the particular matter to which Senator Durack refers. I have only seen a very brief press report of it and I will be seeking further information on that and looking at what issues might arise. I make no assumption that there are any issues of significance in this latest matter but obviously it is something that I will have a look at.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter and more general part of the question, the answer that I give is exactly the same as the one I have always given, and the one that the Prime Minister and everyone else is giving in the House of Representatives, namely, that we do not make judgments about these things simply on the basis of allegations that are made. It is a matter of letting the whole course of this business work itself out in the Royal Commission and a proper decision being made by the Commission on the fully tested evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister raise this matter with Mr Burke during the latter's forthcoming three weeks leave?

—I shall seek further information on the matter. Whether it is something that I will raise directly with him during the course of his leave here or whether it can be dealt with in other ways is a matter that I shall look at over the next day or so. It may be that I can get such a sufficiently precise and extensive explanation of what is involved in this that it may not require any further follow-up.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I ask: could the Minister tell the Senate the effects that the contracts signed yesterday by the Boeing International Corporation, Hawker De Havilland and AeroSpace Technologies of Australia will have on industry development and employment in the aerospace industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The immediate effect is contracts worth $455m for those two companies to build major components for Boeing aircraft. However, I must say that the important thing about these contracts is that they were gained against tough international competition and, in the words of Boeing, in a manner that demonstrates that Australian industry in this area can compete in the competitive world of aerospace. The contracts are worth $455m and are in addition to a $1 billion workload from Boeing currently flowing to those industries.

ANSWER.PARA: Contracts involve a number of things. Australian engineers are in Seattle right now working on these projects. I should add that the contracts are also the result of a long term memorandum of understanding that I signed yesterday with Boeing. Under the memorandum, Boeing has agreed that Australian companies will be allowed to compete for contracts on a free and fair basis and, clearly, they can win work on that basis. Boeing has also placed, or agreed to place, work with a number of other companies in the aerospace and high technology fields. Boeing, of course, has also been freed of its obligations under the civil offsets program.

On the employment side, the two contracts for the sole supply of tail control surfaces for Boeing's new 777 aircraft will lead to significant employment opportunities in Australia's aerospace industries. When output is at its peak, AeroSpace Technologies of Australia expects to have an extra 200 staff employed at its Avalon facility near Geelong and Hawker De Havilland has said that it will employ an extra 160 staff at its Bankstown facility when delivery of the shipsets peaks in the mid-1990s. Hawker De Havilland will also build a $10m plant to manufacture the elevator sections. I expect other major international aerospace companies to sign similar agreements in the near future and I confidently predict a bright future for these Australian aerospace companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Last week Minister Griffiths made a statement in the House in which he objected to my claim that he had received strong representations from the Japanese Embassy in regard to the withholding of several shipments of Japanese seaweed which contained up to 108 times the allowable level of arsenic and up to 40 times the allowable level of cadmium. These shipments were released onto the Australian market on the order of the Minister and no identification was attached to this food so that Australian consumers could identify and avoid the contaminated material. Is it a fact that the seaweed was impounded on the basis of its excessive arsenic and cadmium content? Were representations made from Mr Kazutoshi Ito, Councillor, Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, of the Japanese Embassy, to Mr G. M. James, Assistant Secretary, Environment Health Branch, Department of Community Services and Health? Did those representations make a case for releasing the contaminated seaweed onto the Australian market? At the request of the Australia Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS), did the food science and technology subcommittee review the allowable levels of arsenic and cadmium in seaweed and decide and recommend that no change in the Australian standards be made? Finally, was Minister Griffiths advised of these processes, negotiations and decisions; and if not, why not? If not, on what basis did he decide to release the seaweed onto the Australian market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might say that from my knowledge of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, it is not able to be directed, in the way in which this question implies that it has been, by a Minister. It is a service which is accountable under its charter to its officers.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Griffiths has given me an answer in the event that a question of this nature is asked. I can now answer Senator Coulter's cognate question. The fact is that until recently there were no specific standards for permissible levels of arsenic and cadmium in seaweed and kelp in the food standards code of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC). In the absence of specific requirements, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service commenced testing imported seaweed and kelp in mid-January, using the arsenic and cadmium standards which apply to food stuffs generally. The interception and testing of these products by AQIS identified a number of samples in which arsenic and cadmium levels exceed the limits. Considerable scientific debate ensued as to whether the general standards were appropriate or, alternatively, whether a standard focusing on the more toxic inorganic component of arsenic should be established.

An urgent review of both standards was undertaken by the National Health and Medical Research Council within its framework. Pending completion of the review, the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service followed advice from the Department of Community Services and Health on the appropriate disposition of individual shipments where laboratory tests indicated a possible risk to consumers. Most consignments were permitted to enter the country, based on this scientific assessment, without influence from any overseas government.

The NHMRC has now recommended on scientific grounds that the permissible levels of arsenic and cadmium should be amended to bring them into line with those provided for fish and fish products in the food standards code. In the course of these events the Japanese Embassy in Canberra did maintain contact with both AQIS and the National Health and Medical Research Council to obtain information on the basis of Australia's concerns about the safety of these products.

Contrary to Senator Coulter's offensive inference, I am advised that at no time did officials of the Japanese Embassy make contact with either Mr Griffiths or his office, nor did they influence the outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they did?

—There was no attempt to pressure AQIS into releasing products which could have been harmful to health. Australian consumers can be reassured that the consignments released by AQIS after testing were individually assessed and passed as safe for human consumption. Senator Button interjected and asked what if they did make contact? Indeed, what if they did? If they did, they may well have presented their views, but that does not suggest in any way that those views have been acted on in the way in which Senator Coulter's question supposes they have.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am surprised to hear the Minister say that the NHMRC has recommended a different level from that which, he correctly says, was a general level and not specific to seaweed. However, is it not a fact-and this goes to the fourth part of my question-that the food, science and technology subcommittee did, in January, review the allowable levels of arsenic and cadmium specifically with relation to those levels in seaweed, and decided and recommended that no change be made in the Australian standards? Therefore, the question is: on what basis did the NHMRC make that different decision?

—As Senator Coulter acknowledges in that supplementary question, the National Health and Medical Research Council has recommended on scientific grounds that there be a change. Senator Coulter now asks me what were its reasons for that. I am not a scientist and I have no brief from the NHMRC as to what its reasons were. It is a matter for the Council, but I can direct this question to it and find out, if it is prepared to tell me, what its reasons were. I point out that this is a body over which we, as a government, have no control. It makes its decisions based on the evidence and information it has from some of the best scientific brains in this field and we, as a government, receive its recommendations and act accordingly.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw attention to the presence in the gallery of a former senator of this place, Geoff McLaren, with Mrs McLaren and Mrs Audrey Robertson, the widow of our former colleague, Ted Robertson. I hope that their visit to the Parliament is enjoyable.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RELIEF OPERATIONS FOR KURDS IN IRAQ

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister give the Senate any further details of President Bush's announcement about relief operations for the Kurds inside Iraq? What is the Australian Government's attitude towards this development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, President Bush announced that following consultations with the United Nations (UN) Secretary-General and the leaders of Britain, Turkey, France and Germany, he had directed the United States of America military to establish what he described as five or six `encampments' in northern Iraq from which relief supplies could be distributed to Kurds.

ANSWER.PARA: From my understanding of what President Bush said, two very good reasons for taking this approach were emphasised. First, it will establish an on-site presence in Iraq through which supplies can be delivered and medical treatment given to those most in need. Secondly, it will require the Kurds to come down from the mountain terrain-which, in itself, is hampering the provision of relief-and set up camp in the lower more sheltered areas inside Iraq closer to their homes.

It is important to appreciate that what President Bush is proposing is by no stretch of the imagination a military offensive against the Iraqi army. It is purely a humanitarian exercise which is to be facilitated inside Iraq by the only organisation in a position to do that job without delay, that is to say, the United States (US) military.

The military, as I understand it, will establish the camps and provide security for both the Kurds who visit them and the international relief agencies which will work from them. The encampments will thus serve as a bridge for the return of Kurds to their traditional homelands, which is both the objective of the international community and the desire of the majority of the displaced Kurds.

Importantly, President Bush has characterised the scheme as an interim measure and not as a permanent stationing of US ground forces in Iraq. The Iraqi Government has to date heeded the US warning not to fly aircraft north of the thirty-sixth parallel and will, hopefully-we do not yet know-raise no substantive objection to the current relief effort. Iraq, after all, has a standing amnesty on Kurds returning to their homes. The UN humanitarian relief delegation currently in Iraq, led by Eric Suy, has yet to make its report but will no doubt be liaising with the Iraqi authorities on the implementation of this plan.
