Authority for the action in question derives from Security Council resolution 688, which requests the Secretary-General to `use all resources at his disposal' to urgently address the needs of the refugees and further `demands that Iraq cooperate with the Secretary-General to these ends'. In fulfilling this requirement, the US initiative builds on the idea initially expressed by Turkey and picked up by Britain of establishing an area in which relief could be got to the Kurdish people without them or the relief agencies being attacked by Iraqi forces.

Australia very much welcomes this development as a positive and timely step in the right direction in that it better directs the emergency relief effort in the short term and encourages a return to Iraq by the refugees in the longer term.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TRANSFER OF SOCIAL WELFARE PROGRAMS TO STATES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to next month's Special Premiers Conference, which will consider proposals for an exchange of powers between the Commonwealth and the States. Does the Minister have any objection in principle to the proposed handing over to the States of the home and community care program and the supported accommodation assistance program, or to the reduction of tied grants to the States? If so, on what basis?

—I share with the Prime Minister a desire to see that unnecessary duplication and hence unnecessary expense to taxpayers between the States and the Commonwealth are eliminated. I trust that the exercise between the Commonwealth and the States achieves that over the next few years. The programs to be transferred to the States and the methods by which that will be done are a matter for the Government. A number of reviews are yet to be completed before any decisions are made, and the Cabinet has yet to address the issue. I shall make whatever comments I believe appropriate on any of those programs to the Cabinet when that discussion occurs.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr Deputy President. I welcome the Minister's in-principle support for the proposition. I therefore ask whether he stands by his usual high-principled claim, contained in his recent letter to the Prime Minister, to the effect that the Labor Government had gained considerable kudos - -
—Have you got the letter there?
—No, I have not, but I am sure that the Minister could hand it over.
—How do we know it is true?
—If the Minister wants to tell me that it is untrue, he can go for his life.
—We are asking you to verify it.

—If the Minister is denying it, that is fine. The letter to the Prime Minister said that the Labor Government had gained considerable kudos from taking the reins of social welfare matters and would only lose ground by handing them back to the States. Is that the true matter of principle involved?

—The true matter of principle involved in any transfer of function from the Commonwealth to the States must be that clients have no ill effects from that transfer. Those people affected by program delivery must still get whatever their appropriate reward is, and more if possible. That is the concern that I and the Government have. We will make sure that that is achieved in whatever we do through discussions with the States.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to continued community concern about the massive oil slick in the Persian Gulf arising from the recent hostilities in the Middle East. Can the Minister provide an update on direct assistance being given by Australia to the international clean-up operation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I advised the Senate last month, Australia dispatched two oil pollution experts to be a part of the international coordination committee on cleaning up the spill in the Gulf. One was from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority and the other was from the Australian Institute of Petroleum. Both of those experts have now returned to Australia and have been replaced by others from the Queensland Department of Transport and, again, the Australian Institute of Petroleum. They made a very positive contribution to assisting with the clean-up of the spill. It has been reported to me that we have benefited greatly from this knowledge, in that we now have the capacity to provide assistance, if it were necessary-and hopefully it will not be-with any major problem such as an oil spill in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia also sent to the Gulf last month two oil skimmers on board a Royal Australian Air Force courier flight. The Australian equipment was put into immediate use in the Gulf at Abu 'Ali Island and has contributed significantly to the recovery of oil from Gulf waters. Each one of these skimmers is capable of recovering about 45 tonnes of oil per hour. The skimmers were drawn from the reserve of oil spill control equipment which forms part of Australia's national plan to combat pollution of the sea by oil. However, the removal of these two pieces of equipment from the Australian inventory will not affect in any way our capacity to cope with an emergency should it happen here, because the Australian Government-and I am very pleased with the cooperation I have received from the Minister for Finance-committed itself to replacing immediately the quarter of a million dollars worth of equipment which has been sent to the Gulf.

I am also pleased to advise the Senate that the Saudi Arabian Government has written to us formally thanking Australia for its past contribution, and its ongoing contribution, to cleaning up the oil spill in the Gulf.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AMBASSADOR TO IRELAND AND HOLY SEE: TELEPHONE BILL

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the telephone bill for the official telephone in the Australian Ambassador's residence in Ireland in 1988-89, which was almost $16,000, four times the figure for comparable European posts-and this was prior to the Western Australia Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters. Are telephone calls to lawyers and former political colleagues in connection with the WA Inc. scandal, which has led to the current Royal Commission, classified as official or private? Who is responsible for the classification of telephone calls as official or private? Of the approximately $16,000 bill for 1988-89, what proportion of telephone calls were reported as private?

—Before responding to that question, I would need to satisfy myself as to the nature of the amounts in question and the particular ground rules that are supposed to apply to these telephone arrangements, the extent of comparable practices elsewhere and the nature of comparable bills in comparable posts. I am not in a position to give an answer on the spot to any of those questions. I will take the question on notice and respond as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask this question against the background of the determinations made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission yesterday and some of the interpretations placed upon these decisions. What is the impact of the Bench's decision upon the prices and incomes accord between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions? Does the national wage case decision mean that the accord, as claimed, is dead?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was Mark Twain who said, `Reports of my death are greatly exaggerated'. If that were the case, those words are applicable to the accord. Those pundits who have forecast in some of the articles that I have seen today that the accord may be over, or the accord is dead, are greatly exaggerating the situation. The accord is in good shape, although it is true-and this is a relevant part of the question from Senator Loosely-that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has not endorsed key elements of it in terms of wage fixation, superannuation and enterprise bargaining; and that is regrettable.

ANSWER.PARA: I can say that the accord has served Australia well. Its basic premise is to maintain living standards and break away from the paper chase after money wages that the unions once engaged in -money wages which were frequently eroded because they pushed up prices and pushed those wage categories into higher tax brackets.

To replace that old system with a system in which we negotiate living standards by levels of wages, by reductions in taxes and by provisions of service through the social wage as a way of managing wage outcomes, has meant that the economy has, in each Budget since we have been in power, undershot the aggregate wage outcome forecast for that Budget; and it has meant that wages have played a very positive role in bringing down levels of inflation.

As well as that, the accord has reduced non-farm unit labour costs since 1983 significantly. It has restored the profit share that applied in the Fraser period from the low in 1982 of 12.4 per cent back to a more reasonable level. It has generated funds for further investment, and employment growth has meant that now 1.4 million extra jobs have been created. Medicare, of course, is also part of the social wage that the accord has brought to the Australian community.

I can understand that there is some frustration on the union side because the increase awarded by the Commission yesterday discriminates against those people who are on lower incomes. It is not the $12 flat that was sought. It is a percentage, which means that those people who have borne the weight of the wage restraint in this community but who are at the lower end of the income scale suffer most. In our view, that is not a fair outcome and is certainly not the outcome we sought.

It also means that there will be greater pressure on the Government to do more on the tax cut front in exchange for wages. We believe that is an unwelcome pressure, given that the Commission should have enabled company level negotiations to proceed in a way in which both partners in the company-the workers and the management-could identify, preferably through a strategic plan for that company, how they could increase productivity and how the benefits of that increased productivity could be fairly shared between the workers who helped generate it and the managers and owners who invested in the operations of that company. I think that is an unfortunate outcome as well.

I notice that the Australian Council of Trade Unions is calling for talks with the Federal Government. We will be looking forward to those talks. I think it is vital that accord mark 7, when we reach it, guarantees that we can replicate the record that we had in 1984-85-86-87, during which time the economy grew and recovered from the depression of the Fraser years.

The accord has enabled moderate wage outcomes to be achieved and has channelled more money into profits and thus into investment. I hope that this time in the coming recovery the money that goes into profits is not used for a binge of speculative takeovers with the high fliers of the corporate sector taking over one another and investing in shares, but instead goes into genuine investment and wealth creation and positions Australian industry to grow and expand in a more competitive international environment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support-until 6 May.
—Order, Senator Tierney! Ironical expressions are not allowed in questions. Please continue your question.

—I refer the Minister to my question of yesterday about the Prime Minister's claim in his 12 March statement that two enterprise agreements had been achieved on the waterfront. Senator Collins, in his reply, said-and I quote from Hansard:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the question is a nonsense because it is simply untrue. The Prime Minister said nothing of the sort.
I remind the Minister of the Prime Minister's actual words-and I quote directly from the 12 March statement:
It is particularly satisfying to be able to report to the House on the achievement, just last week, of a new agreement that will deliver breakthroughs in waterfront productivity.

The agreement between the Waterside Worker's Federation and Conaust Ltd, following an earlier agreement with National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, now means waterfront employees and the two largest waterfront employers are committed to a total restructuring of their industry.

I now ask the Minister: who is misleading the Parliament-the Prime Minister, who made the statement knowing full well that the Conaust agreement was not finalised and was about to be aborted by a union claim, or the Minister, who said that the Prime Minister said nothing of the sort?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Tierney, that was a very long question. I would invite you to ask shorter questions in future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the nonsense continues. As I said yesterday, the issue was canvassed fully yesterday. The statement by the Prime Minister - -

—It has already been tabled in the Senate, but if those opposite want to table it again, they can go ahead. As I said yesterday in the Senate, the Prime Minister's statement was accompanied by a full statement by me in the Senate. The terms of that agreement-and the agreement stands; it has not been aborted-between the Waterside Workers Federation and Conaust Ltd stand. That agreement was to accept the conditions laid down on the six outstanding issues of the enterprise agreement as recommended by Commissioner Sweeney in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, an institution which the Opposition is pledged to destroy.

ANSWER.PARA: Having spoken to all the parties again today in this matter, I have no fears about a proper resolution, as I know will occur, in the Industrial Relations Commission. What I fear, and what would be very bad indeed for this country, is that under the no wages policy approach of the Opposition and the devil take the hindmost approach that it advocates, strategically placed unions such as the Waterside Workers Federation, whose strategic power far outweighs its numbers, could play merry hell, as it has done in the past; but because it is a party to the accord and has agreed to accept the restraint provided by the accord and work within the wage fixing principles, that matter will be determined properly in the Commission, and that is where it should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister really claim that there is an agreement between Conaust and the Waterside Workers Federation when the agreement has been signed by Conaust but not by the unions and the agreement document is now lodged with the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority (WIRA) for acceptance and approval?

—There are two parties to an agreement. I understand the strategic reason why Conaust lodged its agreement with the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority yesterday. Claims are being made on both sides and it depends which one is picked up and which paper is believed. Some people are saying that the difference is 14.5 per cent. We heard here in the Senate yesterday that it was supposed to be 20 per cent. In fact, it is a fraction of that. The parties are negotiating this issue and the matter is in the Commission. As I said yesterday, that is where it will be finally determined and is where it should be.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. Is the Minister concerned that Austudy offices throughout Australia have refused to issue counter cheques or make other emergency payments to students facing hardship because of delays in payment, and that offices have been instructed not to issue counter cheques and have informed students that, according to policy, counter cheques are not being issued? Is the Minister concerned that this is in direct contradiction to statements by him in the Senate on 6, 7 and 12 March this year that students in financial hardship should seek urgent payment through access to counter cheques? Do the case studies I have provided to the Minister so far demonstrate the failure of this Government to provide any income support for students who are facing hardship because of lengthy delays in payment of Austudy? If not, can the Minister tell the Senate how many counter cheques have been issued to students since 1 January 1991?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned, but I am concerned more at Senator Bell's presumptions in his question rather than in the facts he alleges. I think that he has some of them essentially wrong and I am so informed. I am informed that he was wrong in claiming that students could not get assistance until the commencement of the academic year. Further on, he claimed that students could get assistance from the Department of Social Security. I am further advised that some of the information that Senator Bell has been passing on to students has been misleading. I am further advised that he is wrong in claiming that the Department will not issue counter cheques.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to correct Senator Bell's earlier errors, the Department has circularised its officers setting out the exact circumstances under which counter cheques would be issued and released a press statement to this effect, and I table the press statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are they supposed to be?

—If Senator Bell holds on, he will get the answer. Where a student's application is awaiting assessment and where the student can provide evidence that he or she is likely to be eligible for Austudy and is suffering financial hardship, emergency payments can and are being made by Austudy officers. Those payments could include the issuing of counter cheques.

ANSWER.PARA: Priority is given to students applying for the homeless or other independent rate or who are transferring from a social security benefit. I am advised that over 800 emergency payments have been issued since 1 January 1991. I note that only half of the cases provided to me by Senator Bell this morning make out a claim for financial hardship. I also noted in the papers he sent me this morning that I am not to proceed with those cases unless I get his advice, and I have chosen not to proceed with them. But, in the normal way, if Senator Bell is prepared to cooperate on those cases, I will have them pursued and processed to ensure not only that the allegation that he makes is wrong but also that the information that the Department has provided to me is right.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the Government's plan to remove the local content component for sales tax purposes on fruit juice products. In view of the desperate plight of Australia's citrus growers, compounded by the announcement on 12 March of an eventual 10 per cent reduction in the tariff on imported juice resulting in no tariff for Brazilian imports, will the Minister agree that it is now imperative that the Government back Mr Kerin's commitment and rescind the sales tax decision due on 1 July?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been aware of problems in the citrus industry for a long time, and I am sure that Senator Boswell knows that. Basically, these problems are caused by two things: first, the great variability in the world price of frozen concentrated orange juice, much of it being from Brazil; and, secondly, the slow rate at which the industry as a whole has been able to do anything necessary to reduce its dependence on fruit for juicing and improve its performance in the fresh fruit market, both domestically and overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, took a submission on the citrus industry to the Cabinet just before Christmas last year. As a result, the Government agreed to support and speed up the industry's application of an anti-dumping finding. The Government also provided an additional $2m for the promotion of fresh oranges and juice, to be made available through the Australian Horticultural Corporation.

Curiously enough, representatives of the citrus industry are this very week meeting to decide whether they will withdraw from the Australian Horticultural Corporation. If they do they will, of course, not have access to that additional $2m, and for this and other reasons the Government is very hopeful that the industry representatives will agree to stay in the Corporation.

Following Cabinet's consideration, Minister Kerin also established a special Commonwealth-State citrus advisory group. This has already met three times, and one of the important elements of its report to the Minister will be a statement of the impact of the withdrawal of local content provision, mentioned by Senator Boswell in his question. In the meantime the Government has agreed to postpone the decision which was due to take effect on 1 July this year. What happens to the local content provision after that will depend in part on the recommendations of the citrus advisory group.

While the Government is sympathetic to the industry's problems, I should point out to honourable senators that the world prices for both orange juice and fresh fruit have already risen since before Christmas. Once again, some of the immediate pressures for change may have been removed but the Government hopes that the industry will continue to accept the need for change and do what needs to be done to improve our performance in exporting fresh citrus.

Finally, it will be recalled that part of the Prime Minister's industry statement was about speeding up the rate of tariff reductions. These further reductions will affect the citrus industry and provide a further stimulus to cooperatively restructure that industry and focus on fresh fruit exports and on promotion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to the current widespread concern within the community about the costs of justice, which the Minister will be aware is currently the subject of a detailed examination by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, so ably chaired by my colleague and seat mate Senator Cooney. What is the Government proposing to do to address concerns which have arisen as a result of the Committee's proceedings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government is aware of the concerns about Australians having access to better and cheaper justice, particularly in the Federal Court system. That is why we are taking steps to introduce new legislation to give groups with a common legal cause better and cheaper access to that court. The legislation will not confer any new legal rights but it will certainly allow people to assert existing rights collectively, effectively and more cheaply. If such a measure had been in operation, the present actions by haemophiliacs and others, who have medically contracted acquired immune deficiency syndrome, for example, could have proceeded with one action representing the general group of AIDS sufferers. Similarly, those individual investors affected by the recent corporate collapses might well have been able to pursue their claims more cheaply and efficiently as a group using this type of procedure. For example, the reforms could benefit shareholders who had suffered loss as a result of a misleading prospectus or stock market manipulation.

ANSWER.PARA: This will be a reform of great benefit to many individual Australians who, as individuals, do not have great financial resources but who can be adversely affected by the actions of one company or organisation. On the other hand, for the companies and organisations concerned, it could be a more efficient way to deal with legal disputes than the present alternative of facing a succession of individual cases. There is a proper concern in Australia about the cost of justice and I am delighted that the Senate has established a reference to a committee on that particular matter. People who have been denied access to justice in the past because of the high costs involved will now have that barrier removed by acting in concert with numerous fellow claimants. The measures that the Government will introduce into the Senate shortly make an important contribution to the Government's determination to ensure that the courts are not the sole province of the rich, the Government and large corporations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell asked me on 15 April about making public the reports made by the receivers of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd, former operators of the Ravenshoe sawmill. The receivers' duty under section 324c of the Companies Code, now section 422 of the corporations law, is: if they believe that company officers may have committed an offence, to report and provide information to the Supreme Court and the Australian Securities Commission-not to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, nor her Department. The receivers have informed the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories that a report under section 324c has been made to the Securities Commission but, as it is a confidential document, the receivers have declined to provide a copy or describe the contents.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will no doubt be aware that the Securities Commission, while within the portfolio of the Attorney-General, has statutory independence and is obliged to conduct its inquiries with strict confidentiality. Reports made under section 324c of the Companies Code fall within a class of documents to which individuals are not entitled to have access. Mrs Kelly's Department therefore does not have access to the receivers' report. Even if the Department had a copy of such a report, nothing in it could be released publicly without prejudicing possible legal action; not only by the Commonwealth to protect its interests as creditor but also by the regulatory authorities to enforce the companies law.

Senators Boswell and O'Chee were reported in the media over the last few days as claiming that there are secret reports from the receivers which Mrs Kelly's Department has but will not make public. If they mean statutory reports under the Companies Code, as I have said, the responsible Department learnt of the existence of such a report only in the last week and does not have a copy. But if it did, it would not and could not release it.

There are no reports from the receivers relating to the operation of Plywood and Plastic Pty Ltd in the Department's possession other than two letters from the receivers to the Minister. For the same reasons that I have just given, to publicise them would prejudice the investigations that are under way. I do not think it is appropriate that that should happen. I am sure that all honourable senators will understand that there is nothing more I can or should say about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Reid asked me a number of questions about an inquiry into the Commonwealth employees compensation and rehabilitation scheme. They were questions of fact. I have a reply which I could read into Hansard, but which I would prefer to seek leave to incorporate, which answers all the questions raised by Senator Reid.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Cook

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 April 1991 Senator Reid asked me as Minister for Industrial Relations the following question without notice:

INTERJECT.PARA: Has the Minister for Industrial Relations initiated a review of the 1988 Commonwealth employees' compensation scheme? If so, what are the terms of reference of the review? Who has been consulted about the operation of the scheme in the past two years and when will the review report?

In my reply, I indicated that I have initiated a Review of Comcare, the Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth Employees, and I promised to provide more information. I now provide the following response:

I did initiate a review of the Comcare program in December last year. When the Government approved the reform of the Commonwealth Workers' Compensation system in 1987, it decided that so wide-ranging a reform needed to be re-examined after about two years of operation, to see if all its components were working as had been expected. That was the purpose of this review.
I have the terms of reference of the Review here, and would like to table them.

A number of client agencies of Comcare, Unions, individual compensation claimants, service providers, special interest groups and others with an interest in the scheme's operation have made written submissions to the Review.

In addition, consultation with people or organisations with an interest in the program was undertaken by way of a stakeholder survey conducted by Pappas, Carter, Evans and Koop, a management consulting firm. This consisted of interviews with selected clients and a wider survey of client attitudes.

There were meetings with Comcare's employer consultative group (attended by about 50 employer representatives), and with union representatives (unions representing more than 75 per cent of workers covered by Comcare attended this meeting). There was also a seminar for senior government decision makers involved with Comcare. I expect to receive the final report of the Review by the end of next week.
ATTACHMENT
COMCARE REVIEW
The terms of reference of the Review are to examine:
Comcare's financial performance;
the effectiveness of Comcare's integrated approach to the management of the Commonwealth public sector workers' compensation function;
any policy and legislative changes needed to enable Comcare to better achieve the Government's intended outcomes;
Comcare's achievements with reference to its corporate objectives and performance indicators;
the attitude of Comcare's customers (employees and employers) and service providers to the program and to Comcare's management of the program;
an analysis of the effectiveness of the self-administrators pilot under the program; and
future directions for the Commonwealth workers' compensation function, in general, and Comcare, in particular.
The Review is led by an independent chair, Mr Ron Brown, a management consultant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of questions from me have been on the Notice Paper for more than 30 days. I therefore wish to ask, in accordance with the resolution of the Senate, for explanations by a number of Ministers of why answers have not been provided to me in eight instances: question No. 442 to the Minister for Administrative Services; question Nos 443, 445, and 488 to the Minister representing the Treasurer; question Nos 500 and 558 to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance; question No. 536 to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health; and question No. 537 to the Minister representing the Attorney-General.
—There is no answer, Senator Short.

—All those Ministers are absent. I point out to the Senate that the most notable absence is that of Senator Button, whom I notified during Question Time that I would be raising this matter at the end of Question Time. He has not had the courtesy to remain in the chamber for it. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate note the Ministers' failure to provide responses to questions on notice Nos. 442, 443, 445, 448, 500, 536, 537 and 558, which have been on the Notice Paper for more than 30 days.

As we have pointed out on many occasions in recent months, the Government is absolutely ignoring normal, proper courtesies in relation to questions asked by the Opposition and is therefore refusing to abide by the accepted parliamentary procedures and the normal courtesies of the Parliament. I find it a very sad proposition indeed that this Government is in effect prostituting the role of the Parliament by its refusal to act in accordance with the Standing Orders of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly during Estimates.

—As my colleague Senator Tambling has pointed out, it is particularly relevant at this time when we are in the middle of Estimates hearings, a process which we, at least on this side of the Senate, regard as being of considerable importance. It is even more important that those questions on notice be answered within the normal statutory requirements as laid down by the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that I am not on my own in this matter. Many of my colleagues are suffering in exactly the same way. I do ask you, Mr Deputy President, in your official capacity, to raise with the President the failure of the Government to observe the normal Standing Orders of this Parliament which the Government has accepted but which it is observing more in the breach.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware of the fact that the motion which gave rise to this order was moved by the former leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Macklin. Therefore we very much support the principle of placing accountability on Ministers-an accountability which we believed, until quite recently, was in fact evaded and in some cases deliberately abused. It was by virtue of that concern that this order came into place. Therefore, we most definitely support the motion that is before the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The general principle is the matter that has been raised by Senator Short and is clearly important. This motion also concerns the substance of the questions themselves, which raises the serious point of why the Government is failing to reply to questions that have been on the Notice Paper for such a long time. Clearly, there does seem to be some political import in its failure to answer some of these questions. For example, a question has remained unanswered for 63 days. In it, in part, Senator Short asked the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus):

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Is the Government still funding the price watch activities of the National Prices Network.
(2) What additional staff resources are currently provided to Members of Parliament (MP) for the purposes of price watch activities.

This question goes on at some length because we in the Opposition have been greatly concerned by the diversion of large amounts of money to what is clearly a political stunt by a group of government members supported at some substantial expense by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the taxpayer.

—I shall accept that interjection. I wonder what has prompted the Government to refuse to reply to that simple direct question for 63 days. There are some clear implications, too, for the advantage that the Government is giving some of those Government members. Another part of Senator Short's question asks:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Has the Minister for Administrative Services made available any computer, fax or photocopy equipment in his electorate or ministerial office for the purposes of price watch activities; if so, please provide details.

(5) Has any computer, fax or photocopy equipment been made available to MPs for the purpose of the National Prices Network since the March 1990 Federal election; if so, please provide the name of the MP, the date on which the computer, fax or photocopy equipment was provided, and what the equipment comprised.

These are matters of some substance and expense. What has the Government got to hide in not answering the questions? No doubt Senator Patterson can explain the importance of the questions to which she has not had a reply from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe). There is a whole range of questions. Senator Short asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) the following question:

With reference to the Minister's second reading speech of 8 November 1990 . . . in which he stated that without adjustments to the haulage tariff, the Government would withdraw the pipeline system from sale, has the pipeline been withdrawn from sale; if not, what is the current status of the Government's proposal for sale, and does the Government have a timetable for conclusion of the sale.

That is a matter of major substance. Why have we not had an answer? It seems to me that, in the absence of the Ministers involved who knew, who were aware-at least in one instance-that this matter was to be raised now, in their failure to attend and to explain, the Opposition has every reason to query the Government's bona fides on this matter. Why will the Government not answer these questions? They are direct questions which the Opposition is entitled to ask. I ask the Government to recognise that its failure to respond casts serious doubts over its treatment of this Parliament and, as a result, the treatment of the representatives of the people who have every right to ask where the taxpayers' money is really going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to speak to the same motion. Only a few weeks ago, the President of the Senate asked Ministers to remain until the end of Question Time, particularly when an honourable senator has given notice to one of those Ministers that he intends, under the Standing Orders, under the procedures of the Senate, to ask about a question on notice left unanswered for longer than a month. It is a discourtesy not only to that honourable senator but to the whole chamber that that Minister has not responded. He has not even left a message with the duty Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that Ministers need to be reminded that the Government, the Executive of this country, is responsible to the elected representatives of the people in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. If we do not treat this complaint seriously, we will find that Ministers will fail in their accountability to this Parliament. Mr Deputy President, I would expect that, in light of the motion that may be adopted in a matter of minutes, you will bring to the attention of the Minister, Senator Button, who is the Leader of the Government in the Senate, that he is required to give an answer during Question Time or at the end of Question Time tomorrow. One would hope that he would include in the answer the reason he was distracted from being here on this occasion.

I further ask that Ministers remain in the Senate after Question Time until the next item of business is brought on. I make this point because on any sitting day any senator has the ability to draw to the attention of a Minister that a question on notice has not been answered. If we let the discipline slip, we will let down the Senate and the processes of the Parliament. We must ensure that Ministers are accountable and that they answer questions put by senators who have been elected to this place.
Amendment (by Senator Hill) proposed:

At end of motion, add ``and the Senate expresses its continuing concern at the lack of courtesy by Ministers in failing to attend the Chamber and to provide adequate reasons for failure to answer questions, and requires that the answers to questions on notice Nos 442, 443, 445, 448, 500, 536, 537 and 558 be laid on the Table of the Senate on the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak mainly because I am concerned about the fact that our questions have not been answered. Many of us have tried in a polite, appropriate and courteous way to seek answers from Ministers. In fact, last week I sent a note to Senator Tate telling him that I was going to raise an issue. Senator Short did the same thing today. Senator Tate responded in the Senate on 9 April by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Patterson has sent me a note indicating that she is concerned that she has not received an answer to Question on Notice number 443.

This question pertains to an area which is of particular interest to me. It is about the holding of personal information by the Health Insurance Commission. As honourable senators know, the Health Insurance Commission now holds all of our Medicare records plus all of our pharmaceutical records. It also holds in some 20 or so other forms private information about individuals. There was little or no concern on the part of the Department of Community Services and Health, until I started questioning it, about whether that information should be depersonalised or not.

This is a question which is of great concern. I have not been asking some mindless question. I have been asking systematically a series of questions to try to get a very clear understanding of the sort of personal data that is held about individuals which can identify, as the Department has said during Estimates committee hearings, a family's fibro cystic disease or phenyl ketonuria. The community ought to be debating whether information like that should be held and be identified as relating to individuals and families.

I was told by Senator Tate that the question I had asked was made up of 21 parts. Well, I have asked a 21-part question in respect of every one of the classes of records being held by the Department. So they are not new to the Department. Senator Tate said that he understood from Mr Howe that the answer was in the course of being prepared for the Minister's consideration in the next day or so. That was what the Minister said on 9 April. I have been waiting for over a month for the answer to that question.

I have a particular reason for wanting the answer. I would have liked to have had it before the Estimates Committee meets tomorrow. I think it would have been appropriate if the Minister had delivered the answer to that question. Ministers should have been in the chamber, particularly when they were given notice that Senator Short was going to ask them questions.

I find the treatment of these questions appalling. I think that the Government needs to lift its game, and that members of the Australian public ought to know the sort of deal that the Opposition gets in trying to find out how their Government-the Government that they elected-operates, and how little regard it has for this place.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim that I was misrepresented twice yesterday in the House of Representatives by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) because of my stance on corporate tax on goldmining companies. Mr Keating told the House as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . members for Pearce, O'Connor and Tangney and Senators Crichton-Browne and Panizza . . . should be brought before the . . . Royal Commission to find out what their relationship with this long-established industry really has been; including, lately, Alan Bond and, for that matter, Mr Connell.

I categorically deny that I have ever met or contacted Mr Bond or Mr Connell. My interest in the goldmining industry is purely a matter of representing an industry of major importance which includes medium sized operations as well as prospectors. My views on gold tax have never changed. I was totally opposed to gold tax at the time and still am now, and would do and say the same things if the debate arose again. Time will prove me right.

I am also the only senator or member from Western Australia who actually lives in the goldfields, except for Mr Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, so it is understandable that I represent that industry alongside the wheat industry, the wool industry, the transport industry and the fishing industry. I note that Mr Keating did not slam Mr Campbell who has exactly the same views on gold tax as I have.
The second point on which Mr Keating misrepresented me is as follows:

I . . . claim that these decisions by the honourable members for Pearce, O'Connor and Tangney and Senators Crichton-Browne and Panizza to change the policy of the Opposition at the cost of the Opposition Leader and to replace him is one of the most corrupt operations of machine politics in the interests of an industry that we have ever seen in this country.

I categorically deny that I took any part whatsoever in any moves to replace Mr Howard. In fact, if Mr Keating were to check the Daily News of 9 May 1989, he would see that he is mighty wrong. Furthermore, the coalition did not change its policy on gold tax at the time, it simply kept the position it had had for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Boswell on 15 April 1991, relating to the receivers' reports on the Ravenshoe sawmill.

In his answer, Senator Richardson told the Senate that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, did not know of the existence of reports made by the receivers of the Ravenshoe sawmill pursuant to section 324c of the Companies Code until last week. What Senator Richardson did not tell the Senate was how Mrs Kelly's attention was drawn to the existence of the reports, and the explanation is very simple.

Last week I asked Senator Richardson a question in relation to these matters. I drew his attention, outside the chamber, to the existence of the reports and he told me that he did not know about them. That is perfectly all right because Senator Richardson is only the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, but that Mrs Kelly did not know about these reports is simply astounding. She is, after all, the Minister who is responsible for the environment-the Minister who is responsible for the Department that has destroyed a township of 2,200 people.

The argument could be put that there is a distinction between the Australian Securities Commission and the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and that may well stand up to scrutiny. But what does not stand up to scrutiny is that the Australian Securities Commission reports to the Attorney-General. Last week, in answer to my question about whether there were prosecutions, Senator Richardson told us that the matter was being reported on by the Attorney-General's Department and that there are ongoing investigations that began six months ago. These include various reports and opinions from senior counsel and other investigations, which I understand include investigations by the Australian Federal Police.

If the Attorney-General's Department were really doing its job properly, or if it had any regard at all for Mrs Kelly, the so-called Minister for the environment, it is very clear that the existence of those reports would have been raised by the Attorney-General's Department in the course of the discussions with Mrs Kelly. As Senator Patterson said, maybe the Department did raise it but Mrs Kelly was too busy having her photograph taken at the time.

These are very serious issues. It is of great concern to me that a so-called investigation, which has so far lasted six months, an investigation into the disappearance of $7.6m of taxpayers' money and hundreds of thousands of dollars from ordinary businessmen and women in Ravenshoe, has been so contemptuously treated that the Minister responsible does not know of the reports by the receivers. I believe that this displays the Government's lack of concern for this matter, the Government's lack of concern for taxpayers' money and the Government's lack of concern for the people of Ravenshoe.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Parer proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need to ensure that all Australians continue to enjoy the right to freedom of expression that they currently enjoy.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a matter of public importance submitted by me on behalf of the Liberal and the National parties in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to ensure that all Australians continue to enjoy the right to freedom of expression that they currently enjoy.

This matter is not just of importance to the Australians of today, but of the greatest and most vital importance for Australians into the future-our children and our grandchildren-whose rights we must protect. When I last spoke on this matter I commenced the debate by saying that I never expected that one day I would be standing in the Senate in the Parliament of Australia pleading for freedom of speech. What prompted that and what prompted this matter of public importance today was the announcement by the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, that he had reached agreement with the Australian Democrats that he would introduce legislation which would ban all political advertising at all times on radio and television. Furthermore, it would apply at all levels of government-Federal, State and local.

The public's impression was that the ban was to apply only at election times, but the idea was to apply it across the board, 365 days of the year-a total ban, a blackout on radio and television. This outrageous assault on freedom of speech was attacked by every media group in Australia and a whole lot of other interest groups as well.

At the last count, I noted that there were 36 groups and individuals-and what a divergence of groups there was-from the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Burdekin; the Law Council of Australia; the Article 19 Group; Don Chipp; Janine Haines; Peter Garrett; and so on. One of the things I noted was the groups or individuals who supported the Minister. Who were they? Surprise, surprise: Bob Hogg; Martin Ferguson, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions; and Phillip Adams, that Australian Labor Party hack and former ALP advertising executive-a captive audience.

One of my colleagues-you, Mr Acting Deputy President-received a letter from one of the radio station leaders; in fact, the President of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters. In his letter he said:

I'd also like to share with you some thoughts I conveyed in a recent interview with an ABC journalist. I said amongst other things . . . who do they think they're dealing with-a peasantry-do they seriously think they can keep the Australian people in an information background-what are they trying to do? Stage an Atlantic style election?
He went on to say:
I know that even the newspapers are worried. They see this subterfuge, this hypocrisy, this unmitigated evil, as being the thin end of the wedge.

The Minister attempted to hold this ban together by linking this blatant censorship with public disclosure. In the debate on the urgency motion in the Senate last week we argued that the ban was a stand-alone issue-one either agreed with the ban on freedom of speech or one did not. It was a black and white issue. We argued that disclosure of political donations and truth in advertising were important matters-Senator Powell will remember that-which should be debated, but not as some sort of sleazy backroom trade-off to limit freedom of speech. That is what this Minister attempted to do. The Opposition is pleased to note that the Democrats last weekend came to the same conclusion as the Opposition.

The Government also argued that it was doing us all a favour and that the reason for the ban was to save money for political parties in election campaigns. Mr Acting Deputy President, can you imagine this Minister-this Government-being big-hearted and thinking about the Opposition, the Liberal and National parties, on a matter such as this? By his own actions the Minister showed this to be a lie because, in what could only be termed the height of hypocrisy, the Government proposed that government funding-taxpayer funding-to political parties would be increased by some $5m. How did he intend to do that? He intended to double the payment that is normally given to political parties from the Senate vote from 45.6c per vote to 91.2c per vote. The fact that the Minister and the Government thought anyone would swallow that just shows the extent of disarray and panic in which this Government finds itself and how hopelessly out of touch it is with the electorate.

In short, the Government was saying that it was free to advertise itself through its departments by direct mail, magazines, radio and television but that dissent through advertisements on radio and television would be illegal.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're a liar. You are a liar.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, I would ask you to withdraw those comments.
—Senator Parer makes a statement which he knows to be untrue.
—Order! Senator Bolkus - -
—I withdraw the word `lie', but it is an untruth.

—I will repeat what I said: under the Minister's proposal, political dissent through advertisements on radio and television would be illegal. That is what he said. No individual, group, special interest group or political party would be allowed to express a different point of view on radio and television by way of advertisements. What is so pernicious about this scheme is that the Government envisages that its own taxpayer-funded political party advertisements will be unaffected by the ban. Apparently, outside election campaigns there will be no restrictions on the Government's monopoly of the airwaves. So much for level playing fields!

SPEECH.PARA: Taxpayers are already footing the bill for the Hawke Government's propaganda machine, and already more than $232m has been spent promoting the incumbent administration. Probably with the ban in mind, earlier this year the Federal Government established a special ministerial committee called the Government Advertising Service, GAS, which is no doubt gearing up for massive information campaigns once all voices have been gagged.

From these signs, it is clear that the ban will not affect the amount of political advertising on television and radio-just the type. Whereas now there are advertisements produced and funded by political parties and other interest groups, in the future they will only be the propaganda of governments paid for by the long-suffering taxpayer.

Under the Minister's scheme, for all but one month of the three-year term of government, governments could spend our money on television and radio block- buster campaigns telling us what a great job they were doing. No other views or options could be presented in this way, and the only time the Government's advertising would be partly restricted was during the actual period of the election campaign.

During the election campaign proper, the Minister says that the Government will still be able to continue with government advertising necessary to cope with national emergencies, advertising by electoral authorities and commercial advertising by government business enterprises. Given this Government's track record, what is to stop it from abusing these provisions in the same way it misused taxpayers' money for self-promotion and partisan campaigning?

A couple of instances come to mind. For example, what if government business enterprises in question are those intended for privatisation by a coalition government and the Government's commercial advertising consists of subtle or not so subtle messages implying that they should remain in state ownership. There are also precedents where this Government has sought unfair advantage from electoral information. I instance the 1988 referendum campaign. It took a High Court judgment to stop the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government from broadcasting misleading and biased advertisements. Who can trust this lot?

I referred earlier to the Minister's press release, specifically confirming that charities would not be exempt from the ban. Therefore, it is obvious that there will be unprecedented and draconian results from the Government's proposal. However, these cannot be excused as unintended consequences because the Government has been told exactly where the ban will lead.

For example, the all-party Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommended against a complete ban on political advertising because it `would have a direct effect on freedom of speech by reducing opportunities for discussion during election periods when voters are determining the candidate or party they wish to support'. The Committee reported:

. . . most witnesses disagreed with a complete ban on political advertising, claiming that it would have an adverse effect on freedom of speech and in particular would disadvantage citizens and groups who wish to bring issues before the electorate.

In his usual dishonest way, the Minister continues to refer to the Joint Standing Committee report, claiming that it supports the Government's draconian policy; and yet every member of the Committee-Labor, Liberal, Democrat and Independent-recommended against a complete ban, including Senator Schacht. Last week in the urgency motion in this place, he said, `Yes, I signed the report, but do you know why? I was interested in consensus politics'. How about that! Consensus politics. What a dishonest statement to make. That is what consensus is all about.

The report of the Committee was received by the Government in 1989, and at that time the Government displayed no sense of urgency about dealing with the matter. Now suddenly it argues that it wants the ban introduced urgently because of corruption. Eight years since it came to power, in the aftermath of the Federal election where the ALP spent considerably more than its opponents on television advertising, we are told that it is imperative that there be a complete ban on the broadcasting of political advertising.

The Government is on notice that its proposal would further enhance the ability of incumbent governments to exploit the spoils of office and cling to power-that is what it is all about-prevent individuals and interest groups from taking their message directly to the people; prevent charities from appealing for funds if they are deemed to be political; deny Australians in rural and provincial areas, where people rely on radio and television rather than newspapers, the opportunity to hear alternative points of view; and limit the freedom of some 110,000 blind or sight impaired Australians and one million plus classified as illiterate to receive political information in the most direct and meaningful way.
Further the Minister has noted:
. . . journalists will be more powerful shapers of public opinion after the ban on political advertising comes into effect.
He said that:
. . . the ban would allow reporters more power to get political assessments across.

This reflects the fact that the ban will deprive all Australians who are dissatisfied with the coverage they receive in the media, or who think it biased, the right to present their views to the public direct and uncensored. If the only way to put political arguments to the public is through the newspapers and through the news and current affairs programs of the broadcast media, enormous power is placed in the hands of those who control such programs. As with every other change to the political process introduced by this Government, it is necessary to look at its hidden agenda. As the Daily Mirror stated on 5 April last year:

This plan to limit the appearance of the politicians on our television screens is not really an attempt to magnanimity on the part of the government. It is a part of a desperate effort to save the party machine from going bankrupt. Labor's money problems . . . are partly the result of its poor performance with primary votes in the last election . . .
The Australian Civil Liberties Union contends that:
. . . the argument that such a ban is necessary to combat corruption is spurious, in view of the absence of evidence of corruption at the federal level . . .

It said that the proposed ban, aimed at helping the ALP overcome its election funding problems, would not be necessary if there was an increase in membership and if it avoided wasting money on election campaign gimmicks, as it has in the past. It is the height of hypocrisy for the Labor Party to say that the ever increasing costs of campaigning justifies this restriction on our freedom because, in the same breath, it proposes to add a further $5m to the taxpayers' subsidy given to political parties.

The other reason given was the potential for corruption and was thus linked to public disclosure. Until now-and I emphasise until now-federal politics has had an enviable reputation of being free of any corruption. It is fascinating that the image has been dirtied by the Labor Party. Day after day we see in the other place Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister of our country suffering from selective amnesia. He did not remember whether he mentioned gold tax over a luncheon with Laurie Connell and others who had a vested interest in gold. But after the luncheon, $950,000 was donated to the Labor Party by Laurie Connell and others. Anyone who believes that the Prime Minister did not give a watertight guarantee at that meeting in order to get this enormous donation would, to use a favourite expression of Senator Peter Walsh, still believe in fairies at the bottom of the garden.

Let me address disclosure. The Liberal and National parties took the view that we would support disclosure provided it was equitable. No-one can ask for more than that. What that means is that we want to be assured that any person or corporation who made a donation was not singled out for intimidation by a government of another political persuasion or a third party. Is Senator Bolkus objecting to that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us how you got rolled.
—Labor members agree with intimidation, do they, because they are used to it? An example of the latter would be harassment by a militant union. It means that there must be a level playing field - -

—I rise on a point of order. Senator Parer was eliciting interjections. He did not get any, and then drew an inference from that fact. I think any inference that he has drawn should not be taken for the record.
—Order! I do not believe that there is a point of order. I ask Senator Parer to continue.

—If there must be a level playing field, let us have one. There is not one at present. The major benefactor is the Australian Labor Party because of its trade union connections. Trade union membership dues are tax deductible. Affiliation fees of those unions with the Labor Party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions come from tax deductible moneys. Whether they like it or not-and many do not, but have no say in it-membership fees of individual trade unions are used to affiliate with the ALP. There is no say on the part of the individual union member. All income from investments by trade unions is free of income tax and capital gains tax. Donations from unions to the Labor Party are therefore paid from tax-free moneys. On the other hand, all donations to the Liberal and National parties and the Australian Democrats by individuals or companies are after-tax moneys. This is not a level playing field. If the Labor Party is serious about disclosure with equity, then those serious inequities must be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Trade unions today are big business. I was fascinated to read recently the Cooke report in Queensland on the Federated Clerks Union of Australia. The union decided to reaffiliate with the ALP in Queensland at a cost of $30,000 a year. It had a meeting with none other than the Premier of Queensland, Mr Wayne Goss, and the ALP President, Mr Ian McLean. It sounds somewhat like a Connell luncheon, does it not? The reason that the leaders of the clerks union gave for paying $30,000 was:

The obvious benefits for the union are an opportunity to influence government policy and decision making; ensuring that clerks through their union have a say in the various forums and improved access to Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are proud of that link.

—What does that mean? It means that if the $30,000 affiliation fee was not paid it would not be able to influence policy. With that sort of background, Mr Wayne Swan will make a likely candidate for the Senate. I could not help but notice when I was looking around the Senate here that of the 32 Labor senators who sit opposite, 10 of them are ex-party secretaries and ex-party assistant secretaries; they are nothing more than party hacks.
—So what?

—The senator is one of them. He would know all the lurks. Professor Gilbert, Professor of Law at the Queensland University of Technology, said in a letter to the Courier-Mail that it is not surprising that this Government has targeted television, as control of the media is what all modern dictators are about. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The Saddam Husseins of this world know the power of `the box'. So apparently does Mr Hawke.
The coalition's view is that when Labor governments say they are curbing freedom of expression and freedom of speech in the public interest, it is time for everyone to worry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came in here this afternoon hoping-hoping in vain, I suppose-that we might get some positive contribution to what is very much a serious problem. I have listened very closely to Senator Parer. He made six points in his contribution and each was based on an untruth.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make the point at the start that our link from the Australian Labor Party (ALP) side with the trade union movement is historical; it has gone on for a century and it is one we are proud of and stand up for. Our involvement with our organisation is such that we produce people of the quality of Senator Faulkner, Senator Beahan, Senator Schacht and others. They make an important contribution and we are proud of that. We will not have their names being smeared by Senator Parer in the way that he has.

Senator Parer's speech was littered with untruths. We made it very clear from the start that government advertising would be handled in the same way as other advertising. The Government's ministerial committee was set up. It was not a new committee; it was the continuation of an old one, and he knows that.

In respect of community groups and their appeals for funds-it has been made very clear that such matters as appeals for funds are not to be seen as political matters. Senator Parer went on to say that federal politics have been sullied by the Labor Party in recent days. It was Mr Eggleton a month ago who made it very clear in a stark comment to Michelle Grattan of the Melbourne Age as to the interrelationship between his side of politics and the corporate dollar. I quote Mr Eggleton:

If a company asks me for access (to Fraser), I would not intimate how big a donor they were but I might say that a friend of the party wanted to see him. It might get them in the door marginally more quickly. Malcolm never asked how much they donated.

It is precisely the sort of thing that Senator Parer now mentions, but it has been going on on his side of politics longer than I have been alive. But we do not expect anything better from the Opposition. We do not expect in this debate anything better because we can see the record of those opposite. We can see their history. We can see how they have performed on human rights issues and on disclosure issues.

We know, for instance, that when Senator Parer was involved with Utah Mines he was very keen to ensure its contribution to the conservative side of politics at a time when it was ripping off the Australian taxpayer by shifting profits offshore by the bucketload. He was very keen to ensure that that was not disclosed to the public. He was also very keen to ensure that no money came to the Labor side of politics, and he was overridden in that respect. We can see why those opposite do not want to see these sorts of things disclosed. We can also see their history on human rights. It was only a few years ago when people such as the National Party leader in this place, Senator Boswell, said:
Senator Chipp said that it would take the National Party to approve of the bill of rights. The National Party would not approve of it in one million years.

That is the attitude of the National Party to human rights. But it is not just the National Party. Senator Durack, who as a former Attorney-General might be thought to have some sort of understanding, sensitivity and respect for human rights, said:
We will not join in an international covenant to bring human rights to everybody.

Opposition senators would not join in such a covenant to introduce human rights for anybody. That is their position on human rights. That statement was topped off by Senator Harradine, who is not here. I must quote for the record Senator Harradine's contribution:
The proposed human rights Bill will not create one additional job.

I do not know how that fitted into the debate but it is on the record. What are Opposition senators doing about human rights? They raise a point that I made about the role of the media. In making that point all they are asserting is that they do not trust the media in the press gallery or throughout the country to report the news and current affairs in a fair and honest way. If that is not an attack on the freedom of the press, I do not know what is.

They come in here as born again democrats-not Australian Democrats-but their record on human rights issues stands very clearly and starkly for the Australian public to see. They vehemently opposed our Government's attempts to entrench the international covenant on human rights in law through a Bill of rights. They filibustered in this Senate, they gasbagged and they stopped it. Of course, who from the start opposed the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission? Who wants to abolish it now? It is they who are now calling on the Commission to act as an umpire. Those on the other side reek of hypocrisy. They have shown time and time again that when it suits the Opposition they howl about human rights but when it comes to the crunch they do absolutely nothing.

This is a coalition that opposed, for example, constitutional reform-constitutional amendments to enshrine things as basic as the right to vote; the right to one vote one value; the right to freedom of religion; the right to trial by jury; the right to a fair compensation and acquisition of property.

The Constitutional Commission, which included a former State Premier and leader of the Liberal Party, Sir Rupert Hamer, campaigned for these rights to be enshrined in the Constitution. But what did those opposite do? They opposed it for short term political gain. They have a short memory when it comes to human rights and it is one that they are trying to invoke now. While Senator Parer was speaking I could not help thinking of John Stuart Mill, a great liberal. He made the following point, which is quite pertinent when one listens to debates in the Senate:
Conservatives are not necessarily stupid but most stupid people are conservatives.

In terms of the contribution we are getting on this issue from the conservative side of politics, John Stuart Mill was right. We are talking about a notice of motion which addresses freedom of speech. The most fundamental aim of the Government's proposal is not only to protect freedom of speech but also to enhance it. That is why we on this side of the Parliament have no trouble in supporting the expression that the Senate has been asked to treat as a matter of urgency today.

The most fundamental principle, the most fundamental premise in our democracy, which I can understand Opposition senators may not understand because they have not recognised it, is one person one vote, one vote one value. Our proposals enhance and protect this right. Anatole France, for instance, said in the late nineteenth century:
The law, in its majestic equality, permits the rich as well as the poor to sleep under bridges, to beg in the streets, and to steal bread.
Judge Skelly Wright, of the United States appellate court, commented in recent years:

A latter day Anatole France might well write after observing American election campaigns, `The law in its majestic equality, allows the poor as well as the rich to form political action committees, to purchase the most sophisticated polling, media and direct mail techniques, and to drown out each other's voices by overwhelming expenditures in political campaigns.
The same judge concluded that:

Financial inequities pose a pervasive and growing threat to the principle of one person, one vote, and undermine the political proposition to which this nation is dedicated-that we are all created equal.

We have recognised that as the most basic premise of our constitutional system. In addressing the issues that face this country at the moment, we have acted to improve the access to freedom of speech and to enhance the democratic process in the meantime. We cannot look at a concept without seeing how it is applied, and in its application there is one thing that can be said about advertising: it is an inherently undemocratic medium. It is not free speech but - -

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you use so much in 1983, then?

—The last people who should contribute to this debate are National Party senators from Queensland. If anyone in this Parliament knows anything about the costs and the interrelationship between the corporate dollar and political parties, it is members of the National Party in Queensland. They have made a profession of it. I should have thought that any contribution that Senator O'Chee's Party could make to this debate would be as expert evidence to assist us in drafting legislation to close off loopholes, because the National Party has known and tested them all.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about an inherently undemocratic medium. It is not free speech; it is expensively bought speech. With advertising costing as much as $13,000 a minute it is out of the reach of the great majority of people and organisations in this community. A person's vote, a person's participation in our democratic system, should not depend upon the size of his or her bank account.

It is not radicals from the Left of politics who have made these points. But there is a very basic point that needs to be addressed in this debate and it is about who sets the agenda. Senator Barry Goldwater, who is no conservative, made this point in the United States Senate:
It is not . . . the people . . . but moneyed interests who are setting the nation's political agenda and who are influencing the position of candidates on the important issues of the day.
Our proposal is aimed at ensuring not only a level playing field between organisations and people in our community but also that we rid our system of a great potential for corruption.

Some people say that disclosure is sufficient. However, we start from the point that what we need is a clean and democratic process. We need less reliance on funds. The cost of campaigning in this country has exploded over the last three election campaigns; it has increased three times over that time. Disclosure is not enough because we have to address the whole question of how costs are contained.
I am not the only one who says that disclosure is not enough. Recently Mr John Howard made it very clear in his column in, I think, the Sunday Telegraph when he said:

The United States has had elaborate disclosure laws for years. These did not stop a former Vice President, Spiro Agnew, receiving corrupt payments while occupying the second highest political position in his country. There is a time honoured maxim that, where there is no instinct for honour, it cannot be legislated.

The basic point is that disclosure is not enough. This Parliament has a responsibility to ensure that the costs of campaigning are reduced to such an extent that we can reduce that undue influence on the whole political process. I can understand Opposition senators being disinterested. However, we are concerned about a situation such as the one that occurred in Western Australia a number of years ago when the mining industry ran millions of dollars worth of campaigning in a very racist, unfair campaign against Aboriginal land rights. It was effective. It was a negative campaign, but that starkly showed the Australian community the inequity of advertising as a medium. The mining industry set the agenda. It excluded from the agenda legitimate consideration of Aboriginal land rights and, in doing so, used the power of its resources to stifle and censor free speech.

However, it is not only the mining industry that uses those tactics. When one looks at the last election campaign one sees more examples of it. Let us look at the last election campaign. Let us look at the assertion by the Opposition that we are stifling free speech. In the 1990 election campaign $1.75m was spent by third party groups. All three political groups spent only $1.75m. That covers the corporate sector, the loggers, St Vincent de Paul and the greenies. Of that money, only $63,000 was spent by community based organisations; the rest was spent by the corporate sector. Looking at the specific issue of logging of native forests and logging generally, the loggers spent $1.15m and the greenies, the Australian Conservation Foundation, spent something like $28,000. That is stark evidence of how advertising is an undemocratic medium.

There are two good reasons to tackle the issue in the way that we have done: firstly, to reduce the costs of advertising and, secondly, to provide a more democratic structure through which organisations in this country can work. Let me quote, for instance, what the National President of the Society of St Vincent de Paul said in a letter he wrote to me recently:
1. The Society has no position, for or against, the Cabinet decision to ban political advertising.

2. We are a non-political organisation and we do not run advertising supporting or opposing any political party. Therefore, any ads we do run-for appeals and the like-will not be affected by Cabinet decision.
Phillip Toyne said:
On political balance, we see the ban as levelling up the playing field.

That is precisely what we are on about. At the moment we have a situation which, firstly, leads to undue influence and potential corruption and, secondly, is inherently undemocratic. The best way is to tackle it head on; one cannot tackle it with one arm of the response. Even if we were to accept the proposition of the other side that what we are doing here is breaching article 19 (2) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the Opposition ignores article 19 (3). Article 19 (3) expresses very clearly and starkly an exemption for the protection of public order.

If there is a more serious threat to our society posed by the increasing cost of political campaigns and the consequent reliance of political parties on corporate dollars, I do not know what it is. It is not just me who holds this view.
