Commissioner Roden in the Independent Commission Against Corruption report on north coast development in New South Wales also recognised this threat to public order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not the National Party?
—Of course it is the National Party again. That is why I hoped it would be quiet on this. Commissioner Roden stated in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: With the mounting cost of campaign advertising, parties must be increasingly vulnerable to attempts by substantial donors to exert influence.

That goes very much to the heart of our parliamentary and democratic system. If it is such a breach of the International Covenant, why is it that only four countries in the world allow paid political advertising? The Opposition does not focus on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you tell us which countries they are?

—The countries are: Germany, America, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Canada does not allow advertising in the election campaign period. We are talking about political advertising; we are not talking about free speech. People will still be able to be reported. Journalists and others will be able to get on radio and television and portray their views without the imperative of having a full wallop before they get on radio and television. Anything that needs to be said can still be set in print, as well as in debate on current affairs programs on radio and television. No idea or proposition will be muzzled. It is just that one will not have to have a full bank account to get one's voice heard.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about getting rid of political advertising; we are not jeopardising free speech. Let us look at the product that we are talking about. Phillip Adams said this recently about political advertising:

The most effective election ads don't pretend to make a positive contribution to the debate. Nor are they used to put forward policies. At the best they'll attempt to reduce a complex slogan to an idiot-simple slogan, or try to seduce the voter with some surging excuse for an anthem. But their real job is to hit and run.
He goes on to say that political advertisements are:
. . . about as worth defending as graffiti slogans sprayed on the walls of public buildings, or the obscenities scrawled in loos.
But it is not just Phillip Adams. The Opposition members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters had this to say about the value of political advertising:
We reject as absurd the assertion that political advertising is a social good.
That is from the mouths of Opposition members. They go on to say:
We have seen no convincing evidence of any co-relation between election results and either the quality or quantity of political advertising on electronic media.
In another comment, they say:

It seems likely that it is the news and current affairs programs, and not the party advertisements, that provide the information which makes television a significant influence on individual political choices.

We are talking about an inherently unfair medium-a medium that is used depending on the size of one's bank account; a medium that sets the agenda in the interests of not the majority of the Australian people but in the vested interest minority; and a medium that, to date, has been kept secret in the way that it has operated.

We have been asked to look at other aspects of this issue. For the months I have looked at this issue, I have looked very closely at alternatives. I have looked at the alternative of caps, of free time and of more limited bans. But to me, and I am sure to honourable senators if they fairly approach this issue, the fairest way to go is the one that we have proposed. If one is looking at caps, free time periods or whatever, one still has to grapple with the issue of what happens with third party organisations and with front organisations.

The Liberal Party would not be concerned about that because at the last New South Wales election it spent $20 or $30 to set up a company in New South Wales, set up a front organisation called Community Polling, and ran a parallel campaign to the State campaign through that organisation. The organisation raised money, it conducted polling-it did all sorts of things. It was so easy to set up that front organisation. Such issues as caps and free time leave the way open for massive loopholes-loopholes that the Opposition has exploited and which have been exploited to the state of the art in the United States where political action committees basically run the campaigns. Community Polling was run out of Mr Metherell's office in New South Wales because Mr Greiner had no confidence in the then Liberal Party secretariat.

In conclusion, we are talking about the immense problem of the interrelationship between the corporate dollar and campaigning. The Government has responded to it in the fairest and most democratic way. In our response, we have recognised that the medium of advertising is inherently undemocratic. It is a late twentieth century version of the property franchise-something that the Opposition would not know about. It is nothing more or less than a property franchise before one participates in our political process. We are sure that the Government's proposal stands the scrutiny of international covenants. We have no trouble supporting this afternoon's matter of public importance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition asks us to debate today as a matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The need to ensure that all Australians continue to enjoy the right to freedom of expression that they currently enjoy.

It is a pleasure to rise to speak in a debate brought on by the Opposition about the rights and freedoms of Australians. I do hope that this is the beginning of a changed trend from that side of politics. I remind the Opposition that the need for a Bill of Rights for all Australians to protect all our freedoms, including our freedom of expression, has been a matter of high priority policy and parliamentary action for the Australian Democrats ever since we have been in this place.

Indeed, Senator Haines, the former leader of the Party, introduced a private member's Bill in this place in 1982. Subsequent to that, the Australian Democrats supported the thrust of, and attempted to strengthen, the Bill of Rights which was introduced by the Hawke Government later in the mid-1980s. I could go through in some detail the private member's Bill of former Senator Haines and our attempts to improve the legislation brought forward finally by the Hawke Government. But in this debate it is important to note not only the lack of support from the Opposition, then in government, for former Senator Haines's legislation but also the mass hysteria generated from the Opposition side of politics towards the Hawke Government's Bill when it was finally introduced. The Government finally went to water and pulled that Bill off, even though it always had the numbers in this place, and of course in the House of Representatives, to enact such a Bill.

I nail right here and now the myth that the reason we do not have a Bill of Rights in this place was obstruction in the Senate; it was not. The numbers were always here. We have throughout our existence as a political party had a strong commitment to the rights and freedoms of all Australians and to legislation to underpin those rights and freedoms. It is worth reiterating that when such legislation was before us a hysterical public campaign was generated and supported by the Opposition in this place. The Bill was called treasonable and it was described as a communist or socialist plot. It was suggested that existing rights would be extinguished by the Government's legislation and totally inaccurate information was given out about the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on which the Bill was based, on which the Democrats' own Bill was based, and on which I presume the motion before us today is also based.

We do need to make it clear that certainly the Democrats support that covenant in all its aspects. I remind the Senate that article 19 (2) of the international covenant provides for the right to freedom of expression, which is the subject of our debate today. This right is expressed in subsection (3), however, as being subject to certain restrictions provided by law and is necessary, as Senator Bolkus has already pointed out, for the protection of public order. No freedom of expression, as it exists under that covenant, is totally without some restrictions, which are there to provide for the protection of public order.

Many of those restrictions do spring to mind. For example, the defamation laws and other restrictions which currently exist on advertising specifically go to the Opposition's motion today. Indeed, I stand here as a person who has successfully restricted advertising in this country. I am proud to say that, by way of a private member's Bill, I have stopped the advertising in the print medium of tobacco products and other enormously harmful products. It is advertising which, through the promotion of those products, has created damage and death in our community. That legislation followed only a decade after restrictions in electronic advertising of that substance.

We do not advertise other commodities such as pharmaceutical products in the general public arena for obvious reasons. Since they are not products to be promoted to the general public, the freedom of expression of the producers of those products is limited in the public interest, for the public good or to maintain public order. These sorts of restrictions are common.

I make those points because it is important to get the debate about the Government's package of reforms to the electoral process in context. I stand in agreement with the Opposition on one aspect of its position, which is that the blanket ban on everybody all the time on paid political advertising is too draconian, even in the context that I have set down.

However, it is important also to make it clear that the Democrats welcome the Government's package. As I say, it is a package designed to improve the conduct of elections in this country and, indeed, the general political debate. We were delighted with that aspect of the Government's proposal which calls for complete disclosure of all political funding of political parties and other players in the political arena. That has also been a matter of policy for the Australian Democrats ever since our inception. We have pushed for it and promoted it in this place for 14 years.

We were pleased that the Hawke Government went so far as to have disclosure for election campaigns. It recognises, as we made clear at the time, that partial disclosure left massive loopholes which no doubt were used to circumvent that disclosure, since the disclosure of other funding for reasons other than campaigning was not required. All the evidence is there to prove that that was the case. So we totally support that aspect of the Government's package, although we do make it clear that the form of the disclosure is important. We believe that it must be virtually instantaneous disclosure so that there cannot be any shonky deals about funds being passed across and time passing between the passage of funding and an election or the fulfilling of some commitment that might be attached to it. It must be transparent and the public must know of funding that is passing into the political system on an ongoing basis. That part of the legislation is very welcome and will be supported by the Australian Democrats.

We also welcome what appears to be at least movement on the side of the Opposition, through its leader, Dr Hewson, and in defiance, it seems, of the party organisation on the Opposition side of politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.
—That is not right.
—I have Ashley Goldsworthy's press release here and it certainly does not sound to me like a resounding endorsement of Dr Hewson's position.
—It is subject to the legislation.
—It is always subject to the legislation; there is no doubt about that. As I say, it is good to see movement on the question of disclosure in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the detail of a blanket ban on everyone all the time, as put forward by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) and again pending legislation, did seem to us to be too draconian. But from it we take the understanding that the Government is interested in regulating the advertising that takes place in the political arena. We agree with it on that principle. While we will not support a blanket ban, we are very interested in further regulation of political advertising.

The case for truth in advertising is a matter of public record and action in this place. We have been active in this place in all the matters that I am raising, usually without any support from either side or with only partial support. The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 amounts to a licence to lie, and it is used. It is a licence that is exercised on a regular basis such that it is futile even to imagine bringing any kind of action in the current political context against an absolute untruth that is perpetrated about one's views or one's Party's views.

As recently as 31 May last year Senator Macklin once again moved in this place to bring the Electoral Act into line with the sorts of provisions that are in the Trade Practices Act 1974 and which apply over all other forms of advertising. The Opposition might want to argue that there are restrictions on freedom of speech. Nevertheless, no advertising is free and clear of restrictions except political advertising.

The Democrats want to see as part of the package, when it eventually gets through this place in whatever form, those amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act which were most recently put before the Senate in May last year by Senator Macklin. All we are asking is that basic matters put forward as matters of fact as part of a political advertisement are indeed provable as fact. That is not a lot to ask. We know that a government cannot legislate against politicians making promises and that politicians cannot be locked up if their promises do not come true. Some people might say more is the pity, but we are not attempting to do that. All we are attempting to do is introduce into the Electoral Act the most basic aspects of truth on matters of absolute fact. To us, that is the sort of regulation that is absolutely vital in the political process.

We should also have some system where fairness can be addressed, particularly in the broadcasting area. A fairness-in-broadcasting code, administered through what would have to be a better resourced Australian Broadcasting Tribunal than we now have, would go a long way towards improving election campaigns and the level of information that is given to voters.

In terms of advertisements that do appear, other steps need to be taken. There are other ways to meet the concern, again which we share with the Government, of the costs of election campaigning. In our view, there ought to be some time limits on advertisements. We are concerned that, in particular, television advertisements have become not a matter of information for the electors in the process of election campaigns. A lot of the advertisements have not even involved speech making; they have been more about image making. We have had depictions of octopuses and bulls in china shops, et cetera. There is not a lot to do with speech or information; it is all about the image building or, more particularly, image breaking of one's political opponents. I understand that the former Prime Minister of Great Britain refused to take minimum time-limited free time on the British Broadcasting Corporation because of the requirement that the candidate or the party representative simply stand before the camera and speak to the audience for a minimum period.

It is our view that that is the sort of process that would create much more effective, much more efficient, fairer and, therefore, better election campaigning in this country. It is in that area of regulation of political advertising that we will want, firstly, to look at what the Government brings forward and, secondly, to bring forward our own proposition and our own amendments.

As someone else has already said in this debate, this whole question has been a matter of public debate for a considerable time. I welcome the opportunity to urge the Opposition in the future to pay much more attention to the rights and freedoms of Australian people and I look forward to the time when it will begin to support Democrat initiatives in this area. I also welcome the Government's package for the opportunity it provides for this country finally to lift the veil on the things that we have seen in the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, the Independent Commission Against Corruption inquiry and the brown paper bags in Queensland. I look forward to all of us working together here in this Senate coming forward with a package which will provide fair, truthful, effective and efficient election campaigns that are democratic and do provide, add to and enhance the democratic process in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the need to ensure that Australians retain the right to freedom of expression that they currently enjoy. Senator Bolkus says that freedom of expression can simply be reduced to the notion of free speech. He used that to oversimplify the argument and to say that he is not trying to ban free speech; he is trying to ban bought speech. I say to that that if free speech, that is, the right to freedom of expression, means nothing more than speech for which we have not paid to have it distributed, for several decades the United Nations, academics, politicians interested in promoting civil and political rights, including those in the Party of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus), the Australian Democrats and also people on my side, have been wasting their time. They have been wasting lots of time. They have wasted countless hours of negotiating on this issue, writing about it, talking about it and resolving what the issues really are. That has been a complete waste of time because we could have gone off to Senator Bolkus and said, `What does free speech mean?'. He would have said, `It is anything that is not bought'. We all know that that is not what free speech means. The Minister has oversimplified this argument to a degree that I would think must be an embarrassment to his Party which, until this stage, has a very honourable record in terms of promoting civil and political rights.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister's simplification did not display such a monumental misunderstanding by a Government Minister of what is meant by the right to freedom of speech, it would be laughable. In fact, I have no doubt that primary school children and secondary school children, as part of their social studies debates, are now being asked, `What does free speech mean? Should we be able to ban political advertising? What do you mean by free speech?'. I have no doubt that primary school children are laughing at the Minister's concept of free speech being anything which is not bought. It is a laughable notion.

Let us look at our legal rights for example. We need an enormous number of dollars to exercise them. People may have a right of action in a court but they need an enormous amount of money to access that right. Is the Minister now going to say that we should ban the use of courts and lawyers because only the wealthy can afford them and because the wealthy will get a fairer slice of legal rights? Of course he will not say that. We are concerned about the cost of justice. One of the Senate committees has an inquiry with a reference into the cost of justice. But no-one is having the temerity or the stupidity to come into this place and to say that, because it is expensive to access legal rights, we will ban that access and everyone will have the same access, that is, none.

That is what Senator Bolkus is saying about our rights to gather some money together and put our views across. He is saying that because to use the electronic media is expensive-and he does not refer how efficient it is - -
Senator Macdonald interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald, you may not interject while you are not sitting in your own seat.

—The Minister says that because advertising is expensive and, therefore, some people cannot afford it, political advertising will be banned for everybody. It is a laughable notion. It is a disgraceful notion for a Minister of the Crown to be putting forward. Under article 19, freedom of expression, or the guts of it anyway, has been defined as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression;-
and it goes on to enunciate for us-

this right shall include the freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of his choice.

I am not complaining that this ban will simply take away my right to place an advertisement; I am complaining because it takes away the right of all people sitting in the gallery, all people in the country, to read that advertisement, to listen to it, to see what I have to say and to decide whether they want to vote for me on that basis. It is not just a question of the right to place an advertisement; it is the right to hear the views that people want to express. That right is also being taken away.

Scholars have spent an enormous amount of time on the question of why we need to protect the right to freedom of expression. What is so special about it? Why are we getting excited about it? There are four simple reasons that have been settled on; not by me but by people, such as Professor Emerson who, in an article in the California Law Review in 1980, listed four reasons why we want to protect freedom of expression.

First, individuals get some self-fulfilment from being able to express themselves, being able to say what they think. Secondly, freedom of expression will advance knowledge and discovery of truth. The argument is that if I say that the sky is black today, Senator Macdonald goes outside and says that it is not, it is grey, and someone else goes outside and says that it is blue, a couple of us will be lying and/or mistaken; but someone will be telling the truth. Those who are listening will be able to say, `That person is the one telling the truth; I agree with that person'.

So it is with political advertising. People will put forward a particular view. Some of it will be, for want of a better expression, embroidered, for example, the Democrat advertisement which says, `We will keep the b's honest.' If ever there was a mistruth in advertising, it is that one. Nonetheless, some of us will judge some advertisements to be untruthful. We will judge that some are a waste of money and say, `What idiot put that ad in? Who would do an ad like that?'. However, that advertisement tells me something about that person. It tells me that that person's priorities are different from mine and that, therefore, I probably do not want to vote for that individual. We are not just talking about my right to place an advertisement-a sensible one or a stupid one-but about the right of all Australians in here, around the country, to make an assessment on the basis of those advertisements.

Thirdly, freedom of expression ensures a proper balance between stability and change. A constant push for change brings about change. If people cannot really express themselves, change is stifled and limited. Fourthly, what has been agreed on as the most essential element of the need to protect freedom of expression is that it is essential to effective decision making by society. That is what this is all about. That is the guts of it.

The Minister could turn his mind to some American cases on the first amendment, loosely referred to as that which guarantees freedom of speech in the United States. In the judgment in the Monitor Patriot Co. v. Roy case, the Minister would see these words:
It can hardly be debated that the constitutional guarantee-
that is, freedom of speech-
has its fullest and most urgent application precisely to the conduct of campaigns for political office.

It is no good this Minister coming in here and saying, `I am not banning freedom of speech, I am just banning political advertising'. That is the very advertising, the very passing on of speech and ideas that the freedom is expression is designed to protect. That is the very guts of it. That is what the Minister wants to get at.

If the Minister does not like the case of Monitor Patriot Co. v. Roy, because he does not think it is relevant, he can turn to Mills v. Alabama. America has a very rich history of litigating this matter of freedom of expression, much richer than ours. The Minister will see that the judgment in Mills v. Alabama states:
There is practically universal agreement that a major purpose of the Amendment was to protect the free discussion of governmental affairs . . . including discussions of candidates.

I ask: when else would we want to do that but at election time? What do we mean by freedom of expression? It is all very well for people on the other side and the Democrats to wear the badge `freedom of expression' and march around the country saying, `Vote for us, we are for it'. But they have not given much thought-and if they have, it has not been displayed in this debate-about what we really mean by that. It is just a convenient badge to wear around in order to try to suck up a few votes. But they should give a bit more attention to what they actually mean by it. One of the noted academics in this area, Mr Alexander Bickel, says:

The social interest that the First Amendment vindicates is the successful operation of the political process, so that the country may be better able to adopt the course of action that conforms to the wishes of the greatest number.

In other words, it is quite clear that the United States will not tolerate an intervention in freedom of speech that limits the exchange of views in relation to political matters. This will not be tolerated because it is the very reason that freedom of expression is meant to be protected. It is there to ensure the unfettered interchange of ideas for bringing about social change. Those words can be found in the case of Roth v. US. The case of New York Times v. Sullivan shows how freedom of expression allegedly demonstrates a `profound national commitment to the principle that debate on public issues should be wide open'. There is no doubt about that.

Why do I say that this blanket ban will necessarily cut down freedom of expression? This is shown in an even newer case, Buckley and Valeo, in which the Government tried to do what Senator Bolkus is trying to do. It missed out. It breached freedom of expression in doing so. That case is very useful to us to look at to see how we can go about achieving what the Minister wants to achieve without limiting freedom of expression.

That case spoke about a restriction on the amount of money a person or group can spend. The Minister says that he does not want a restriction but he admits that he wants to cut the cost. One cannot cut the cost without putting some sort of restriction, de jure or de facto. He does not want to allow us to spend money on the more expensive things. It was argued in the Buckley and Valeo case that this necessarily reduces the quantity of expression by restricting the number of issues discussed, the depth of their exploration, and the size of the audience reached. They went even further and pointed out that it would be disastrous to exclude all citizens and groups except candidates, political parties and the institutional press from significant use of the effective modes of communication. We find in Buckley and Valeo that these effective modes of communication should be kept open at least to candidates and political parties. But the Minister wants to ban everybody from using them-not just at election time but at all times. If we go to the case law in the United States, we find that the Americans can see how important it is that candidates and political parties have unfettered access-that means, unedited access-to the media in order to put their ideas across.

I understand that we have some people in the gallery today who wear the honorific title of being the Rats of Tobruk. I do not imagine that those people fought for anything other than these rights-that is, the right to express one's view freely, unfettered and unedited.

Again, we find in Buckley and Valeo that the electorates' increasing dependence on television has made radio, television and other media the most expensive modes of communication but the most indispensable instruments of effective political free speech. This Minister wants to ban my access, these people's access and anyone's access to putting their view across in what Buckley and Valeo say are the most indispensable instruments of effective political speech. That is what we are on about. That is what this Government is trying to do.

The Minister quotes the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. He says that some people on my side said that they did not think election advertising was very effective. But he misleads this chamber. He did not tell us that they went on to say that if people want to waste their money with ineffective advertising, they should have the right to do so. He does not say that not one Government member of that Committee supported the complete ban that his Government has now turned around and decided that it wants.

There was no dissenting report saying, `Hold on, I think a complete ban would be a good idea'. I notice that some people are trying to squirm out of that now by saying, `Oh well, I thought it was a good idea but, you know, I went along with the majority'. If people come into this place and are so weak as to not put their view, if they are so cheap in delivering a service to the people that they will not tell the Parliament what they really think, and if they just go along with majority, that is on their shoulders.

The exchange of ideas will be limited because I will not be able to put advertisements on television and radio which most people spend most time looking at and listening to. My freedom of speech will be further limited because the cost of reaching a thousand people is the cheapest by radio and cheap again by television. It is far cheaper than doing it in the newspaper. So I will be restricted.

I am told that I can go through the media. But journalists have to service critics and to do that they have to have intellect, special expertise, reflection and judiciousness. Journalism is not intellectually rigorous. It does not attract the best minds. Journalists are generalists. They are required to write for a 12-year-old and the very nature of their profession requires them to be sceptical-that is, to see the flaws and then list them. Political advertisements will tell us what the parties think. What current affairs programs will tell us is what is dramatic, what is scandalous and what is tantalising. For example, at the next election if I throw an egg at the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that will get on television. But if John Hewson wants to elucidate the benefits of a goods and services tax, I will get on television throwing an egg and the electorate will be poorly informed because he will not be able to put his view as a result of some drama. That is what this Government is trying to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, the Labor Government can strongly support the matter of public importance that has been proposed. Indeed, as Senator Vanstone has pointed out, the Labor Government and other Labor governments in this country have for the last century been strongly committed to and continue to support freedom of expression in this nation. Our record is very clear. Such issues as the Bill of Rights and one vote one value have been very strongly supported by the Australia Labor Party. We will continue to support matters such as that. I would like to offer the following quote:

SPEECH.PARA: We would not, I don't not think, support a full ban, however, I do believe that the cost now of running elections . . . is escalating at a rate which I don't think is in the best interests of any of the citizens.
I think it is something we ought to be looking at in a non-partisan sort of way.
I do think, otherwise it will get out of hand. We don't want the situation like we've got in the US where you have got to be a multi-millionaire to stand for President.

That was said on 8 April 1990 by none other than John Elliott, the out-going President of the Liberal Party of Australia. Before I develop the arguments in support of the proposition put forward by our Government, I would like to respond to some of the positions put forward by those opposite, particularly by Senator Parer. The honourable senator said that he never expected to be standing in the Senate pleading for freedom of speech. I would suggest that they are hollow words when matched against the attitude of those opposite on such issues as a Bill of Rights, one vote one value and the International Covenant on Human Rights. They are hollow words indeed.

Senator Parer also mentioned that the Government's proposition has been condemned by all of the media. Well, surprise, surprise! He did not mention, of course, that the media does have something of a vested interest in that it receives some millions of dollars during election campaigns and that perhaps-just perhaps-it is motivated by the desire to gain extra revenue rather than any proposition to uphold the rights of free speech.

Senator Parer attacked the role of trade unions. He quite legitimately mentioned that trade unions, through affiliations, do give money to the Australian Labor Party. He suggested that that should be restricted in a number of ways.

That is not a balanced approach to the giving of moneys to political parties. Senator Parer referred to trade unions allegedly failing to consult with their members, some of whom do support the conservative parties. I draw the comparison with companies that donate money to political parties. Do companies consult with their shareholders about the giving of money to political parties? Of course they do not. As usual, those opposite do not draw an equitable comparison in a debate.

There has been a lot said about a one-party state and that the proposal of the Government will lead to the establishment of a one-party state. The countries where advertising in the electronic media is banned, such as the United Kingdom, Italy and Scandinavia-in fact, almost all Western democracies, except for the four named by Senator Bolkus earlier-are not one-party states. It is absurd and ludicrous to maintain that the prohibition of advertising in the electronic media will lead to one-party states. Indeed, on the basis of that logic we could only assume that prior to the advent of radio in the 1930s and 1940s, and the advent of television in the 1960s, every democracy was a one-party state because there was no radio or television. In fact, there were thriving democracies without the need for advertising on radio and television.

Senator Vanstone made a very interesting comment about laying the issue before a class of school children. I will take up that challenge. If we laid the issue before children fairly, and talked about free speech and the need for them to have freedom of expression, and we then said to those children, `Only one or two of you could afford to pay $40 or $50 to get up and advertise yourselves through radio or television' I dare say most of them would not consider that proposition terribly equitable or fair.

I do not intend to spend a great deal of time on Senator Vanstone's contribution because, frankly, it is not worth it except to say that the reference she made to people in the gallery-the rats of Tobruk-I believe is an unnecessary and, as was referred to in the interjection, totally cheap shot. If she wants to substantiate her arguments with those sorts of comparisons that is up to her, but it just shows how desperate she has got to be in this debate.

In terms of the background to the reforms that are being proposed by the Government, our motivation is to ensure a continued, clean, political environment. Secondly, we are going to ensure that there is equity in the political process and that we have a level playing field. The Government is doing this by proposing the full disclosure of all income and expenditure for political parties and partial disclosure for third parties. Was it not a knock-down, drag-out fight from those opposite to get that commitment out of Dr Hewson? We are still not sure whether we have a commitment. It is always prefaced with, `We need to see the legislation' and I suspect that will be its way out of it.

Another area is the containing of the costs of campaigning by prohibiting radio and television political advertising. Senator Bolkus mentioned just a few areas when giving a breakdown of third party expenditure on broadcast advertising. The forestry industry spent over $1m. Looking down the list of those third parties that spent $1,774,000 in the last Federal election, I suspect there are not too many people in the gallery, for example, that Senator Vanstone referred to, who could or did spend anywhere near that amount of money.

Saab and Yorke Motors spent $27,000; the Local Government Association, $90,000; the pharmacists, $175,000; the union movement, which is so often berated by those opposite, $56,000; the Brotherhood of Saint Laurence, $26,000; miscellaneous-and I suspect this includes at least some ordinary, common citizens who managed to buy time on the airwaves-some $10,006.

In terms of the democratic issues that motivate the proposal from the Government, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, while not specifically agreeing to what is proposed did agree that reform was necessary. The proposal that is being presented is the most democratic outcome from the Committee's recommendations. The most fundamental premise in our society-one vote one value, one person one vote-has consistently been opposed by those opposite. Mr Justice Skelly Wright, who has already been quoted in this debate, of the Appellate Court in the United States of America (USA) said:

Financial inequities pose a pervasive and growing threat to the principle of `one person one vote' and undermine the political proposition to which this nation is dedicated-that all are created equal.

Advertising is an inherently undemocratic medium. It is not free speech. It is very expensive. It can cost up to $13,000 a minute. Again, I do not think there are too many people in the gallery-there are not too many people there-who would be willing to spend up to $13,000 a minute. A person's voice should not depend upon the size of a bank account.

Advertising leads to money, not people, setting the agendas. It is interesting, despite all that we have heard from those opposite, that there are two States in this country where people have actually been convicted in the process of eliciting bribes and being involved in the political process. They involve the National Party of Australia in Queensland, and the various links between the Liberal Party of Australia in Tasmania and Edmund Rouse-who has ended up in gaol-which may well be established through the current Royal Commission in Tasmania.

Those opposite would do well to remember that there is more than one royal commission going on in this country at the present time. I do not criticise Opposition members for drawing to our attention the role of the Royal Commission in Western Australia. I just criticise their lack of balance and the fact that they seem to forget that what has been going on in Tasmania for some time has yet to be exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy for you to have a good dig around.
—We are going to have a very good dig around in Tasmania, I can assure Senator Vanstone of that. Senator Barry Goldwater of the US Senate said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's not . . . the people . . . but moneyed interests who are setting the nation's political agenda and are influencing the position of candidates on the important issues of the day.

It is not an issue of buying influence before an election, but the influence that is bought with future governments after they have been elected. I would like to quote from Commissioner Roden who reported on the North Coast Development in 1990. He said:
Whether the parties intend to allow the donations to influence them or not, they are unlikely to react to them in a manner that will chase the benefactors away.
He went on to say:

So long as substantial donations can be made to political parties or candidates without disclosure, they can be used to purchase influence. The law that allows secret political donations, creates conditions conducive to corrupt conduct . . . The alternative to compulsory public disclosure, I believe, is an unacceptable risk that through financial necessity, influence with Government (of any political colour) will be a purchasable commodity.

One of the main motivations that leads political parties to seek such enormous donations on both sides of politics in this nation is the cost of political advertising. Advertising is no substitute for the real aim of political process, and that is addressing the issues. Those opposite seem to believe-I do not accept it-that this is some sort of secret plot to ensure that we are re-elected at the next Federal election. It is certainly not true because, if that were the case, then other nations of Europe, where political advertising is banned in the electronic media, presumably would have remained one-party states. I suspect, in fact I am sure, that in the next Federal election, should we be defeated-I do not believe we will be-it will have absolutely nothing to do with whether or not, and how much, money is spent on political advertising.

If, at the end of the day people believe that we have failed to run the economy properly, and that we have failed to address the issues, then they will defeat us. I am confident that they will not come to that conclusion but, at the end of the day, I believe that the cost of political advertising, and the fact that there will be, I hope, no advertising in the electronic media, will make little or no difference to the outcome of that election. It certainly has not occurred in Europe. There have been numerous changes of government, despite the fact that advertising in the electronic media is prohibited.
The Opposition members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters had this to say about political advertising:
We reject as absurd the assertion that political advertising is a social good.
The Committee went on to say:

It seems likely that it is the news and current affairs programs, and not the party advertisements, that provide the information which makes television a significant influence on individual political choices. We have seen no convincing evidence of any correlation between election results and either the quality or the quantity of political advertising on the electronic media.

Public funding, even though linked to the consumer price index, cannot keep up with the increased costs of radio and television advertising. Since the introduction of public funding, radio rates have increased to five times the rate of public funding. Television advertising rates have increased to three times the rate of public funding. Advertising has placed participation in the political process out of the hands of the ordinary people.

As I mentioned earlier, if we look through the list of third party expenditure in the last election, we see very few individuals-in fact I could not find any at all-who through their organisations spent any significant sums of money on advertising in the electronic media. The net effect of all this is that the cost of advertising leads practically to censorship; that is the outcome of it. The right to speak is based on the size of one's bank account.

In terms of the issue of undue influence, it is interesting that the former Liberal Party director, Tony Eggleton, told Michelle Grattan that when Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister he was told when the Liberal Party donors wanted to see him, `It might get them in the door marginally more quickly'. By the following two measures, we distance the political process from undue influence. We take $19m worth of purchasing out of the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Freedom of speech is more than just the right to have a say. Freedom of speech is the right to hear what other people have to say. This is the hallmark of democracy and this is why I believe so firmly that we must stand up against the attempts of this Labor Government to ban paid political advertising. Yes, it is paid. The banning of paid political advertising bans not only our right to have a say, but also our right to hear what other people have to say. I believe that resistance to what the Australian Labor Party has to say about banning political advertising is critical, not because I am a member of parliament-not because I am a parliamentarian-but because before and after being a member of this Parliament I was and always will be a concerned Australian citizen. The arguments that have been advanced by Senator Bolkus boil down to three essential points, but he fails to understand the crux of the debate, which is the right to hear what other people have to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Two thousand years ago, eminent Greek philosophers understood this principle of democracy, but Senator Bolkus does not because he is only a third of the way there. Senator Bolkus does not understand the fact that there can be all sorts of extraneous circumstances that limit a person's right to hear what prospective political candidates have to say. Senator Bolkus's best argument-perhaps his only argument-is that what the Government wishes to do is to make the system fairer by equalising the rights of the people who put themselves before the public, and there is a lot of superficial value in this argument. It is superficially very attractive to say that we are going to put everybody on the same basis, but in Buckley v. Valeo, the case to which Senator Vanstone has already alluded, the judgment of the court was very interesting. It said:

Moreover, the equalisation of permissible campaign expenditures might serve not to equalise the opportunities of all candidates, but to handicap a candidate who lacks substantial name recognition or exposure of his views before the start of the campaign.

Let us bring it back to ordinary terms. The judgment was saying that, suppose Richard Carlton or Max Walker or Derryn Hinch chose to stand for Parliament, they would not be on the same footing as everybody else just because they were allowed to spend the same amount of money. Of course they would not. They would have a substantial advantage because they are well known, people who are on the air all the time, people whose faces are before the public.

There is more to equalising opportunity than just equalising the amount of money that people have to spend. There is more to equalising opportunity than limiting the rights of people to have their say when they ought to have their say. We must remember that, to equalise opportunity, we must also equalise the opportunity to hear. This is the flaw of the Labor Party's campaign, this is the flaw of Senator Bolkus's arguments, and this is why the legislation which was brought before this Parliament by this pernicious Labor Government must be knocked back, must be defeated-because we believe wholeheartedly in freedom of speech and freedom to hear.

The next argument that was advanced by Senator Bolkus and, to his credit, by Senator Sherry, was that there is a limitation on how much an individual has to spend. Certainly there is a limitation on how much an individual has to spend, but there is no limitation on how many individuals may club together, pool their resources, to have a collective say.

Senator Sherry, a member of the Labor Party, should know all about collective voice, should know about people forming political parties because they have similar views. Just because one party is on one side and another party is on the other, why should they have to have the same amount of money to spend? The party that is on one side may well have fewer members than the party that is on the other. It may well have fewer supporters.

We cannot just say that we are going to make everybody equal by giving everybody the same amount of money. That is like saying we are going to make everybody equal by giving them the same amount of pay. In the past couple of years we have seen how this concept was destroyed in the socialist countries of eastern Europe. Senator Sherry and Senator Bolkus both claimed that there were only four countries in the Western world that allowed freedom of electronic advertising. That may be the case. Senator Sherry then tried to say that we were saying that banning political advertising creates a one-party state.

Nobody on this side of the chamber would be naive enough to advance that argument. Senator Sherry might be naive enough to think that we were advancing the argument, but that is not the case at all. All we say is that banning political advertising increases the likelihood of a country becoming a one-party political state. Although only four Western democracies give the freedom to advertise political beliefs, none of the communist totalitarian regimes we see around the world give people that right at all. We are saying: let us not drag the best down to the level of the worst, but let us increase democracy; let us increase freedom and increase the right of individuals to say what they think and to listen to what they like because we have already pioneered the processes of democracy which we believe are so important.

Australia was one of the first nations in the world to give women the right to vote. If we follow the argument that Senator Bolkus and Senator Sherry have advanced, we should have said in 1930 or 1940, `There are not many other Western countries that give women a right to vote, so why do we not ban women from voting?'. It is the same sort of ludicrous argument that we hear time and time again from the other side of the chamber-the same sort of ludicrous argument we hear from the Minister of propaganda, Senator Bolkus. He makes great play of quoting from the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. If Senator Bolkus did not have a beard, I would be tempted to call him a bare-faced liar, because he has said that that Standing Committee report justifies everything he wants to do.

But the truth is-and truth is very important here-that not one member of that Committee supported the argument that Senator Bolkus is making; not one member of that Committee said that we should ban political advertising. Here is the rub, and it brings it back to my original point: freedom of speech is not just the freedom to have a say but the freedom to hear. The sorts of mistruths and the sorts of deceitful, untrue arguments we have heard from Senator Bolkus, not just today but day after day-because Senator Bolkus is one of those people who believes that the more one says something the more people are likely to swallow it-are allowed to flourish in a society where we ban political advertising. Only one side-in this case Senator Bolkus and his mates-has a chance to put forward its argument. This is why we on this side of the chamber object to that which they are setting out to do.

Senator Bolkus said, `You do not have to advertise; you can always use radio interviews and television interviews and all of those other things to put your point of view'. But, unfortunately, Senator Bolkus was not listening the other day to his Labor Party colleague Senator Walsh, who highlighted-I believe very clearly and succinctly-the danger in putting one's trust in the press. According to Senator Walsh, he was gravely and, in his words, `gruesomely' defamed and manipulated by an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program. Either Senator Bolkus was not listening to what Senator Walsh had to say, or Senator Bolkus does not care what Senator Walsh had to say. The important point is that we cannot trust the freedom of our political system to journalists who may have a vested interest. If we do not have the right to advertise-the right to say what we believe-then we increase the likelihood that the freedoms of this society will be hijacked, either by people in the media or by people in government whose sole interest in governing is not to benefit Australia but to benefit themselves.

Of course, we can go through some of the individual arguments that Senator Bolkus has raised and see the fallacies in the sorts of things he has been talking about. He tries to say that those of us on this side of the chamber are not interested in human rights because we did not support a proposed constitutional amendment to give trial by jury. But Senator Bolkus has not looked on the first floor in the public gallery of this building and seen the protection of our rights that we have in the Magna Carta. He does not understand that the right to vote does not need to be put into the Constitution because it has existed in this country since Federation. It is one of the principles-the axiomatic, undeniable principles-on which this country is built: a democracy of people who have a right to choose and in the process of having a right to choose have a right to speak and in the process of exercising their choice have the right to listen.

That is why Senator Bolkus fails to understand what is going on. That is why only Senator Bolkus and his mates will flourish in the sort of Australia that their political censorship would give us. I use the words `political censorship' very carefully because if we ban political advertising on radio and television we have to choose what is political and censor it accordingly.

Television and radio advertisements do not cost $13,000 per minute. In fact, I put out a lot of radio advertisements over Christmas and I will tell honourable senators what the radio advertisements said. They said, `Congratulations to all of the high school students who have just completed their last year at school. If you have a difficulty this is the telephone number of my office; I would be pleased to hear from you'. Somebody on the other side of the chamber could say that this is political because I am a member of parliament. Somebody on the other side could say, `We have to ban this. We don't want Senator O'Chee getting up and having his say because, after all, he is an elected member of parliament'. But, of course, what that side is trying to do is ban the access of people to their elected parliamentarians and ban the rights of their elected parliamentarians to report back to the people.

This is the flaw, the weakness, in the argument that we have heard from the other side. In fact, if Senator Bolkus had done his research properly-and the questioning to which Senator Parer has submitted him over the last week and a half would indicate that he clearly has not-he would know that the absurd figure of $13,000 per minute does not describe accurately the cost of political advertising. In many places in Queensland one can get a television advertisement for $50 per minute. If a person does not have $50, as Senator Vanstone has said quite clearly, that person can get 50 people together who can pay $1 each and they can all have their say. This is what we believe in: the right to speak and the right to listen.

Of course, Senator Bolkus reminded us that the amount of advertising has tripled in the last eight years. Why has the amount of advertising tripled in the last eight years? The Government has led the way by spending the taxpayers' dollar to achieve its ends-the Government that gave $1 1/4m to the Australian Conservation Foundation so it could further its political ends and then comes back and talks about equalisation of opportunity. This debate is much more complex than this Government would have us believe. I believe it is important for the enduring freedom of this nation that people have a right to free speech, a right to free expression and a right to hear what other people have to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance raised this afternoon by the Opposition, in seeking to justify its opposition to the electoral reforms proposed by the Hawke Government, has two flaws. Firstly, the Opposition carelessly assumes that there is no room for improvement in the freedom of expression currently enjoyed by all Australians-a very unwise assumption. On the contrary, there are still many Australians who, for the reasons of socio-economic, educational, linguistic, physical or locational disadvantage, are able to exercise much less than the freedom of expression which could be considered optimal. The Hawke Government has introduced well-targeted programs, as some people may have noticed, which are designed to bring this right-the right to speak, the right of expression, the right to hear and be educated-within the reach of all Australians. The Government is conscious of the inequities which still exist. This consciousness is one reason, but not the principal reason, for our commitment to this particular reform. Such considerations are not the chief purpose of this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The second flaw in Senator Parer's motion is in the attempt of the Opposition to equate the capacity to purchase advertising-excessively expensive electronic advertising in many cases, though not in all-with the right to freedom of expression. This is an indication not only of muddled-mindedness but also of a late conversion by the coalition to the principles of the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights; the instrument which was rejected categorically in this chamber as recently as 1986 when Senator Durack stated that if we are to have a Bill of Rights it ought to be based on something more apt and appropriate for Australia than the United Nations International Covenant on Human Rights. He got that wrong too: it was the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which was being used as the basis for the amendments that we were seeking to the Constitution.

This vehement and ill-informed rejection of the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights by the coalition was responsible for the defeat of this Government's proposal to include a Bill of Rights in our Constitution. That has been referred to several times this afternoon. The coalition's outrage at our intention to legislate to bar electronic political advertising is mild by comparison with the fury that it directed against the United Nations Covenant in 1986. This is the same covenant that the Opposition is now calling in aid and, at the same time, misinterpreting.

The coalition's confusion about rights should not surprise us however. Every move that has been made by successive Hawke governments over the past eight years to protect the rights of individuals by legislation has been opposed by the coalition or at least by substantial numbers of the coalition. This includes the sex discrimination legislation of 1984, based on the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. With the assistance of the Australian Democrats, we proceeded and were able to have that legislation finally adopted in the Senate. It is now widely accepted in the Australian community that this is an extremely valuable piece of legislation. In fact, it is very much taken for granted.

I have also referred to the constitutional amendments which failed in 1986, but even more recently we had considerable opposition from coalition members in this Parliament and also in State parliaments to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child-a convention which had been endorsed by all 160 member nations of the United Nations. It was ratified by many countries ahead of Australia because of the opposition to it here, especially opposition from National Party of Australia members around the nation.

At the time I made my first speech in this chamber in 1981, I had just read a slender volume entitled Liberal Thought by C. J. Puplick and R. J. Southey. I commented at the time that their approach to the issue was idiosyncratic, to say the least. One conclusion of the authors was that there are no unqualified rights except to be treated like a man. I asked at the time, `Which man?'. I have received no answer to that question, but I think this is indicative of the confusion that reigns within the Liberal and National parties about what is meant by imperatives and by human rights.

It should be clearly understood that all rights, as now codified in various United Nations instruments but as discussed by philosophers for centuries, are qualified. I too recommend to the coalition J.S. Mill on this subject. No rights are absolute. My rights are circumscribed as soon as my exercise of those rights encroaches upon the rights of another individual or in some way damages the public good. It is bizarre to try to elevate paid advertising to the status of a public good.

That is not just purely my opinion as a member of the Australian Labor Party. It is also the opinion that was agreed to by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Services (FACTS), which also incidentally cast serious doubt on the degree to which television is a significant influence on political choices. That opinion has been quoted several times in this debate this afternoon. The actual quote is as follows:
. . . free advertising is unnecessary as the public are informed through news services, commentaries and interviews in current affairs programs . . .
I also quote from the minority report of the Opposition:
Australians are well provided with such programs by the television and radio stations, both commercial and the ABC, and this is much to the credit of the stations.

We do not pretend for a moment that the Fourth Estate in Australia is completely without flaw, but there is considerably more opportunity for small groups and individuals to have their opinions and views aired and to hear the views of other people through the medium of news and current affairs programs rather than through the medium of paid advertising. What in fact do we get from paid advertising? By its very nature, it simply reflects the way in which advertising agencies filter and manipulate realities in order to attract swinging voters.

It is either dishonest or inept for the Opposition to quote article 19 (2) and to ignore article 19 (3), which is the qualifying clause. As I have said, every imperative in any United Nations document about civil, political or other rights has these qualifications, and such instruments should be quoted in full and not ignored.

Part (3) says that these rights are subject to certain restrictions provided by law and necessary for the protection of public order. This is where we come to the real point of the legislation that is being proposed by this Government. What could be more crucial to public order than the integrity of the electoral system? In other words, the proper functioning of the electoral system is the paramount consideration in our proposal to eliminate the necessity for political parties to raise huge sums of money to pay for advertising. That absolutely fundamental part of our position has been almost ignored this afternoon by the Opposition. I am aware of no set of imperatives which includes the right to advertise. That is what we are talking about, and that is what the Opposition is obsessed with, regardless of its protestations.

If during the next election campaign Senator Vanstone is suddenly taken by an overwhelming and unavoidable desire to throw an egg, I am quite certain that if she does it in the right place at the right time she will appear on the news and will probably be asked by someone later that day why she did it. There will be no need for her to advertise that she is the champion egg thrower of that campaign.

If, on the other hand, Dr Hewson makes some policy statement which is actually worth publicising-and I have no doubt that he will have things to say during that campaign-and it is in the public interest for it to be heard, that will also feature on the news, in commentaries and in interviews. In that way, there is more likelihood of the message he is trying to distribute and communicate coming over in its complete form and in a far more accurate way than would have been the case if one short phrase had been taken out for a grab, highly polished and filtered through goodness knows how many different ways of sanitising the way he looks, the way he speaks and the things he is saying. It will cost nothing except a little bit of careful thought in putting that policy or statement together in the first place.

I am afraid that the debate this afternoon on the Opposition side has been very much at an undergraduate level in relation to an understanding of human rights and an understanding and preparedness to give some real thought to what is intended, to what is behind the intentions of the Government and also to what the implications are of continuing the roller-coaster of having to raise enormous amounts of money in order to fund ever more expensive electronic advertising.

Indeed, in getting rid of political advertising in the electronic media, we are not jeopardising free speech; we are enhancing it. We are eliminating at least some of the selectiveness and the notorious superficiality of the grab: those few seconds, skilfully illustrated, which seek to focus the mind of the viewer, to exclude analysis and to appeal to the swinging voters, those precious few extra votes that we all woo-my Party, the same as others, in years past. In the future as well, we will still be trying to attract the swinging voters but in different ways, I assume.

The most effective election advertisements do not pretend to make a positive contribution to the debate. They are slick; they are beautifully produced; they are beautifully photographed; and they are about as stimulating as or slightly less so than the average sitcom. Nor are they used to put forward policies. At best, they will attempt to reduce a complex slogan, as has been said before this afternoon, to an idiot simple slogan. They try to seduce a voter with some slurring exercise for an anthem. Their real job is to hit and run.

There has been enough manipulation of people's voting intentions; it has not been very effective. It has cost an enormous amount of money, but most of all-and I go back to this point-it has been the raison d'etre for the raising of enormous and ever increasing sums of money by whatever methods.

We believe that this is the total antithesis of the way in which an electoral system maintains its integrity. We will do all that we can to ensure that this system of ours is one in which there is honesty and equity and in which the opportunity to degrade the system is eliminated as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, under section 191 I seek to explain a speech of mine which has been either misquoted or misunderstood. In the debate that has just concluded I made certain remarks. Senator Giles, among other speakers-I choose Senator Giles because she has just spoken-has either misunderstood those remarks or she has misrepresented what I chose to say.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two aspects in which this has happened and I would like to deal with the first aspect, and probably the most important one, first. In my speech I made the point that, if at the next election I were to throw an egg at the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), undoubtedly that would get on television. It was my assessment that if on the same day my Leader, John Hewson, were to make some comments elucidating the benefits of a goods and services tax, when the two were juxtaposed I would get on television for throwing an egg at the Prime Minister but the important information about the value of a goods and services tax would not get on. I made that point to make it clear that the media work on what is tantalising, what is sensational, what is confrontationist and what is news.

Senator Giles in her speech referred to those remarks that I made-she has only recently said this, I think even before you came in, Mr President-and said that, if I were to throw an egg at the Prime Minister, she was quite sure that I would not need to advertise the fact that I was a champion egg thrower. This misrepresents to people who may have been listening to her speech but not to mine what I was saying. I was not saying at all that if I threw an egg at the Prime Minister I would want to be able to advertise the fact; quite the opposite. I would have thought that any idiot who threw an egg would want to hide that fact. The very point that I was making was that stupid acts would get free coverage through current affairs and news programs and quite sensible statements would not. In that sense my speech was either misunderstood by Senator Giles or was most clearly misrepresented by her.

The second aspect in which I claim to have been misquoted or misunderstood is in relation to my reference to article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I made reference to that, as did a number of other speakers. Senator Giles in her speech-this is the second and last aspect in which I claim to have been misquoted or misunderstood-pointed out that, because people on this side, including me, had been opposed to a Bill of Rights, we were therefore opposed to article 19 relating to freedom of expression. She expressed surprise at the use of it in my speech. What she was conveying to people listening at that time was that in my speech I had rejected a position that I had held in the past. If that is the impression that Senator Giles got-it is certainly the impression that she gave to people who were listening when she was speaking-it is a misunderstanding. It is quite true that in my speech I did not refer to cases that I could have, for example, Davis v. the Commonwealth, which is the most recent one to uphold the common law right to freedom of expression, where certain Aboriginals claimed that the Australian Bicentennial Authority Act - -

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President - -
—If the Minister does not want me to go on about that, I will not - -

—I am raising a point of order, which is my right. Mr President, my point of order is that this is essentially an abuse of Standing Orders. We did hear Senator Vanstone's speech. It is true that Senator Giles disagreed with some of those things. But what is now being canvassed is a political point of view, not a matter of misrepresentation or wrong presentation. It is inappropriate for it to be canvassed at this length. We have been very tolerant about it but I think there is an extent to which tolerance can be stretched and we have gone beyond it now. Senator Vanstone should be brought to order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I indicated to you that there were two aspects, and I indicated very clearly that I was close to the end of the second one. I am close to the end of the second one and I would like the opportunity to conclude.
—I did feel that you were beginning to debate the question but, as I had heard neither speech, I thought I was lenient. But, if you are going to conclude, I ask you to do so.

—I conclude by saying that, to the extent that Senator Giles in her speech gave the impression that I no longer believed that there was a common law protection to the right of freedom of expression and that I now believed that the only protection available to freedom of expression was article 19, she misunderstood and misrepresented my position.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Perestroika: Implications for Australia-USSR Relations and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PERESTROIKA: IMPLICATIONS FOR
AUSTRALIA-USSR RELATIONS
Report of the Senate Standing Committee
on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade
Government Response
presented by Senator Gareth Evans,
Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade

The Committee's decision in September 1989 to conduct an inquiry into the implications of Soviet reforms for Australia-USSR relations was timely in its conception. The inquiry covered a broad range of issues-political, economic and strategic-and was undertaken at a time when the changes it dealt with occurred at a bewildering pace.

The Government welcomes the Report, which provides a contribution to public debate and policy formulation with regard to Australia's relations with the Soviet Union. There is much in the Report with which the Government can readily agree. The Report contains a number of valuable findings and recommendations, most of which are either consistent with the present thrust of Government policy, or are already being implemented. At the same time, these recommendations must be considered in the light of changes that have taken place in the USSR since the Committee delivered its findings, which have raised concerns about the direction of the Soviet reform process.
SOVIET REFORMS

The Committee has drawn attention to the major developments in the Soviet Union in that key period of 1989-90, coinciding roughly with the Committee's own deliberations. On the domestic front, we saw the emergence of embryonic democratic institutions which have done so much to crack the monolith of the Communist command system formed over seven decades. We also witnessed major improvements in the USSR's human rights performance, particularly in such areas as freedom of speech, religion and movement, although many reforms in those areas are yet to be thoroughly rooted in law and practice.

Of singular importance has been the growth of representative institutions in the 15 union-republics of the USSR (and indeed in many smaller autonomous republics and other administrative units) culminating in the election during 1990 of republican governments which were variously non-Communist, reform-minded or asserting republican autonomy and seeking to loosen links with Moscow to some degree. In the process, the question of the very future shape and existence of the Soviet Union has been raised. Insofar as it touches on fundamental intra-Union power relations and insofar as some republics, such as the Baltic States, are seeking to leave the Union, the nationalities issue has assumed an importance equal to that other great problem which has dogged the course of perestroika-the economy.

1989-90 saw the continuation of faltering steps towards economic reform. The election of reform-minded republican governments gave a boost to such efforts, particularly with early attempts at cooperation between the central government and the government of the Russian Federation, which focused on the much-discussed ``500-days'' plan for a transition to a market economy. Those attempts did not bear real fruit, and many of the precepts underlying the ``500-days'' model of a decisive shift to market conditions were watered down in the version finally adopted by the USSR Supreme Soviet-in large part because they challenged important institutional strongholds and long-cherished ideological beliefs. Nonetheless, the ``guidelines'' adopted did have the major virtue of enshrining a commitment to a transition to a market economy, albeit after a lengthy transition period.

The debate on economic reform was to a large degree conditioned by the acceleration of the Soviet Union's economic decline during 1990. The latter can be attributed to a number of factors: the way in which the reforms were implemented; the decline in the Soviet Union's external position, particularly as a result of falling oil export values; resistance by bureaucratic interests associated with the old command economy; and dislocations caused by the breakdowns in traditional chains of command and confusion and conflict over lines of authority following the emergence of new political structures.

The Committee has also highlighted the changes in Soviet foreign policy the impact of which was felt to an unprecedented degree during 1989-90. These changes were driven both by domestic economic factors and by a reassessment in the Soviet Union of its own interests and of the rationality of previous foreign policy. The results have been noted by many commentators. First and foremost, superpower cooperation reached a level undreamed of several years ago.

Other key results have been the conclusion of major arms control treaties, such as the Agreements on Intermediate Nuclear Forces and Conventional Forces in Europe; and the transformation of the strategic landscape in Europe, with the relinquishing of Soviet military domination of Eastern Europe and the emergence of fledgling democracies there; and the drawing of the Soviet Union into the pan-European process, particularly following the signature of the Paris Charter last November. In a broader perspective, a fundamental aspect of the new East-West relationship has been the decline of ideological competition which had been for over forty years the centrepiece and organising principle of international relations.

The Government has recognised the fundamental changes that have been encapsulated in the statement that the Cold War is over, as well as the formidable challenges and considerable opportunities they present, not least of all in our own region. The Committee points to the shifts that have occurred in the Soviet Union's relations with the Asia-Pacific region and the fact that they are occurring in a security environment which has its own characteristics and is quite different from the European strategic landscape. I would take issue, however, with the Committee's suggestion that the Government is not addressing in a thoroughgoing fashion the longer term implications for our region of the changes in the global security environment. This is a point to which I shall return.
RECENT DEVELOPMENTS

The Government can therefore agree broadly with the Committee's assessment that the Soviet Union has changed in fundamental ways; that a return to an exact replica of the past is impossible; and that radical and probably irreversible changes have taken place in the global strategic environment which will have a profound impact on our own region. The Government can also concur with the Committee's prediction that uncertainty and instability are likely to be a feature of the Soviet political landscape for some time to come.
