That assessment has been underlined by the course of events there in recent months since the Committee's Report was released. Indeed, the development that first caused alarm bells to be rung loudly, the resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze, occurred on the same day that the Report was tabled. The events of ensuing months have introduced a note of caution into assessments of the Soviet Union and of appropriate policy responses.

The main trend of recent months could be characterised as a resurgence of traditionalist forces in the central organs of Soviet power, concerned that changes were going too far or too fast; as well as sharpening of conflict between the central government and the republics. The developments which have raised serious concerns about the future of the reform process include the use of force in the Baltic States; the departure of leading reformist figures from the ranks of President Gorbachev's key advisers; strengthening of the roles allotted to military and security forces domestically, including in the economic field; statements by senior ministers redolent of pre-perestroika days suggesting that Western governments and business have engaged in subversion in the USSR; efforts to place curbs on some of the more critical and outspoken elements in the media; and economic measures which appear to reinforce centralised controls rather than open the way to market reforms.

Considerable uncertainty continues to surround the future shape of centre-republican relations. The recent referendum on preservation of the Union, held on 17 March, continues to leave many questions unanswered. While it showed that a majority in the participating republics voted to support the retention of a Union of republics in some form, it did nothing to resolve the future of those republics whose governments boycotted the poll, particularly the Baltic States whose plebiscites conducted in preceding weeks underlined the strength of support for their governments' aspirations to regain independence-aspirations which Australia has supported for many years. It is also an open question as to what kind of a Union people thought they were voting for, given that some republics amended the question or added supplementary ones which reflected differing ideas about the kind of ties that should obtain between the centre and the constituent units of a new federation. This issue will be at the top of the Soviet political agenda for some months and seems likely to be the subject of intense bargaining and negotiation.

In the area of foreign policy, it has also been disconcerting to hear the stridency and increasing volume of voices criticising the foreign policy path followed by the Gorbachev-Shevardnadze team. Those voices were raised in particular against the position taken by the Soviet Union in relation to the Gulf War. There have also been difficulties associated with implementation of the CFE treaty and in progress on negotiation of a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, and in resolving arrangements for the withdrawal of Soviet forces from Poland.

Nevertheless, it is heartening to note that Mr Gorbachev has reaffirmed his commitment to reform and in particular to the ``new thinking'' in Soviet foreign policy. It is notable that the Soviet Union stood firm in its support for United Nations action in countering Iraqi aggression against Kuwait; the Supreme Soviet has ratified the Two-Plus-Four Agreement on German reunification; and the Soviet Union agreed with its Warsaw Pact partners to dismantle the military structure of the Warsaw Treaty Organisation effective from 31 March.

The developments of recent months do raise the prospect that the Soviet Union could take one of a number of different paths, some of which the Committee has noted in its conclusions. While the Committee argued that the general direction of reform which the Soviet Government has been implementing is towards a more open and increasingly democratic society with a market-based economy, and maintaining its current foreign policy line, we cannot be so sanguine that this is an inevitable course. Possible scenarios include the reversal of key reforms and the installation of an even more hard-line government with or without Mr Gorbachev, with more repressive policies aimed particularly at rebellious republics. In such a case, while a return to the full-blooded confrontation of the Cold War is highly improbable, a more difficult relationship with Western democracies, and the possibility of many of the gains made in recent years being challenged or threatened, would be more likely.
IMPLICATIONS FOR AUSTRALIA

It is in that context that our policies must be formulated, including with respect to the specific recommendations of the Report. It is not a situation that calls for a single-track policy. Clearly, much will depend on how the unfolding Soviet drama is played out. On the one hand we will continue to encourage reform within the limits of our capacity to do so, so long as there is an underlying commitment to basic reform. Our aim should be to give both moral support to the proponents of reform in various regions and levels of public life-through engaging the Soviet Union in dialogue, and encouraging its integration into the international community-and to provide access to expertise and experience, that will assist those reforms to take root.

At the same time, it must be made clear that cooperation and support for the Soviet Union will not be forthcoming at any price, regardless of the domestic policies it pursues. We, along with other countries, made clear in responding to the use of force in the Baltic republics in January, that such recourse to violence cannot but affect the course of cooperation between the Soviet Union and Western countries, including Australia. We believe that the Western message on this point was clearly received, and possibly averted an even more tragic turn of events.

The role of countries like Australia in responding to the manner in which centre-republican relations and other contentious domestic issues are resolved should be to encourage a peaceful and democratic resolution of these problems. Notwithstanding the difficult and complex challenges facing the Soviet Union, it is important that democratic institutions be given a chance to take root and the desire of ethnic and other minorities for autonomy in governing their affairs should be respected. We strongly urge that the path of dialogue and negotiation be followed. In the case of the Baltic States, we have urged the Soviet Government to respect their aspirations to independence, as we do not recognise their incorporation into the Soviet Union. These are principles which we should support both for their own sake, derived as they are from our strong support for human rights and international law, and because it is by following that path that the Soviet Union is likely to achieve a prosperity and security which will be to the benefit of the entire international community.

The Government stands ready to support the reform process within the means available to us, but our capacity in this regard should not be overstated. It is prepared to consider the question of extending technical economic assistance of the kind already provided to Eastern Europe, as the Committee recommends, and has already offered to arrange a high-level business mission to the Soviet Union to study and advise on food storage, processing and transport problems. Our decision to provide credit facilities, which will enable the Soviet Union to purchase traditional commodities as well as food, took into account the present economic difficulties facing the USSR. The Government decided, however, not to provide direct food aid to the USSR, given a number of practical difficulties rather than through any lack of sympathy.

The Government is also ready to continue to strengthen the web of dialogue, exchanges and formal arrangements which we have with the Soviet Union. Those relations have been developed vigorously by this Government since 1983. The number of bilateral agreements concluded has grown from four to sixteen. The two-way exchange of visitors and delegations has expanded considerably. These provide a framework which contributes not only to advancing our economic and political interests, but also to the process of drawing the Soviet Union into a more normal relationship with the international community as a whole.

In this process, the Government will pay special attention to fostering ties with the Soviet republics, as the Committee rightly suggests. Assuming that the republics continue to strengthen their autonomy, particularly in the field of economic decision-making, it will be necessary for Australia to establish broader contacts with the governments and peoples of the republics. At the same time, the extent and the type of arrangements that Australia is able to enter into with those republics will depend very much on the kind of status the republics acquire as a result of negotiations within the Soviet Union in the months and years ahead.
STRATEGIC RELATIONSHIPS

An important aspect of the Report concerns the implications of changes in Soviet foreign policy for our own strategic environment. The Committee notes the trend towards declining superpower competition and a multi-polar world, which is likely to have a profound impact on our region, a subject that will continue to require careful review and reassessment.

The Government does not believe, however, that it is appropriate at this point to engage in a strategic review by Cabinet as recommended by the Committee. We consider that the Committee has underestimated the extent to which the Government has already responded to the changes that are occurring in the Asia-Pacific region. Indeed, my December 1989 statement on Australia's Regional Security was premised on a recognition that the global and regional environments in which Asian and Pacific countries pursue their security policies are changing rapidly, and that changes in East-West relations have implications for the Asia-Pacific region as well as for Europe. The assessments of the Regional Security Statement not only remain valid today, but have been reinforced by a rapid series of events over the past year which further underline the fluidity of the present regional security situation.

Furthermore, it should be emphasised that the changes flowing from reform in the USSR do not undermine the bases on which Australia's defence policy and force structure development have been formulated, particularly as set out in the 1987 Defence White Paper and the classified report to Government ``Australia's Strategic Planning in the l990s''. Those policy documents, which concentrated on developments in Australia's areas of primary strategic significance-South East Asia, the Eastern Indian Ocean and the South-West Pacific-retain their force and effectiveness. Reform in the USSR has little direct relevance to the formulation of Australia's defence policy and force structure development, as the USSR in current and prospective circumstances does not pose a direct military threat to Australia.

The Government has recognised that it must respond to the more fluid and complex regional security environment Australia now faces through contributing in an active and considered way to the development of new processes and dialogues in the region. An important example was Australia's proposal at the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference in Jakarta in July 1990, and in a number of subsequent discussions, for the development of enhanced regional dialogue on security issues. The Government has given priority to the deepening of existing dialogues with regional partners and to the commencement of new regular dialogues on regional security issues where these did not already exist, for example with the Indochinese states.

Active engagement in a continuing process of dialogue and review is the most appropriate way to tackle the task of analysing and responding to the changes in our region, both indigenous changes and those flowing from the changes that have occurred in the USSR and in East/West relations. Central to the Government's approach has been the need to pursue assiduously processes of dialogue, both bilateral and regional, in order to develop a sense of shared strategic interest and mutual security understanding in the Asia-Pacific region.

The development of any sort of comprehensive regional security institution is not a goal of our policy. It is too early to say what role such an institution might play, or what form it might take. We therefore believe that our efforts should be directed to developing and expanding the region's network of bilateral and multilateral security dialogues.

In developing this process, it is essential that we take account of realities distinguishing the Asia-Pacific region. In particular, the Asia-Pacific region differs from Europe in that there is multiplicity of security concerns, varying from country to country and sub-region to sub-region. Moreover, countries of the region have demonstrated a preference for bilateral solutions, particularly in matters of security, and there are some mechanisms already in place for handling aspects of security. These include the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation and the Five Power Defence Arrangements. For Australia, our alliance commitment to the United States remains of fundamental importance. The maintenance of US strategic engagement in the Western Pacific is vital to the security of the region as a whole. To be soundly based, any future regional security arrangements would have to take full account of United States interests and views.

The evolution of the Soviet Union's role in regional dialogue will be tempered by the uncertainties regarding political outcomes in the Soviet Union, to which I have already referred. Nevertheless the Soviet Union has made some contributions to improving the security environment in the Asia-Pacific region. It has drawn down its forces in the region and is withdrawing its power projection capability from South East Asia. It has played a constructive role in seeking a settlement of the Cambodian problem. Normalisation of Soviet relations with the Republic of Korea has also been an important step.

With the strengthening of this more positive role in the region and of its political and economic reforms, the Soviet Union is likely to be engaged more deeply in processes of regional dialogue, including in regional economic mechanisms. Australia already discusses regional security and arms control issues with the Soviet Union. While Soviet participation in the APEC mechanism is unlikely for the foreseeable future, the Government wishes to support the development of the USSR's economic links with the region and its involvement in regional economic dialogue, not least in recognition of our economic interests, as well as the need to encourage a broader and more constructive Soviet role in the region. As a measure of this, Australia has supported the USSR's application to join the Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference (PECC). No consensus has thus far been reached on the Soviet application within PECC.
AUSTRALIA-USSR ECONOMIC RELATIONS

The Committee has identified a number of important trends which will affect Australia's trade with the USSR in both the short-and longer-term. The Government concurs with the Report's overall conclusion that while the Soviet Union's worsening economic conditions are a barrier to any significant increase in bilateral trade, it is essential for the Australian Government and business community to remain alert to any opportunities that might arise as the Soviet authorities seek to transform its economy, and realise the potential latent in its endowments of great natural resources and a large and well-educated population.

The Soviet Union has long been an important and stable trading partner for Australia. However, recent developments underline the extent of the challenges facing Australia in maintaining its exports to the USSR at the level of previous years. These have fallen from some $l billion in 1989 to $414 million last year, largely reflecting the hard currency crunch that country is now facing. That, in turn, is as good an indicator as any of the accelerated decline of the Soviet economy; according to Soviet estimates, the GNP could fall by as much as 11.6% in 1991, industrial production by more than 15% and agricultural output by 5%. Last year the Soviet Union also recorded its second successive hard currency trade deficit, a problem that is likely to continue, particularly given declining oil production, exports of which have been a principal source of hard currency revenues.

Another difficulty lies in the uncertainty surrounding the economic direction that Soviet policy makers wish to pursue. While there is a stated commitment to a transition to a market economy, recent economic measures in many respects are characterised instead by continued centralisation. No steps have been taken to implement any effective price reforms, planning norms rather than market signals remain in primacy, the vital sector of agriculture remains in state hands, and even cooperatives, representing the first faltering steps towards private enterprise, have come under attack from the traditionalist forces. To some extent all this is the result of understandable concern to reassert control over the economy in a period of rapid decline and dislocating changes, but, unfortunately, it is also attributable to vested interests in, and ideological resistance to changing, old methods and structures.

While the Soviet Government has acknowledged a role for foreign participation in the country's economic development, the ground rules regarding rouble convertibility, joint ventures and foreign investment remain vague and the bureaucracy obstructive. A particularly significant problem now emerging is the great uncertainty over hard currency reserves and earnings between the centre and the republics, straining at Moscow's economic leash. In short, there is thus considerable uncertainty regarding the future environment for trade with the USSR.

It is against this background of economic uncertainty that the Government's efforts during the last year have been focused on protecting existing levels of trade, particularly following Soviet delays in payments for Australian imports, especially wool. The Government's decision to extend credit facilities to the Soviet Union worth $525 million, which the Committee has welcomed, was part of a strategy aimed at securing the repayment of those debts, and encouraging a resumption of traditional commodity trade. Following that decision, the bulk of the outstanding amounts owed for wool exports has been paid, and Soviet buying organisations have utilised the credit facility to make significant purchases of Australian wheat and barley. The Soviet Union has also now re-entered the market for Australian wool, using the credit facility.

The Government takes note of the Committee's recommendation that additional credit arrangements be considered for other Australian exports. The Government believes that a more cautious approach would be prudent for the time being, to allow assessment of the performance of the current credit facility. Similarly, the Government is not convinced that such arrangements can be extended to individual republics until their status and their capacity to pay for imports are resolved with a much greater degree of clarity than presently exists. While the Committee has perhaps overestimated the capacity of the republican governments to enter into formal foreign economic relations at present, it is undeniably correct in pointing to the need to pursue a broader range of economic contacts involving decision-makers at the republican level. This is now an increasingly important focus of our trade diplomacy towards the Soviet Union, one which will lay important foundations should the republics' powers to engage in foreign trade become established and consolidated.

The Committee has provided a number of pertinent recommendations with respect to enhancing our economic relations with the USSR. The Government concurs with the view that the provision of technical economic assistance, particularly management training, is potentially of benefit not only to the Soviet Union but also in strengthening Australian business links with that country. The Government also accepts the need to keep under review the quality and dissemination of information and advice to business to assist the latter's efforts to export to the Soviet Union. The possibility of establishing regular air services between Australia and the USSR is now being explored. The Government will also seek to strengthen the existing bilateral framework underpinning economic relations with the USSR, both through existing agreements, and through the negotiation of new agreements on Investment Protection and Double Taxation.

The Government also accepts the thrust of the Report's findings concerning the need to work actively to reduce unnecessary restrictions on exports of technology to the Soviet Union, governed by COCOM controls. It is precisely the interests of Australian exporters that prompted the Government's decision for Australia to participate in COCOM. The Government has also sought to ensure that timely adjustments are made to Australian regulatory mechanisms and prompt advice is provided to industry in relation to changes in COCOM controls. However, the Government does not believe that COCOM controls have been a significant impediment to expansion of exports to the USSR. To a large extent, the basic problem facing exporters to the USSR will remain that of identifying, in the face of bureaucratic, structural and personnel changes in the Soviet Union, the right people to deal with who have the capacity to pay for Australian goods and services.
SOVIET FAR EAST

The Committee has identified both opportunities and difficulties facing the development of economic links with the Soviet Far East. The difficulties include not only those applying to trade with the USSR as a whole, but also poor economic infrastructure in the Soviet Far East, similarities between that region and Australia as well as natural limitations which flow from the latter's proximity to Korea and Japan.

That said, opportunities nonetheless exist for the development of a worthwhile partnership with the Soviet Far East. This was the thinking behind the Government's initiative to mount an Australian Trade Exhibition held in Vladivostok in July last year. The Exhibition was successful in generating a significant amount of business for Australian firms, but equally significantly, it laid the foundations for longer term commercial relationships between Australian business and Soviet partners in the region. Many of the firms exhibiting at Vladivostok are engaged in precisely those areas that the Report identifies as offering scope for Australia: mining and mining technology, food handling and processing, transport, and construction. AUSTRADE is developing a strategy to follow up the Exhibition in consultation with interested companies.
CONCLUSION

The Senate Committee's findings and recommendations make a valuable contribution to the development of policy with regard to Australia's relations with the Soviet Union and in relation to our broader security environment. The schedule of responses tabled with this statement addresses the specific recommendations in detail.

The changes taking place in the Soviet Union are of profound significance for the world community, and the task of assessing and responding to those changes will continue to occupy an important place in Australian foreign policy. Recent events have served to emphasise the fluid nature of the situation in the Soviet Union, which will temper the way in which our relations develop. While Australia's capacity to influence developments in the Soviet Union is limited, we will seek to play our part in encouraging the continuation of the democratic reforms and reorientation of foreign policy initiated by President Gorbachev's program of perestroika; and will seek to foster a constructive and mutually beneficial relationship with the Soviet Union and its diverse republics and regions.
COMMITTEE RECOMMENDATIONS AND SCHEDULE OF RESPONSES
STRATEGIC ISSUES
RECOMMENDATION ONE

5.13 Recommendation One: The Committee recommends a Cabinet review of Australia's strategic environment to supplement, and go beyond the Defence White Paper of 1987 and the Foreign Minister's December 1989 Statement of Regional Security.

5.14 In conducting such a review one important issue that needs to be addressed is the need for appropriate mechanisms or processes for regional security consultations. Ways of promoting an approach in the Asia-Pacific region similar to that pursued with considerable success in Europe need to be more fully explored by Australia and other countries. The risks of an arms race spiral amongst members of the region are too great to permit Australia the easy options of accepting without question the policies and framework of the Cold War or of leaving it to others to determine the direction and pace of change.

5.15 In the Asian region, President Gorbachev proposed in his Vladivostok speech of 1986 a process similar to that started in Helsinki in 1975. In 1990 a similar proposal was tentatively put forward by Australia as a possible goal for the future.

5.16 It is generally recognised that the situation in the Asian region is different from that in Europe. The Cold War dynamic of two hostile camps has worked more indirectly in Asia, though with more devastating results, making the unravelling of that dynamic more complex. So, for instance, although the Indo-Chinese states have been closely aligned with the USSR the alliance relationship has not been as close as that between the USSR and the Eastern European countries. This is also the case with North Korea, which has maintained close relations with both China and the USSR. Not only has there not been a Warsaw Pact in Asia but allies and friends of the USSR have often had minds of their own. This has been most evident in the case of China, once firmly in the Soviet camp but subsequently an implacable opponent. India, too has never entered into an alliance with the USSR, and has not only maintained its independence as a sovereign nation but also asserted itself as a regional power in its own right.

5.17 Nonetheless, super-power rivalry has been imposed upon regional disputes, and has been evident in the India-Pakistan relationship, the Vietnam War, the Cambodian problem, and in the division of Korea. It has also been a significant factor in the high levels of US and Soviet military presence in the northeast Pacific, as well as the US presence in the Philippines and Soviet military and other assistance to Vietnam.
Response

The paragraphs preceding the Committee's first recommendation note the strategic significance to Australia of developments in the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War. The Committee acknowledges that the impact of these developments on Australia's immediate strategic environment is less easy to assess, and asks a series of questions which, in its view, call for a thorough reassessment of Australia's strategic environment.

The Government has constantly monitored the changes to the strategic environment referred to, and has responded accordingly. It is firmly of the view that the bases of its strategic policies, in particular the Defence White Paper of 1987, Senator Evans' Regional Security Statement of December 1989, and the classified report to Government, ``Australia's Strategic Planning in the l990s,'' retain their force and effectiveness. It does not consider that a Cabinet review, going beyond those policies, is warranted.

For defence, it needs to be noted that reform in the Soviet Union has little immediate relevance to the formulation of Australia's defence policy and force structure development as set out in the Defence White Paper, which concentrated on developments in Australia's areas of primary strategic significance, namely South East Asia, the Eastern Indian Ocean and the South-West Pacific. In current and prospective circumstances the USSR does not pose a direct military threat to Australia.

In terms of foreign policy, the 1989 statement on Australia's regional security was premised on a recognition that the global and regional environments in which Asian and Pacific countries pursue their security policies are changing rapidly, that changes in East-West relations have implications for the Asia Pacific region as well as for Europe and that these issues are already being actively and comprehensively addressed by the Government.

In the Government's view and as the Report itself implicitly acknowledges, the assessments in the Regional Security Statement remain valid today. Indeed they have been reinforced by a rapid series of significant events over the last year which further underline the fluidity of the present regional strategic situation. Some of the changes occurred as a direct consequence of the fundamental change in East-West relations. Others were indirect consequences of that change and some were indigenous to the region. But it is clear that the effects of rapid changes in East-West relations are not confined to Europe alone but have implications for the security of countries in the Asia Pacific region.

The Committee goes on (paragraph 5.14) to state that a review should address the need for appropriate mechanisms or processes for regional security consultations. This is a pertinent observation, which goes to the heart of current Government policy attention.

The Government has recognised that it must respond to the fluid and complex regional strategic environment which Australia now confronts and is actively engaged in efforts towards the establishment of new processes for security consultations in the region. The Government's objective is the gradual development of a regional security community based on a sense of shared security interests. The situation in the Asia-Pacific region differs in important respects from that in Europe. There are disparate regional conflicts (e.g. Korea, Cambodia and the Spratlys) and, apart from the Korean Peninsula, there is an absence of the bloc-to-bloc confrontation that marked the Cold War in Europe. The second factor is that countries of the region, even those in associations such as ASEAN, have demonstrated a preference for bilateral solutions, particularly in matters of security.

For Australia, our alliance commitment to the United States is of fundamental importance. The United States' presence in the Asia-Pacific region, which is essentially maritime, has underpinned the stability and prosperity of the region since the Second World War, and the maintenance of the US strategic presence in the Western Pacific is vital to the continuing stability of the region in the future. The views of other allies of the United States, notably of Japan, are also important in the Government's thinking. As the Government said in December 1989: ``The United States-Japan Security Treaty continues to underpin North Asian regional security.'' Accordingly the Government places priority on the need to ensure that the US continues to maintain a viable presence in the region.

These factors have played a significant part in the Government's approach. It has examined what Australia can do on its own, what bilateral opportunities can be exploited and what multilateral options are available.

The Government has taken a number of initiatives over the past two years at the bilateral level with the aim of improving Australia's security environment. It has built on the existing pattern of talks at ministerial and official level, for example disarmament talks and discussion on strategic issues and threat perceptions. It has significantly improved dialogue and cooperation with neighbours such as Indonesia. It has extended its links with all countries of the region in this period.

The Government has also taken multilateral security and security-related initiatives, including disarmament at the international and regional levels. The Government's multidimensional approach to security is detailed in Senator Evans's Regional Security Statement.

The essence of the Government's approach-which is covered to an extent by the Committee's second recommendation-is one of dialogue. Dialogue with allies ensures that essential security interests are harmonised. Dialogue at the bilateral level with regional countries provides an effective way to address their specific concerns, to cope with the risk of weapons proliferation and arms races, and to work out ways to make further progress, whether through one-to-one cooperation or through the involvement of a wider range of parties. Dialogue at the multilateral level is a matter for cautious handling, and is still in the exploratory phase. The objective of such a process of dialogue is what the Government has called the gradual development of a regional security community based on a sense of shared security interests.

The Committee has recommended (paragraph 5.18) that the network of bilateral defence and security contacts already established should be further developed, including with the Indochina states. The Government has already been able to include Vietnam and Laos as full participants in its efforts to develop dialogue on regional security issues. The first round of talks with Vietnam took place in Canberra in February 1991; both sides would like to see these talks continue on a regular basis. Given the difference in perceptions on defence issues between Australia and Vietnam and Laos, there is not yet a basis for defence contacts. In the event of a comprehensive settlement being achieved in Cambodia, Australia would be prepared to make a major contribution to a United Nations presence in that country.
RECOMMENDATION TWO

5.18 Recommendation Two: The Committee recommends that, at the same time, the Australian Government should continue to press for the establishment of regular processes of multilateral dialogue on security issues for the whole region. The USSR should be a part of this regional process. The Soviet Union has legitimate interests in the region and legitimate aspirations to be part of that region's efforts to promote the economic well-being of members of the region within a secure regional environment.
Response

In recent years regional dialogue on security has increased significantly. The Government has encouraged this process, because we recognise that the process of dialogue can quickly bring in its train a building of confidence, transparency and readiness to cooperate in specific ways.

But the development of any sort of comprehensive regional security institution is not a goal of the Government's policy. It is too early to say what role such an institution might play, or what form it might take. We therefore believe that our efforts should be directed to developing and expanding the region's network of bilateral and multilateral security dialogues.

The Government has pursued that goal with energy and innovation. Some of these efforts can be briefly summarised. Existing dialogue with regional countries has been extended, and regular talks have been supplemented by other exchanges, visits and defence cooperation. Global activity in disarmament has been supplemented with initiatives at the regional level, particularly with regard to chemical weapons. Non-governmental and academic exchanges have been supported as additional aspects of the enhanced dialogue process.

In the Government's view established regional organisations and mechanisms are of primary importance in helping to manage change in the evolving strategic environment. In particular, the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference (PMC) process is a mechanism through which active and frank exchanges on regional security issues can be held among South East Asian states with their designated dialogue partners, Australia, New Zealand, the United States, Japan, the EC and Canada. The Republic of Korea is expected to be admitted as a dialogue partner later this year. Regional security issues appeared on the ASEAN agenda for the first time last year, in Jakarta. Australia put forward a proposal for the development of enhanced regional dialogue on security issues at the ASEAN PMC and in subsequent bilateral discussions.

The absence of any single commonly perceived threat distinguishes Asia from Europe in security terms. There is instead a multiplicity of security concerns, varying from country to country and sub-region to sub-region. The mechanisms already in place, such as the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, regional disarmament arrangements and the system of alliances with the United states all make important contributions to processes for enhancing security or for conflict resolution.

The Government notes the contribution made by the Soviet Union to debate on regional security issues, notably in speeches in Vladivostok by Mr Gorbachev in 1986 and by then Foreign Minister Shevardnadze in 1990. Australia welcomed the acknowledgement by the Soviet Union in the latter, less ambitious speech, that a step-by-step process is necessary for the Asia Pacific region. The Government remains cautious on the proposal made by Mr Shevardnadze for a meeting of Asian Foreign Ministers in 1993. This is some way off and its current status uncertain. In the meantime there are a number of contributions the Soviet Union itself could take towards enhanced regional security and confidence-building, including greater transparency in military dispositions in the Soviet Far East and resolving its longstanding bilateral issue with Japan.

The Government fully recognises the major contribution made by the Soviet Union to reducing tensions at the global level, with significant implications for the Asia Pacific region. It has drawn down its forces in the region and is withdrawing its power projection capability from South East Asia. The Soviet Union's constructive role in seeking a settlement of the Cambodian problem and its normalisation of relations with the Republic of Korea are instances of its contribution to an improved security environment in the region. Problems remain, however. One set of problems relates to Japan, and the North Asia sub-region in particular, which remains one part of the region where old tensions persist. Moreover recent events in the Soviet Union may indicate a broader retreat from domestic and foreign policy reforms; this tendency could increase if the Soviet traditionalist lobby gains increasing sway over policy.
RECOMMENDATION THREE

5.19 Recommendation Three: The Committee recommends that one area that should be the subject of regional discussions is the overall levels of armament in the Asia-Pacific region. While there have been some unilateral reductions both by the Soviet Union and the United States, there is no comprehensive multilateral discussion of arms control in the region similar to that which has occurred in Europe. Such discussion is important not only because of the dangers inherent in the concentration of superpower military power in the Northeast Pacific but also because of the potential for arms races to occur between the major regional powers in the multi-polar security environment now emerging.
Response
The Government shares the Committee's concern that changes in the Asia Pacific region should not lead to greater strategic uncertainty or precipitate a regional arms race.

The Government's proposal for enhanced dialogues on regional security issues is directed precisely towards achieving these ends. Through the encouragement of communication, dialogue, transparency, and through understanding how others view the threats they face and how they feel they need to respond, we hope to discourage competitive arms acquisitions or the adoption of policies which increase military tensions. These processes will reduce suspicions and misapprehensions that might emerge as a result of the changes taking place and lessen uncertainty about the new strategic balance in the region.

The Government is working on two broad fronts: to promote global regimes aimed at constraining or eliminating proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and excessive arms transfers, and at the regional level to develop a common sense of security to remove the rationale for any arms race and to encourage support within the region for global actions. It recognises that the Gulf War has accentuated the dangers of weapons proliferation, although the aftermath of that war has also provided a unique opportunity to address the obvious challenge to security posed by the proliferation of the means of mass destruction and by the excessive accumulation of weaponry, as in Iraq.

Australia has the capacity and international standing on arms control to play a significant role in endeavouring to advance international arms control and disarmament efforts. The Government sees it as part of its global responsibilities and as part of Australia's direct national security interests to make every effort in these directions.

There is an urgent need for measures to strengthen the existing export control regimes on items related to nuclear, chemical, biological and missile proliferation. We are active participants in the Nuclear Suppliers Group, the Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR) and the Australia Group which has instituted controls on chemical weapon precursors and equipment.

We recognise however, that the only feasible long term answer to the proliferation of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons is through global multilateral agreements. In this regard, we have stepped up our efforts by working to revitalise and impart a new sense of urgency to the negotiations in the Conference on Disarmament (CD) on the comprehensive Chemical Weapons Convention; continuing to work in the CD and at this year's UN General Assembly for the early conclusion of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT); and pressing for the development of a verification package to tighten the Biological Weapons Convention at the forthcoming Review Conference in September 1991.

The international community has yet to come to grips with the proliferation of massive amounts of offensive conventional weaponry. This is a complex issue but clearly more restraints are needed on a global basis and we expect it to become a major focus in the future. Australia is an active participant in the growing exchanges between countries on this particular problem. The United Nations Expert Group on Conventional Arms Transfers has been focusing on increasing transparency of conventional arms transfers. An Australian expert is a member of the group. The Australian Government looks forward to finalisation of the group's conclusions and recommendations, to which it will give careful consideration.

Conventional arms are readily available from a wide variety of sources, except for specialised categories involving very high technology. Wide agreement amongst arms producers could be expected to have some effect particularly with respect to more sophisticated items, but it has to be recognised that effective supply side controls are difficult to realise in practice.

The most enduring and satisfactory outcome for restraint, in the Middle East for example, would be the achievement of a political settlement which at least reduced the incentive to purchase arms and hopefully included a regional agreement capping arms levels.

There is a strong regional aspect to Australia's international work on arms control. The Government recognises that its efforts in multilateral forums is contributing to the emergence and establishment of non-proliferation regimes which can shape the pattern and habits and practice of countries in our region towards avoidance of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. We are, in addition, taking direct steps to address the regional situation:

(i) As a member of the South Pacific Forum, we are proud of our role in the establishment of the South Pacific Nuclear Weapons Free Zone which is a significant regional measure in the fight against regional nuclear proliferation;

(ii) We have sought to ensure that the region is kept free of an entire category of weapons of mass destruction by the Chemical Weapons Regional Initiative. Based in our strong commitment to secure complete chemical weapons disarmament, this concept, initially advanced by the Australian Prime Minister, seeks to develop a solid regional consensus for the early conclusion of a global Chemical Weapons Convention to eliminate chemical weapons and to prepare for its implementation;
(iii) We are stepping up our efforts to strengthen Asia-Pacific regional commitment to international arms control treaties and to keep the region free of proliferation pressures.

As well, the Government firmly believes that it is important that countries in the region develop a sense of shared strategic interests and an understanding of each other's security needs, objectives and capabilities in order to remove the rationale for any excessive build-up of arms or a regional arms race. We see this developing through a growing network of bilateral and sub-regional dialogues on such issues as military capabilities and doctrine, and security requirements and perceptions. This is of particular significance in a South East Asia context because of the region's importance for Australia's security. The bilateral disarmament consultations we conduct are an important component of security-related dialogue with regional countries which is fundamental to the Government's approach to handling regional security issues in the post Cold War era.

Compared with the process of dialogue in Europe in recent years, there is little in the way of free-flowing exchanges on security issues between countries in the Asia Pacific. It is, however, only through such processes of dialogue that mistrust can be broken down, different interests better understood and accommodated, constructive patterns of reassurance developed, and a beginning made on establishing common security as the prevailing security perception in our region. Australia is working hard to develop these habits of consultation and exchange in the hope that a strengthening of the web of dialogue at the bilateral and sub-regional level will lead to an understanding of shared security interests in the region, and a realisation that as a region we have much more in common than we have to separate us.
RECOMMENDATION FOUR

5.20 Recommendation Four: Regarding possible nuclear proliferation Australia has consistently supported initiatives to achieve a global nuclear non-proliferation regime. In line with this approach, the committee recommends the review should therefore thoroughly explore what measures Australia might take to reduce the risk of nuclear proliferation in the region, particularly on the Korean peninsula and by Taiwan. More specifically, the review should examine what scope there might be for Australia to act as a facilitator in bringing the three nuclear powers with a direct interest in the issue, namely the United States, the Soviet Union and China, together to address the issue.
Response

The Government acknowledges the great importance of the issues addressed in this Recommendation. Australia is a leading participant in international efforts to restrain nuclear proliferation, both through its own efforts and in multilateral forums. The recommendation refers to both the Korean Peninsula and Taiwan as presenting the risk of proliferation in our region. There is good reason for considering these two separately.
Taiwan

Concerns about Taiwanese development of a nuclear weapons capability have abated, although not disappeared, since it was last an issue in the 1980s. Taiwan, although not a party to the Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), has its nuclear facilities subjected to safeguards applied under an International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)/Taiwan/United States trilateral safeguards agreement. There is, however, no cause for complacency, and Australia will continue to monitor Taiwan's nuclear program closely for any indications of renewed interest in nuclear weapons development.

Because Taiwan does not have formal state to state relations with Australia or with the three nuclear powers with interests in the issue (and indeed is considered to be part of one of them-i.e., China), it is likely that there would be little scope for joint action on Taiwan by the three nuclear powers as envisaged in the Recommendation. The United States on its own, however, still has considerable influence on Taiwan.
Korean Peninsula

Concerns about the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK) are of a different order and should be more amenable to the sort of cooperative international action mentioned in the Recommendation, although success will be problematical. The persistent refusal of the DPRK, a party to the NPT, to conclude its obligatory NPT safeguards agreement with the IAEA, thereby submitting all of its peaceful nuclear activities to international inspection, is of great concern to its immediate neighbours and to all other countries in the Asian/Pacific region, including Australia.

Over the last two years, in concert with other countries strongly supportive of the NPT, including Japan and the United States, Australia has made representations to the DPRK bilaterally and through multilateral action, urging it to honour its NPT obligations.

Most recently, Australia, along with the United States, Japan, Canada and Poland, has responded to a letter from the DPRK to the President of the UN Security Council which attempted to make conclusion of its NPT safeguards agreement conditional on the removal of United States nuclear weapons from the Republic of Korea (ROK). The Australian letter rejected the DPRK's attempt to place conditions upon the fulfilment of its NPT obligations. This position was supported by a large number of NPT Parties at the meeting in late February of the IAEA Board of Governors, in which Australia holds a designated seat.

The proliferation pressure building on the Korean Peninsula must be addressed at both the global and regional levels. At the global level, we should continue to strengthen the operation of the multilateral treaty system. Australia is actively contributing to this process.

But it is primarily at the regional level that the key to a solution to proliferation on the Korean Peninsula will have to be sought, given the high level of tension between the two Koreas, and the vital security concerns of neighbouring countries and the United States. A regional layer of commitments and confidence building measures could be based upon and complement the global non-proliferation regime.

The Government sees some prospect of progress in the DPRK/ROK high-level dialogue, despite the cancellation of the last scheduled talks by the DPRK. Beyond this, in the face of continued refusal by the DPRK to meet its NPT obligations, if proliferation is to be averted it will be necessary to look beyond the symptom of the safeguards agreement to try and address the reasons behind the DPRK's unsafeguarded nuclear activities. A carefully balanced mix of incentives and disincentives related to the NPT and the strategic situation on the Korean Peninsula may be needed to induce the DPRK to abandon a nuclear weapons option. It may be, however, that only a political solution on the Korean Peninsula and outright reunification will ultimately resolve the issue.
Facilitation of Dialogue

The following points should be noted with regard to an additional role for Australia as a facilitator of dialogue. Australia already consults regularly and in depth with the United States on matters relating to nuclear proliferation, including on the Korean Peninsula. The Government also takes appropriate opportunities to regularly encourage the USSR and China to bring to bear whatever influence they can in order to persuade the DPRK to abide by its NPT undertakings. For example, at the recent nuclear consultations between Australian and Soviet officials in Moscow, the visit by a senior Soviet official to Canberra in February, and at regular disarmament talks in the latter part of last year in Beijing.

Just as Australia consults with these major powers over the proliferation pressure building on the Korean Peninsula, so too do these countries already maintain a regular dialogue with each other on this issue. There may be scope for trilateral contacts between these three countries adding weight to their existing efforts to influence the DPRK.

However, any attempt by the three to attempt to address the sources of tension on the Peninsula, and to impose a solution on the two Koreas (and Japan) without their participation, would be doomed to failure.

The Government will continue to keep Australia's interests in averting nuclear proliferation in this volatile region before these three powers, and to seek their continued vigorous engagement in the search for a regionally-tailored solution.
AUSTRALIA-USSR ECONOMIC RELATIONS
RECOMMENDATION FIVE

5.23 Recommendation Five: The Committee recommends that more effective channels of communication and a greater flow of information be established between Government assessment agencies and departments and the Australian business community. The objective should be the establishment of an active program for the regular dissemination of assessments on the USSR to important user groups within the community. The Government needs to give greater emphasis to supporting Australian businesses seeking to export by providing more responsive, high quality commercial intelligence, and by offering greater country expertise to solve specific problems that Australian exporters face in dealing with the complexities of a situation such as that in the USSR. Essentially, Government departments and agencies should assume more effectively the role of a clearing house for information on the Soviet Union. The precise nature of such a mechanism would need to be the subject of discussion between all departments and agencies involved, including the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Defence, Industry and Technology, Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, AUSTRADE, Office of National Assessments and the Defence Intelligence Organisation.
Response

Government Departments have developed regular channels to facilitate dissemination of information to the Australian business community. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) produces a range of commercially-oriented material on the USSR, including its Country Economic Brief series and the monthly publication Eurofile, to which a wide range of business and other organisations subscribe. Officers from DFAT, AUSTRADE and other Departments dealing with trade with the USSR are available to provide briefings and assist exporters, and have frequent contact with business people through such mechanisms as the Australia-USSR Business Council. AUSTRADE also disseminates commercial intelligence to Australian business through the East Europe Market Development Office based in Canberra and through the Trade Commissioners based in Moscow. This process involves not only providing information, but also spending time with companies, interpreting for them what is happening in the USSR, relating it to their own company situation and then advising them the best way to approach the market.

The Committee's recommendation nonetheless highlights the need for better coordination among Government Departments to improve the flow of Soviet economic and commercial information to the business community at a time of rapid change and uncertainty. The Government will continue to monitor and keep under review its role in this respect.

Recent initiatives by the Government to improve coordination of strategies should improve services provided to exporters to the USSR. The recent decision to implement the McKinsey report on AUSTRADE and transfer responsibility for AUSTRADE to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development from 1 September 1991 will enhance the role the Government is playing in markets where governments have a significant impact in the conduct of international trade, such as the USSR.

More generally, the Government has announced that the Ministerial Trade Strategy Group, chaired by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development and including the Ministers for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Industry Technology and Commerce, and Primary Industries and Energy, will be working with State Governments and industry organisations to develop a coordinated national trade strategy, particularly with respect to overseas trade missions and contacts with foreign governments on trade development activities.
RECOMMENDATION SIX

5.23 Recommendation Six: The Committee further recommends that the Australian Government, in collaboration with private business, seek to establish a high level joint working group, comprising both Australian and Soviet government representatives, business and academics. Such a committee should meet regularly to discuss the evolving economic situation and identify potential trade and investment projects. Representatives of USSR republics should also be included in the joint process as necessary to deal with specific issues of direct interest to Australian business in individual republics. In a period of turbulence such as that now occurring in the USSR, the Committee considers that there needs to be more direct and more frequent contact at a high level between involved organisations. Australia should take the initiative.
Response

The Government does not consider that a high level joint working group of this kind, in particular one covering such a range of interests, needs to be added to the existing framework of institutional mechanisms at this stage. The most important of those mechanisms are the Australia-USSR Mixed Commission on Trade and Economic Cooperation and the Australia-USSR Business Council. The Mixed Commission enables regular review of the bilateral trading relationship with high-level participation by Government and business representatives. The Business Council provides a framework for regular consultation between the business communities of both countries, and has frequent contact with Government. While academics are not routinely included in either body, the point is that Government and business representatives keep abreast of academic analyses of Soviet developments through economic/political seminars and conferences that are frequently held on this subject both in Australia and the Soviet Union. An additional institutional mechanism, largely consisting of the same Government and business representatives as on the existing bodies, is likely to complicate and confuse the handling of the bilateral trade relationship.

The Soviet republics are already involved to a certain extent in the Mixed Commission and other bilateral consultations. It is the Government's policy to expand and strengthen our relations with the republics, given the likely trend towards their greater autonomy in economic management, and will continue to encourage this process. Towards this end, the Government actively encourages contacts with representatives of the Soviet republics, including high level visits to Australia.
RECOMMENDATION SEVEN

5.24 It has become evident that the loosening of central control over foreign currency transactions will enable some Soviet enterprises to enter into more extensive and more imaginative arrangements with foreigners, with potential advantages for both sides. It is equally evident that these activities will carry with them a significant element of risk. From the point of view of Australia's long-term economic interests there is obvious benefit in getting a firm foothold in the Soviet market sooner, rather than later, when international competition can only become more intense. The Committee applauds the Government's initiative in offering a A$525 million line of credit for Australia's wool and wheat exports.

Recommendation Seven: The Committee recommends that similar credit arrangements be considered for other potentially significant Australian exports for the immediate future. These arrangements should not be confined to the central Soviet authorities but should also be extended to individual republics.
Response

While the Government will naturally keep its options open with regard to the possible extension of the credit facilities to the USSR, it believes it would be prudent to first gain experience in the operation of the facility currently in operation, particularly the Soviet Union's payment performance, before considering additional facilities. It is important to note that the credit facility currently in operation comprises two elements: a $125m facility for wheat, and a $400 million rollover facility on 240-day terms covering not only purchases of wool but also other commodities.

As noted above, the Government considers it important to develop relations with individual Soviet republics. However, with regard to extending credit facilities to the republics, the main difficulty is that the central Soviet authorities remain in full control of hard currency reserves. The Government could consider the participation of individual republics in the current credit facility, which would be a matter for internal consideration within the Soviet Union. Any facility negotiated directly with an individual republic would require a guarantee from the Soviet Foreign Economic Relations Bank such as already applies to the existing credit facility. However, the Government will keep this issue under consideration in the context of the developing pattern of the Soviet centre-republican relationships.
RECOMMENDATION EIGHT

5.25 The Committee agrees with the view expressed in a number of submissions that there is scope for considerable expansion in Australian export of technology and scientific expertise to the Soviet Union. This applies particularly in the agricultural and mining sectors.

Recommendation Eight: In pursuing these opportunities the Committee recommends that particular attention be given to joint venture possibilities, including with third parties, such as, for example, Korean companies.
Response

The Government supports the view that Australian companies should give consideration to joint venture possibilities in expanding economic links with the Soviet Union. A number of Australian companies have already entered into or are negotiating such arrangements. Government Departments already provide information to companies on the legal and economic conditions concerning joint ventures in the USSR. At the same time, however, it is important not to underestimate the difficulties associated with joint venture operations in the Soviet Union. Of some 2000 such ventures registered, only 10-20 per cent are effectively in operation. The difficulties essentially lie in repatriating profits overseas, obtaining reliable supplies and skilled labour, and in the vague nature of the regulations (concerning foreign participation in the local economy), often restrictively interpreted by the bureaucracy. That said, clearly the Government and Australian companies should be alert to any opportunities that might arise, particularly in the context of Soviet attempts to arrest the country's economic decline through foreign economic links.
RECOMMENDATION NINE

5.26 The Report notes the high level of controls still applied under the arrangements agreed to by the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Strategic export controls (COCOM), notwithstanding certain advances in recent times, such as the removal of the former German Democratic Republic as a proscribed country.

Recommendation Nine: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government work actively to ease the restrictions further in order to open up new trade opportunities for Australian exporters of high technology goods and services to the Soviet Union. An important opportunity to do so will be at the forthcoming meeting of COCOM in early 1991.
Response

Policy coordination and development on COCOM matters is handled through an interdepartmental committee, comprising the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Defence, Industry, Technology and Commerce (including the Australian Customs Service and the Australian Trade Commission), Primary Industries and Energy, Prime Minister and Cabinet, and Transport and Communications. The Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio has prime responsibility for Australia's participation in COCOM. The Department of Defence administers Australian export controls on dual-use (civil and military applications) technology and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy administers the controls on exports of nuclear materials and technology. These controls are enforced at the barrier by the Australian Customs Service.

The extensive coordination on policy matters is necessary to achieve the broadest possible perspective, including commercial considerations in the formulation of Australian positions on COCOM. However, the arrangements for administration of Australia's controls ensure that Australian industry is given timely advice of changes (including intended changes) to controls and that Australian controls are adjusted quickly following agreement by COCOM. For example, bulletins are sent to all known exporters alerting them to changes of the control lists. To supplement this, industry advisory groups are being set up to provide a commercial input into the development of the Australian position on list changes and to provide industry with advance information on proposed changes/liberalisation of the control lists.

In view of the profound changes in East/West relations and the consequent impact on strategic considerations, COCOM has been examining the liberalisation of controls to all proscribed countries and has recently agreed that favourable consideration will be given for the export of controlled goods to Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia.

The Department of Defence conducted a survey in 1988 to gauge the impact of foreign controls on dual use technology on Australian importers and exporters. Significant delays, particularly from the US, in granting export licences were evident. Similarly, the US tried to exercise control on the re-export from Australia of US origin goods and technology. Australian membership of COCOM has removed most of this delay and has provided Australian importers access to technology that had been previously denied to them. So long as major technology suppliers seek to restrict access to high technology, Australia sees membership of COCOM as being in its self interest.

A number of COCOM members, including Australia, have recently introduced special arrangements within their national controls eliminating the licensing requirements for most controlled goods on trade with other COCOM participants. Australia has also participated in the work to develop a new and significantly reduced COCOM list of dual-use technology which will reflect the changed West-East strategic situation. Most of the new core list items were agreed at an Executive Committee meeting held in February 1991. The COCOM High Level Meeting scheduled for May 1991 is expected to decide on the final shape of the new list and its implementation date.
RECOMMENDATION TEN

5.27 The Report notes the recent increase in the number of persons travelling between Australia and the Soviet Union. The Report also notes with some concern that in recent times there has been a decline in the level of Russian language and other studies in Australian universities. Greater person-to-person contact is, in the Committee's view, a vital ingredient in the development of a healthy and mutually beneficial relationship. In order to facilitate and encourage such a development, the Committee makes the following recommendations:

5.28 Recommendation Ten: The Committee recommends that the decline in Australian University resources made available to Russian studies be halted, and preferably reversed. One avenue would be for the representatives on the joint working groups proposed above to explore ways and means of developing, in cooperation with the private business sector, a long-term program for a steady increase in Russian studies in Australia. In addition, a student or senior scholar exchange with specific institutions in the Soviet Union, preferably both in Moscow and in the Soviet Far East, should be established.
Response

The Government agrees that it is important that a sound base of Russian language study, as well as teaching and research on the Soviet Union in other disciplines, be maintained in Australia in order to facilitate the development of the bilateral relationship, both at the official and people-to-people level. While University funding allocations to individual disciplines are principally a matter for tertiary institutions themselves to determine, the Government will seek to encourage them to maintain and, subject to demand, if possible expand resources available to Russian studies, as well as to the study of other languages of the USSR. The Government hopes that business will see the value of employing such language skills in dealing with the USSR; this will be a factor in maintaining demand for Russian studies.

The Government is currently reviewing its literacy and languages policies. A discussion paper, ``The Language of Australia: Discussion Paper on an Australian Literacy and Language Policy for the l990's'', was released in December 1990. Following extensive consultation, a literacy and languages policy paper will be released in the context of the 1991-92 Budget, covering the general issue of promotion of languages other than English. The Committee's recommendations will be taken into account in consideration of the issues involved. The professional development of language teachers is likely to be identified as a priority.

The Government has already sought to support tertiary study of the Soviet Union, providing in 1990 $100,000 to the Australian National University program of research and teaching on the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe covering a number of disciplines. This allocation was approved in the context of considering the Government's response to the historic changes taking place in Eastern Europe, and was aimed at supporting Soviet and East European area studies at an Australian university with a reputation as a leading centre in this field. The Government also notes the establishment in 1990 of the Centre for Soviet and East European Studies at the University of Melbourne, which will provide added momentum to research and teaching on the Soviet Union in Australia.

The Government agrees that a framework of institutional contacts with Soviet universities is an essential element in maintaining and developing Australian expertise on the Soviet Union and its languages in particular. To that end, it has encouraged and facilitated the establishment of such institutional ties and will continue to do so. Over the last five years these ties have expanded significantly, to an extent far beyond that reached in 1979 prior to the freezing of cultural and academic ties by the Fraser Government in response to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. Several Australian tertiary institutions have concluded institute-to-institute arrangements with Soviet counterparts, including Moscow State University, Leningrad State University, the USSR Academy of Sciences, the Pushkin Institute for Russian language study, Kiev University, and the Far East Maritime College in Vladivostok. These arrangements provide for exchanges of a number of senior scholars and students. The introduction of the Overseas Postgraduate Research Scholarship Scheme (OPRS) in 1990 has seen some 150 overseas students undertake research training in Australia at the Masters and Ph.D level each year. Currently four students from the USSR are in Australia on these scholarships. From 1992, 300 OPRS scholarships will be made available.

In addition, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade provides funding for exchanges of senior scholars and students under the bilateral Cultural Cooperation Agreement with the USSR. There is scope for a limited number of places for such exchanges under the present budget for the USSR ($110,000 in 1990-91).

The Government is pleased to note that a number of youth exchanges have been established or are under discussion, involving Australian schools and organisations such as Rotary and AFS. These should play a significant role in developing people-to-people contact as well as knowledge of the USSR and its languages.
RECOMMENDATION ELEVEN

5.29 Recommendation Eleven: The Committee recommends that members of ethnic communities in Australia with origins in the Soviet Union be encouraged to use their natural advantages, such as knowledge of language, to establish business contact with the Soviet Union and with its constituent republics. In particular, efforts should be made to remove obstacles, including any limiting regulations, and to facilitate such contacts.
Response

The Government agrees that the background and language skills of members of ethnic communities in Australia with origins in the USSR are potentially valuable assets in business dealings with the USSR. A number of Australian business people from those ethnic communities have been active in establishing business contacts with the Soviet Union. The Government is ready to encourage and facilitate the further development of such contacts. Government Departments, in particular the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, maintain close and frequent contacts with ethnic organisations (for example, the Baltic Council, the Australian Federation of Ukrainian Organisations, and the Armenian National Committee) with cultural links to the relevant Soviet Republics.

The Agreement on Human Contacts and Humanitarian Co-operation, signed in February 1990, is a particularly useful document in removing any impediments to ethnic communities being able to maintain links with Soviet republics of their origin. The Agreement will facilitate a broad range of human contacts between people in Australia and the USSR. These include family reunion visits and permanent settlement for family reunification.

The Agreement will also make it easier for religious organisations in both countries to establish and maintain contacts and for journalists to communicate personally with their sources of information, and commits both Governments to ensure rapid communication by mail and telephone between the two countries.

Both Governments, in providing for contacts, commit themselves under the Agreement not to discriminate between persons on the ground of their origin, social and property status, race, nationality, colour, sex, education, language or religion. They are also obliged not to discriminate against people seeking to have such contacts (for example with regard to employment, housing or educational privileges).
RECOMMENDATION TWELVE

5.30 Recommendation Twelve: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government draw the attention of Australian business to the possible benefits to be gained from offering management training to senior executives of their potential or existing business partners in the Soviet Union. The Soviet Union is desperately short of expertise to manage the transition to a market economy and representatives of the Soviet Union have actively sought such assistance, both in Australia, the United States and in Europe. In particular, the Australian Government should establish a program for the Soviet Union similar to the Australian Programme for Training in Eastern Europe (APTEE).
Response

The Government agrees with the Committee's comment that there is a shortage of expertise in the Soviet Union in the field of business management. The foreshadowed movement towards a market economy presents a great challenge in circumstances where knowledge of business, commercial and trading practices is almost non-existent. The absence of this skill base is bound to hamper, or at worst make unachievable, economic restructuring, as well as make more difficult the development of mutually beneficial commercial relations with the West.

The Government is considering the question of establishing a program of management and business training for the Soviet Union similar to APTEE. This issue will be considered in the light of Australia's regional aid priorities and current budgetary constraints, taking into account the recommendations of international funding institutions and the experience gained in relation to APTEE. While Australia's capacity to contribute to efforts to address this problem is limited by our size and budgetary constraints, provision of management training in Australia should be of advantage to Australian companies in the future. Some companies have already initiated programs in this area, and one Australian company has concluded an agreement to train Soviet managers. Their experience, as well as the experience of overseas countries and of Government programs such as APTEE, will help other Australian firms to assess for themselves the possible benefits of introducing similar management training programs.
RECOMMENDATION THIRTEEN

5.31 Recommendation Thirteen: The Committee recommends that Australia's aviation authorities and Qantas should take fully into account the potential trade and tourism benefits that would flow from expanding further the present agreement allowing Aeroflot to operate charter flights and to establish regular services together with reciprocal opportunities for Qantas in the Soviet Union.
Response

The Government agrees that potential trade and tourism benefits should be taken fully into account in considering the establishment of regular air services with the USSR. The Soviet Government has recently proposed that Australia and the USSR conclude an air services agreement. This question is currently under consideration by the Government.
RECOMMENDATION FOURTEEN
5.32 The Report notes the range of bilateral agreements signed by Australia and the Soviet Union at the time of Prime Minister Ryzhkov's visit in early 1990.

Recommendation Fourteen: The committee recommends that there should be a sustained effort to implement those agreements and not allow them quietly to gather dust. In particular, scientific exchanges in the area of monitoring major environmental changes such as ozone depletion and the greenhouse effect should be encouraged.
Response

The Government endorses the Committee's view that there should be a sustained effort to implement the bilateral agreements signed at the time of Prime Minister Ryzhkov's visit. It can report that implementation of the agreements in their first year of operation has, by and large, been satisfactory.

Three of the agreements-on Human Contacts, Consular Relations, and the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy-were framework documents, establishing the principles according to which the two countries would conduct themselves in particular areas of bilateral relations, rather than agreements requiring implementation in the form of a program of activities. The first bilateral talks on implementation of the Human Contacts Agreement were held in Moscow in January 1991.
