The Australian delegation was able to raise a number of issues of concern to the Government and undertake a review of the Agreement with the Soviet side in a constructive and business-like atmosphere.

The Agreement on Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy was brought into force by means of an Exchange of Notes between the Australian and Soviet Governments on 24 December 1990. Administrative arrangements for implementation of the Agreement were negotiated during 1990 and signed on the same date. The first bilateral consultations on nuclear issues under the Agreement were held in Moscow in March 1991. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) has concluded a Memorandum of Understanding with the USSR Academy of Sciences in September 1990 to promote collaboration in radioactive waste management technology.

Three other Agreements-on Fisheries, Commodities and the Environment-were also signed during Premier Ryzhkov's visit. Some progress has been achieved in the implementation of the Fisheries Agreement. Soviet fisheries agencies have been negotiating a possible joint venture agreement on feasibility fishing in Australian waters. The Government has agreed to the Soviet Government's request to open a fisheries representative office in Melbourne, in accordance with the Agreement.

The Commodities Agreement has been overtaken to a large extent by Soviet foreign exchange difficulties since mid-l990, which has severely hampered its capacity to fulfil existing contracts, let alone conclude new ones. The focus of the Government's trade relations activity towards the USSR has been to ensure that debts owed by Soviet organisations to Australian exporters are paid and to encourage them to maintain the level of exports to the USSR to the maximum extent possible. Unavoidably, Soviet buyers have not been able to meet some of the indicative quantities for purchases of commodities set out under the agreement, but major sales of wheat and barley have taken place. The Government hopes that new credit facilities provided to the Soviet Union will facilitate a return to former levels of trade, but given the USSR's continuing economic problems, assesses this as unlikely in the foreseeable future.

No collaborative activity has yet commenced under the Environmental Co-operation Agreement, as a result of budgetary restraints both in Australia and the Soviet Union. The Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is examining ways of obtaining funding to advance cooperation under the Agreement. The Government agrees that scientific exchanges in the area of monitoring major environmental changes would be of substantial value to both countries.
MULTILATERAL ECONOMIC
COOPERATION
RECOMMENDATION FIFTEEN

5.35 The Committee does not expect to see a rapid, or complete, transition from a command to a market economy in the Soviet Union. On balance, and notwithstanding some of the reservations noted previously, it is in Australia's interests to see a transition which boosts activity in the USSR succeed. It is equally in Australia's interests to encourage economic interdependence between the Soviet Union and the Asia-Pacific region, and to link the Soviet Union into regional efforts to devise mutually beneficial ways and means to encourage the overall growth of trade and economic development in the region.

Recommendation Fifteen: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government look at a possible mechanism for involving the USSR in the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) process. At a minimum it should ensure that the USSR is kept fully informed on the APEC progress. Consideration might, in the first instance, be given to some form of observer or other partial membership status for the USSR.
Response

The Australian Government regards the participation of the USSR in APEC as desirable and inevitable in the long term. To this end, the Government has encouraged the USSR to develop its economic links with the region, and has undertaken to keep the USSR informed of developments within APEC.

However, Soviet participation is not considered feasible in the immediate future. APEC Ministers agreed in 1989 that further applications for participation should be assessed in the light of the strength of economic linkages with the region, and that decisions should be made by consensus. The USSR's economic links with the region are currently not developed to an extent which would assure it of entry into APEC.

The question of wider participation is being addressed within APEC; the present focus is on participation for the PRC, Taiwan and Hong Kong, three economies which clearly form part of the region's economy. Once this is resolved, it will be possible to consider whether there is a consensus for further expansion, including economies such as the USSR and Mexico which are of growing importance to the region.

There is no provision for a country being given observer or associate status in APEC. The three entities that have observer status are regional organisations (ASEAN, PECC and the South Pacific Forum). The Australian Government is of the view that all economies which become part of the APEC process should do so as full participants.

The Australian Government supports the USSR's application to join the Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference (PECC). As noted in the Committee's report, the USSR has already formed a Committee for Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation, one of the prerequisites for PECC membership. In 1990 the USSR lodged a formal membership application, which was considered by the PECC Standing committee in September 1990 (along with seven other applications). Despite Australian support, some other PECC members still have reservations about Soviet membership, and no consensus on the Soviet application was reached. The Government considers that it is probably only a matter of time before the USSR joins PECC.
FOOD CRISIS
RECOMMENDATION SIXTEEN

5.36 Finally, it is Committee's view that the reform process in the USSR is to be seen as a positive development, which should be supported. The most pressing and immediate need is likely to be for food supplies in the coming months.

Recommendation Sixteen: The Committee recommends that particular attention be given to devising effective means for Australia to contribute to international efforts to provide food during this critical period. In line with the approach being considered by Germany and Canada, such assistance should not be a hand-out but a commercial transaction in the form of favourable terms of credit. At the same time, it should be made clear to the Soviet Government that the use of force, including the imposition of economic blockades, in dealing with the wish of some of the republics for greater autonomy is not acceptable.
Response

Under the credit facility the Government has extended to the Soviet Union, the latter is able to purchase food supplies from Australia. The Government also considered the question of providing direct food aid to the Soviet Union in view of the food shortages in the country. It decided that, for a number of reasons, it was impractical to do so, given our competing regional aid priorities, current budgetary constraints, and complications involved in both sending such aid and assuring its effective distribution. Moreover, the shortages appear to have arisen primarily from the breakdown of the central distribution system and other deep-seated infrastructural factors, rather than from production shortfalls, and the experience of countries extending direct food aid to the USSR has demonstrated the difficulty of distributing it to those actually in need. The Government also took into consideration the fact that Australian exporters were negotiating commercial food purchases by the Soviet Union. The fact that significant sales were ultimately made vindicated the Government's view in taking the interests of Australian companies into consideration.

The Government is nonetheless taking practical measures to assist the Soviet Union in its present time of difficulty. As noted above, the Government has made available credit facilities worth $525 million to support Australia/USSR commodity trade. Following an initiative from the Prime Minister, the Government has also agreed to organise an Australian business advisory mission to the USSR to look at problems in the areas of food storage, processing and distribution.

The Government's efforts to broaden the scope of assistance to the USSR will take into account developments in the USSR, as the Committee suggests. In developing the bilateral relationship, Australia wishes to encourage the Soviet Union to stay on the course of both political and economic reform. In forthrightly condemning the use of force by Soviet authorities in the Baltic States in January 1991, the Government made clear that the use of such force was not only unacceptable, but that repeated use of force in this way can not but affect the course of cooperation between the Soviet Union and Western countries such as Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I also take note of the response from the Government, presented by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), to the report of the Committee entitled Perestroika: Implications for Australia-USSR Relations. The Committee was empowered by the Senate to begin its investigation on 7 September 1989 when the following terms of reference were laid down for the Committee to inquire into and report on:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) the implications for Australia of economic and political reform in the Soviet Union, with special reference to strategic relationships in the Asia-Pacific region;
and
(b) the opportunities for expanded Australian trade with the Soviet Union, particularly the Soviet Far East and Siberia.

I should say at the outset that the focus of this inquiry, although on perestroika generally and its implications for Australia, was very much on the eastern regions of the Soviet Union, those in the Pacific region, the Soviet far east and Siberia. The Minister's response is available today and no doubt members of the Committee will study that response at some considerable length. It is certainly another edition to a very welcome and useful debate that has been occurring in this Parliament on the reforms in the Soviet Union and on what perestroika means for Australia, both in a security sense and also on the trade and economic front.

This particular report was tabled in this place on 21 December last. As I pointed out, the inquiry began in 1989. In regard to the overall thrust of the Minister's response, I note that he, on behalf of the Government, welcomes the report and points out:
There is much in the Report with which the Government can readily agree.

In regard to recommendation 1 of the report which the Senate Standing Committee put forward as a need for a review at Cabinet level in this country of the current security position in the region in the wake of the various reforms in the Soviet Union under the banner of perestroika, the Minister has pointed out that the Government will not be accepting this particular recommendation and points out that there is a classified document in the hands of the Government entitled Australia's Strategic Planning in the 1990s which assesses the current security position in this country in regard to the various changes that have been occurring in the region. Of course, as a backbencher, I am in no position to comment on that particular document.

I note that on page 9 of the Minister's response he points out that, in both the current and prospective circumstances, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is not a direct military threat to Australia. That is a very significant point.

On the question of trade, for example, the Committee recommended the extension of extra trade credits to the Soviet Union to allow it to trade its way through its present difficult economic circumstances and to enable it to finance the further importation of Australian products, mainly commodities. The Minister has said that the Government intends to proceed cautiously on this particular recommendation. It will not extend further trade credits to the Soviet Union at this stage but, rather, it wishes to monitor the current performance of the Soviet Union, particularly the present existing credit facility of $525m, mainly for wool and wheat purchases.

Most importantly, the Minister has pointed out that the Government wishes to monitor the capacity of the Soviet Union to pay for the commodities it has purchased from Australia. The Committee also put forward the view that not only should we examine extra trade credits with the central Government in the Soviet Union but also we should open up the question of trade credits to the various constituent republics of the Soviet Union. The Minister suggested that Australia monitor the capacity of those countries to pay before extending credits to them.

Recommendation 10 in the report is about the teaching of Russian studies and Russian languages in Australian universities and other tertiary institutions. The Committee identified that the resources available for teaching Russian languages were in decline in our universities despite the momentous changes occurring in the Soviet Union and that country's apparent willingness to play a more constructive role in the world. Our ability to study the Soviet Union and the implications of its changes in policies were perhaps being constrained by a definite decline in the availability of resources at the tertiary education level. The Committee called on the Government to look at measures to halt the decline in resources and preferably to reverse that decline if possible.

I note that on page 39 of the Minister's response he puts forward the Government's view that it will seek to encourage universities to maintain resources and, subject to demand, if possible expand resources to Russian studies units in Australian universities as well as resources for the study of other languages in the USSR apart from Russian.

Recommendation 12 put forward by the Committee in its report brought down last December was that there should be a specific business management and economic training scheme for people working in the embryonic business and commercial sectors in the Soviet Union. The Committee pointed out that there is currently in existence a scheme called the Australian program for training in eastern Europe (APTEE). We said that it could be worth while, given the momentous changes in the Soviet Union and given that that country has been without an entrepreneurial class for over 70 years now, whereas eastern Europe already has a scheme and has not had an entrepreneurial class for some 40 years. So there is quite a difference in the time during which the Soviet Union has lacked economic managers and planners in a Western sense compared with that lack in the eastern European countries.

In response to recommendation 12, the Minister endorses the need for Australia to supply technical economic assistance to the Soviet Union. Presumably that would include the Government looking at Australia's ability to provide some management training for those in the economic and commercial sectors in the Soviet Union. The Minister is now considering extending a scheme such as APTEE to the Soviet Union.

With those remarks, on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I note the Minister's response. I shall pore over the specifics of the Government's response to this important report. I shall look at the details as to how we can implement some of the proposals in the future. I commend both the report and the Minister's response to the Senate as being very useful in continuing the debate on what is happening in the Soviet Union, on the internal dynamics of that country and, most importantly, what that means for the Pacific rim of that country. That area, of course, was the focus of our terms of reference-Siberia and the Soviet Far East. The debate has also been very worthwhile on the implications of the changes in the Soviet Union for Australia's security in this region and the implications for Australian trade with Siberia and the Soviet Far East.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and reflecting the views of Opposition senators, I welcome the Government's response tabled today on the Committee's report entitled Perestroika: Implications for Australia-USSR Relations. That report gained the unanimous support of eight members of this chamber: four from the Government, three from the Liberal Party on behalf of the Opposition and one from the Australian Democrats. It is a three-party report based upon many submissions and the Committee's discussion and evaluation of all the submissions we have had. It is a unanimous report. It is forward looking and it could never be described as conservative. It is cautious but it delivered 16 recommendations to the Australian Government, urging specific actions that would, we believe, enhance Australia's opportunities in relation to the post- perestroika Soviet Union and in matters of very great importance to this nation-assessments of the security interests of Australia in the Asia-Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, the Committee addressed two terms of reference: first, the implications of perestroika policies, restructuring policies-the reforms over recent years in the Soviet Union and the implications of these changes for Australia's strategic relationships in the Asia-Pacific region; and, secondly, the implications for expanded opportunities for Australian trade with the Soviet Union, particularly the Soviet Far East and Siberia.

I do not have the same swelling optimism as the Committee Chairman, Senator Maguire-a Government member-in welcoming entirely the response of his own Government to this report. I know the Chairman has just chided the Government on a few matters, on which we urged action whereas the Government is only going part of the way. However, there is an aspect of the Government's response to the report, not so much of complacency but of not having the same sense urgency, the same alertness, to take up opportunities that the Committee has spelled out in the report and in our recommendations.

The Government's response is somewhat defensive. It is saying, `We welcome the Committee's report and we are doing most of that anyway'. I do not see it so much as complacency as what I would call `bureaucratspeak'; that is, that a hardworking Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and even a hardworking Minister, will profess that they have something to learn from a Senate committee but not a huge amount, and that they are already doing a great deal.

I acknowledge that the Department is increasingly alert but we have made direct criticisms of both the Department's and the Government's record: for example, on information flow; the failure to announce new dialogue with the Soviet Union on security matters in the Asia-Pacific region; and the lack of demonstration that the agreements signed when Prime Minister Ryzhkov was in Australia are actually achieving some tangible results. We could go on.

Senator Maguire referred to the need to review the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Strategic Export Controls arrangements, which are effectively trade restrictions, shared by a number of allied countries and affecting the Soviet Union-that is, restrictions about some of our technical knowledge not being as readily passed to non-COCOM countries as they are to our immediate allies and friends. We are asking for that to be reviewed in order to ease the restrictions but, of course, none of us want to see any weakening of the genuine security interests of Australia or of our allies. The Government's response to that is, `We will be proceeding cautiously'.

A COCOM meeting was held in February of this year and there is to be another meeting next month, in May. The Government may profess at that time that they are reviewing COCOM, but the words we have in the Government's response here today do not live up to the kind of urgency that the Senate Committee expressed. I notice that recommendations eight, nine, 10, 11 and 14 are largely agreed; that is about half of the 16 recommendations. But there are seven or eight recommendations where the Government does not so much disagree but says either `We are doing it already to the extent we think is appropriate' or `Caution is the order of the day. We note the light on the hill that the Senate Committee has put for these couple of years but we will proceed to it in our own judgment'. I am therefore not prepared to give a glowing congratulation to the Government for this report. I would rather ask the Minister, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade-and, to some extent, the Department of Defence in regard to some of the security matters-to think again and give some edge to their professed acceptance of the Committee's report.

A number of the recommendations of our inquiry actually address 1991. They address the enormous change presently going on, although we are now going through a period of chaos before we settle down, we hope, to steady progress in economic development and a successful transition to the post-perestroika Soviet Union. There is an opportunity for Australia to take up the 16 recommendations of the Committee with much more urgency than the Government has shown in its response today and to address, with the same urgency that the Committee has set out, the opportunities that we believe will help in the relationship between Australia and the Soviet Union.
There are two matters that I wish to refer to. Our first recommendation is referred to on page 9 of the response where the Government states:
The Government does not believe, however, that it is appropriate at this point to engage in a strategic review by Cabinet as recommended by the Committee.

That is typical of the response of the Government to our recommendations to which we have got an expression of welcome but not a profession of action. I ask the Government to think that through again. We do not want to see the Cabinet address only the relationship between Australia and the Soviet Union. We are saying there have been such changes, which I am sure the Department is up to date with, affecting the Asia-Pacific region that in these months of 1991 there ought to be a review introduced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade addressing that region, which includes the findings of this Senate committee report and the reassessment of Australia's relations with the Soviet Union.

Do not let us be so conservative that we miss opportunities. Do not let us be so slow to act that we do not help achieve goals for Australia's benefit and, indeed, for what we would assess to be the Soviet Union's benefit. For example, the Government response echoes our descriptions of the emergence of embryonic democratic institutions in the country. It also echoes the Committee's highlighting of both the disarmament achievements in the Soviet Union and the complete revolution in its foreign policy-as we have seen demonstrated in the release of eastern Europe and the flourishing of democracy in so many States there, however difficult the transition may also be for them. There have been massive changes which ought to be taken into account in a review by Cabinet-not just by the Minister-so that all departments of government are working to a 1991 strategic assessment of Australia's relationship with the Soviet Union.

Our final recommendation is about food aid. We did not say that it should be a hand-out; we said that it should be by extended credit to ensure the existence of food and consumer goods to meet the present desperate needs of the Soviet Union. The Northern Hemisphere is just emerging from its winter-the Soviet Union's great discontent over many decades now. The transition from the central socialist economy to a market oriented economy was disruptive and heading for chaos. Grave concerns were expressed that there would be a desperate shortage of food and that this would put in jeopardy the moves to democracy that we had welcomed. So the Committee wants to ensure that the Cabinet addresses the opportunities that exist.

The other area to which I want to refer to is also contained within the introductory pages on page 10. The Minister and the Department have set up something of an Aunt Sally by referring to an institution for regional security in the Asia- Pacific region. That was never mentioned in the Committee report. We did not call for an institution to be set up; we called for dialogue. Let the Senate bear that in mind when I read this paragraph:

The development of any sort of comprehensive regional security institution is not a goal of our policy. It is too early to say what role such an institution might play, or what form it might take. We therefore believe that our efforts should be directed to developing and expanding the region's network of bilateral and multilateral security dialogues.

I say to the Minister and to the Government: it is dialogue that we call for, not an institution. To demonstrate this point, I refer to the relevant words in the first three or four recommendations of the Committee. Recommendation two on page 94 of the Committee report contains these words:

The Committee recommends that, at the same time the Australian Government should continue to press for the establishment of regular processes of multilateral dialogue on security issues for the whole region.
In recommendation 3 we note that:
. . . there is no comprehensive multi-lateral discussion of arms control in the region similar to that which has occurred in Europe.

We want to see that discussion involving the Soviet Union in the Asia-Pacific region, not only in Europe. In recommendation 4 we talk about the risk of nuclear proliferation. Two areas are specifically highlighted-North Korea and Taiwan. We want to guard against that so we ask in the context of these pages that there be a review to see what initiatives Australia could support in order to inhibit, and indeed prevent, the acquisition of nuclear weapons in the Korean Peninsula or in Taiwan.

There is no call for an institution. This Aunt Sally is referred to because the Minister last year was calling for an institution and he has been caught out. He has been directly criticised for that proposal by the Opposition. Last week, Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, again specifically chided the Minister for wanting to develop a conference on security and cooperation in Asia, a so-called CSCA, that the Minister had proposed last year, to parallel a quite successful new development in Europe called the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, or CSCE. It was the Minister's initiative that there be such an institution. Happily last week the Minister responded to the Opposition's chidings and is now talking about dialogue. We have been saying to him for six months that he should be promoting dialogue about security and cooperation in this region and not setting up some new institution like the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation or anything that involves bricks and mortar. We do see a regular process that can have more concrete expression in economic matters-that is Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation-but we want to see a dialogue in this region.

To cap it all off, last week a direct letter was sent from the Secretary of State in the United States to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade agreeing with the criticism of this Opposition, which said that the United States did not support any CSCA that would be in any way like the CSCE. He pointed out that the Asia-Pacific region had unique characteristics that were not in any direct parallel with the situation in Europe. I am very happy to see that in this Government response the Minister has adopted the position that is set out in the paragraph I read at page 10, but it is his own Aunt Sally that he is answering and not the Committee's report.

I conclude my remarks by coming back to the very first paragraph of the Committee report. It is expressed in dramatic terms because not only the Government but also many institutions in Australia-businesses and academics-should come to terms with the post-1989 Soviet Union. I quote:

The `Marxist-Leninist' political system in the USSR, a system of all-embracing political and economic dictatorship involving severe repression and cruelty, has now been acknowledged by the Soviet leadership as an historic failure. . . . The failure is historic in two senses. First, the allegedly utopian economic system, held up for seventy years as the only salvation for humanity and forced on many nations, has now surrendered or lost the world-wide potency that once threatened many countries with subversion or war. Second, the social system that produced dramatic advances in economic potential within the USSR in the 1930s destroyed many of the country's finest people and has proven ultimately to have directed the Soviet economy and culture into a dead end street.

When we fully grasp that the Soviet Union has rejected so much of its post-1917 past in these recent years-the years that we are describing with the concept of perestroika-we have to take stock in Australia and be prepared to face a new reality. Firstly, we have to ask what Australia's advantage will be in terms of the new opportunities from that much more approachable Soviet Union, particularly in the years ahead and not in the present transitional chaos. Secondly, given the enormous changes in foreign policy in the Soviet Union to make it a more normal nation-the breakdown of the last imperialist in the world-we must reassess strategic matters that affect Australia and this region. Finally, taking the evaluation of these changes into account requires more than just the Government welcoming the Committee's inquiry and appearing to go along with half the recommendations while making more noises about some of the others. There needs to be more urgency and action and a more direct positive response to the very considered recommendations that the Senate Committee has brought forward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to include the Australian Democrats in the response to the response of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) on this report. I was only a very new member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade when we started writing up the report, Perestroika: Implications for Australia-USSR Relations, so I did not have much to do with the first part of its formation. Nevertheless, I found it quite fascinating. One of the most interesting points is reflected in the Minister's response when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . these recommendations must be considered in the light of changes that have taken place in the USSR since the Committee delivered its findings, which have raised concerns about the direction of the Soviet reform process.

The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) certainly has changed an awful lot since we got that report together. It is also interesting that, in his response, the Minister mentions that the resignation of Eduard Shevardnadze occurred on the same day that the report was tabled. We thought that was quite appropriate. Events were occurring at an enormous speed at that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not appropriate.

—Perhaps not appropriate. Even though I have only been a member of that Committee since August last year, I found its area of inquiry to be of tremendous interest. The discussions I was part of were very constructive, given those developments which have taken place in the Soviet Union over recent years. Clearly the Committee's terms of reference were drawn up at a time of enormous historic change in the Soviet Union and this made participation in those deliberations all the more fascinating.

SPEECH.PARA: Over a short period of only a few years perestroika, which began as an attempt to make socialism more efficient and more humane, has become an attempt to change the Soviet Union into a multi-party democracy and into a free market economy. It is obvious that enormous risks are involved in such a process of transforming it into a liberal democratic society. It was also apparent that there are strong implications for Australia-Soviet relations in that the relationship between our two countries would be affected by the process of perestroika.

Many of the submissions received by the Committee in the original report suggested that the transformation process of perestroika in the Soviet Union has been so vast that virtually no part of international relations has been left unaffected by that change. Most of all, it was quite apparent to the Committee that today the Soviet Union is facing problems of enormous magnitude. I think that is also quite apparent to the Minister in what I have read of his response. We found that these were not just of an economic nature but also that there were ethnic and cultural problems.

As to human rights-immediately post-perestroika hundreds of prisoners of conscience were released and detention for political crimes was made more open and was cut down quite considerably. Capital punishment is now an item on the agenda. A list of the number of executions carried out in the USSR has just been published. This is the first time that has happened. That is a step in the right direction although that list is very long and the number of executions has to be cut down.

The excessive use of force in protest movements is a real problem. In particular, it must be accepted by the USSR that the goodwill of the Western world will depend on such things as whether the political situation in the Baltic republics improves. A repetition of events, such as the vicious crack down in Lithuania, will clearly do enormous damage to East-West relations and attempts to improve those relations. A continuation of existing Soviet policy, which involves the repression of the wishes of the Baltic peoples and of their human rights, will need to be taken into account when the Western world is addressing ways of increasing economic assistance or aid to the Soviet Union.

It is not only the Baltics. Earlier this year the Ukrainian people's deputy, Levko Lukianenko, visited Australia. Along with several other Federal and State members of parliament, I met him. On 4 April, I received a press release which stated:

On March 26, the Presidium of the Communist-dominated Ukrainian SSR Supreme Soviet voted in favour of suspending the immunity from criminal proceedings of several national-democratic opposition people's deputies . . .

Among the MP's now threatened are top Ukrainian Republican Party leaders, Levko Lukianenko and Oles Shevchenko, both of whom participated in an ``unsanctioned'' Kiev public demonstration in defence of Ukraine's new political prisoners on February 9.

When I met Levko Lukianenko he did predict that this could happen to him. He was quite willing to go back to the USSR and to take his chances. I hope that it does not happen. I do not believe it has happened yet. This is an opportunity to urge the USSR not to take such drastic measures when it is trying to stop people talking about change and reform and improving life in the Soviet Union.

I have not had an awful lot of time to look at this report so I have not gone through a great deal of the things that the Minister has said. As a member of the Committee, I would like to put on record my appreciation and my thanks to those involved in producing the original report and, in particular, Senator Maguire, who is a very good and reasonable Chairman; Senator Teague, who is a most thoughtful and sensible Deputy Chairman; and Ilze Svenne, the current Committee Secretary, who joined the Committee at about the time when I did. I have found her to be a very sensible, very good and very reasonable person and I am sure she will do as good a job on future reports as she has done on this one.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Deaths of Perry Daniel Noble, Richard Frank (Charlie) Hyde and David Mark Koowootha

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I have chosen to speak on the Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody relating to the deaths of Perry Daniel Noble, Richard Frank Hyde and David Mark Koowootha because it deals with an area in the State that I represent. These three deaths occurred at Yarrabah. Yarrabah is an Aboriginal community near Cairns in north Queensland. It grew out of an Anglican mission founded in 1882. Missionary rule there was all pervasive and succeeded in bringing about the demise of traditional cultural practices and the institutionalisation of the population at an early stage. The State facilitated the process and reinforced it upon assuming control of Yarrabah in 1960.

Yarrabah was rocked by events in late 1986 and early 1987 which brought home the extent of the challenge of bringing together the diverse peoples that had been concentrated in Yarrabah. Three men, two of them barely adults, hanged themselves within 10 weeks of each other while incarcerated alone in the cells of the dilapidated Yarrabah watch-house. All of them had been locked up on account of drunkenness and disruptive behaviour, two at the behest of family members. Each had his life tragically cut short in a moment of crisis when, left alone with his anguish and feelings of rejection, he was driven to a desperate expression of pain. The report concludes that whether any of these men ultimately intended to bring about his death is a judgment that is impossible to make.

The first man, Perry Daniel Noble, aged 20, was arrested by Aboriginal police on 4 December 1986 for being drunk and creating a disturbance at the Yarrabah Aboriginal court. Noble would not have been imprisoned that day had he not contested one of the charges against him in a loud and forceful manner. At the watch-house Noble was isolated from other prisoners in the depressing environment of a small concrete cell furnished with a toilet pedestal, mattress and bedding. After the police left, and within the hearing of other prisoners, he threatened to hang himself but his threats were taken lightly. He then asked for a sheet so that he could sleep, and an hour later was discovered hanging by this sheet on the bars of his cell window. As a result of the unavailability of watch-house keys to unlock his cell, there was as delay of about five minutes before he was rescued.

Two weeks later, 42 year-old Richard Frank Hyde, known as Charlie, became involved in an argument at his mother's house, while intoxicated with methylated spirits, after a night of heavy drinking. His mother hailed a passing police patrol and Hyde was arrested by Aboriginal police at her request. He was driven to the watch-house and locked alone in a cell. Less than half an hour later, another prisoner saw him hanging by a vinyl mattress cover tied to a bar of the cell window. No police were present at either the watch-house or the police station opposite who could be alerted.

The report points out there had been no attempt to remedy the problem of exposed cell window bars following the first death, that of Perry Noble. Action was finally taken after Charlie Hyde lost his life, and wire mesh screens were erected over each window in the three cells. However, poor workmanship rendered at least one of these screens ineffective and resulted in the death of the third Aboriginal man. Each of the deaths raises serious questions regarding the adequacy of custodial facilities and practices during this period. The absence of appropriate management strategies for drunken prisoners, including the lack of a system for watch-house surveillance, is highlighted.

The report also addresses the matters of major social changes at Yarrabah and the need for caution in drawing conclusions about the concept of suicide in respect of these three cases. It also points out that the possible significance of Aboriginal notions of collective responsibility over individual autonomy in explaining these events and their actions is not quantifiable, nor is the potential spiritual dimension to these events. I think that this is an excellent report and I particularly commend its final paragraph which states:

The legacy of one and a half centuries of enforced submissiveness, dependence and de-valued identity is not easily redressed. However, Yarrabah is a strong community and, with time and resources, very capable of managing its own affairs so as to be in a position to address some of the issues highlighted by these tragic deaths.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I speak to this report from an electorate perspective. As a senator for the Northern Territory, I am very pleased to note that the Commonwealth Grants Commission, as has always been the case in respect of its reports that address the various relativities between the States and Territories, can be relied upon for its professionalism and for the extreme care and diligence that it has always taken in putting together these reports.

From the perspective of the Northern Territory, I note that the large and widening disabilities that are faced by the Northern Territory are again acknowledged in the report. The report, which consists of two volumes, is very comprehensive and the tables, annexes and additional evidence that have been put forward cover many factors.

With regard to the Northern Territory, the factors of distance, remoteness, transport and the special needs of Aboriginal people are properly acknowledged and given due weight in respect of relativities. The challenge extended by this report will be addressed in May by the Premiers at the Special Premiers Conference which is reviewing so many areas to do with Commonwealth and State functions.

We must recognise that areas such as the Northern Territory, north-west Western Australia and north Queensland are still exposed to macro-economic policies of the Commonwealth which impact on them in a way which is not reflected in the more populous States and the more closely populated urban areas in other parts of Australia.

So it is important that the Commonwealth Grants Commission recognises very carefully all of these issues and disabilities. DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fifth report of 1991 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 6 of 1991, dated 17 April 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present two discussion papers entitled Cost of Legal Services and Litigation: Introduction to the Issues and Lawyers' Fees prepared by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs relating to the Committee's cost of justice inquiry. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

As honourable senators are aware, the Committee currently has before it a wide-ranging inquiry into the cost of legal services and litigation in Australia today. The inquiry has become known as the inquiry into the cost of justice. Since the matter was referred to the Committee, the Committee has received more than 200 submissions and almost as many expressions of interest and concern, and has conducted a series of public hearings and private meetings in most of the capital cities.

To assist it to formulate its final recommendations, the Committee has decided to publish a series of discussion papers, each of which will deal with a particular aspect of the inquiry. The first two of these-Cost of Legal Services and Litigation: Introduction to the Issues, which is discussion paper No. 1, and Lawyers' Fees, which is discussion paper No. 2-I have tabled today for the information of honourable senators. These papers do not set out the final views of the Committee. They have been prepared to raise issues and to elicit more detail where that is required.
