PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator BOLKUS

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill gives effect to a government decision announced last August to introduce a new superannuation scheme for Australia's regular Defence Force personnel. The Scheme, to be known as the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme (MSBS), is intended to take effect from 1 October 1991.

The scheme was recommended in the report of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme Review Committee under the chairmanship of Sir William Cole, a former Secretary to the Department of Defence. The report was tabled in the Senate last year.

The MSBS has been designed to comply with the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987, which sets out the government's guidelines on the structure and operations of superannuation funds. The scheme also finalises arrangements for the treatment of the three per cent productivity benefit, which has been paid in respect of members of the Defence Force since 1988.
In compliance with the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act, provision is made for the scheme to be governed by a trust deed and be administered by a board of trustees.

An important feature of the MSBS is that it provides equitable treatment for members of the Defence Force who serve for less than 20 years. Under the present Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) Scheme, these members receive only a refund of their contributions when they leave the Defence Force. They receive no interest on their contributions and no employer benefit except the three per cent productivity benefit. This is contrary to community standards. Under the MSBS, members will have returned to them not just their contributions but also whatever these contributions earn in the MSBS investment fund, and will accrue an entitlement to a substantial employer benefit in addition to the three per cent benefit.
The MSBS will have the following features:

a. Contributions at a rate elected by the member, in the range of 5 to 10 per cent of salary. Contributions will be invested in a fund and returned to members with earnings when they leave the Defence Force.

b. An employer benefit which will provide a full range of options, that is, lump sum payments, pensions calculated at a rate more generous than that available in the commercial annuities market, or a combination of both. The three per cent productivity benefit will be part of this. The total employer benefit must be preserved until age 55 or later retirement from the Defence Force except in special cases.
c. Invalidity benefits for those members retired from the Defence Force on medical grounds with a disability which appreciably affects the person's civil employment.
d. Reversionary benefits for spouses and children of deceased members or deceased pensioners.
e. An appeals system for persons dissatisfied with decisions of the Board of Trustees or its delegates.

The occupational superannuation standards prevent the inclusion in the MSBS of the benefits structure of the DFRDB Scheme which allows members to receive a life-indexed pension, part of which can be commuted to a lump sum, on resignation at any age provided they have served for 20 years. The existence of this benefit has encouraged many members to serve to the 20-year point who might otherwise have resigned earlier. Its necessary omission from the MSBS, combined with the availability of a lump sum refund of members' contributions, with earnings, on resignation will lessen the incentive for members to serve to the 20-year point and thus has the potential to increase the premature loss of personnel.

To offset this, the Bill provides a retention benefit payable to certain members who complete 15 years continuous full time service and undertake to serve for another 5 years. The benefit is equal to one year's salary and is taxable as income. Conditions attaching to payment of the benefit are set out in the Bill. The benefit will be administered by the Department of Defence, not by the trustees of the MSBS.

Persons joining the regular Defence Force on or after 1 October 1991 will automatically join the MSBS. Members who are contributors to the DFRDB scheme on that date will have the option of remaining in that scheme or joining the MSBS. Membership of the MSBS will also be available to reservists who render continuous full time service for periods of or exceeding 3 months, and to reservists who render continuous full time service for less than 3 months with a unit of the Defence Force allotted for duty in an operational area.

Members will have until the end of September 1992 to decide whether to join the MSBS unless they retire or resign earlier, in which case an earlier decision will have to be made. Each member will be provided with the information necessary to enable him or her to make a considered choice and individual counselling will be available.
Permanent part-time service

The report of the review committee included a proposal for inclusion in the new scheme of provisions which would be appropriate for permanent part-time service if this were to be introduced for the regular Defence Force. However, the present legislation governing the rendering of service by members of the Defence Force makes no provision for the rendering of permanent part-time service and, until it does, it would not be appropriate to make provision in MSBS. If permanent part-time service is introduced changes will be required to a number of Acts and the necessary changes to MSBS would be included.
FINANCIAL IMPACT
The introduction of MSBS has a number of financial impacts resulting from:
a. The funding of MSBS member contributions.
b. The funding of the 3 per cent productivity benefit for MSBS members.
c. The provision of a retention benefit to members of the requisite rank who have completed 15 years service.
d. The credit of notional interest to the DFRDB contributions of members transferring to the MSBS.
e. Increased administrative costs during the MSBS implementation period including the provision of advice to members on their transfer options.
f. The change in the form of the primary superannuation benefit from a pension in the DFRDB scheme to a lump sum in the MSBS.
g. The deferral of payment of the MSBS employer-financed superannuation benefit until members reach 55 years of age in the majority of cases.

It should be recognised that these costings are dependent on assumptions made about future behaviour and circumstances (such as transfer rates, commutation decisions and CPI increases), many of which cannot be tested against actual experience for many years.
Short and medium term impacts

There are bring-forward costs associated with the introduction of MSBS in the short and medium terms. These will result mainly from the funding of member contributions and the 3 per cent productivity benefit in MSBS, the provision of the retention benefit, and the transfer provisions.
The estimated net impact of the introduction of MSBS on annual budgetary outlays for Defence Force superannuation is expected to be $151m, rising during the transitional period to $209 for 1994-95.
Budgetary savings are expected to commence in about 35 years.
Longer term impacts-current Defence Force membership

The Australian Government Actuary and the consulting actuaries (TFP&) have forecast that the expected net long-term employer costs, after tax and social security clawbacks, for current members who join MSBS will be less than the projected net long-term employer costs of the DFRDB scheme for these members if they remained in that scheme.
Net employer liabilities for current Defence Force membership
The estimated net reduction in costs of superannuation for the past and future service of current members of the Defence Force is $690m.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill was under consideration by the Senate prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch today. At that point, I was highlighting the fact that a number of implications, particularly in regard to the increased levies that have been required to be imposed on the Ranger uranium mine in the Northern Territory, were exclusive. I had developed a number of points with regard to that argument. Also, I had expounded the view that I was disturbed at the paucity of contribution to this debate by members of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There was not one Australian Labor Party speaker on the speakers list with regard to this important consideration of uranium policy at this time. As I said earlier, I give credit to Senator Coulter and Senator Vallentine who, while they hold diametrically opposite views to my own on this matter, did have the courage to come in here and put their views. I think it ill behoves Labor Party senators in this place, who are not only gutless but also spineless, and are totally devoid of any capacity to make a contribution on such an important policy issue that is listed on the agenda of the Labor Party's convention this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tambling, I ask you to withdraw those adjectives.

—I withdraw them. We need to be aware that Ranger's operations have, at all times, been clean and straightforward. The strong record of the Northern Territory's Department of Mines and Energy in administering procedures and safeguards has also been well documented. The same cannot be said of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Section 28 of the November 1988 report of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled, The potential of the Kakadu National Park Region, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from the complexity of the regulatory framework and problems of liaison with Ranger, other criticisms have been made of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Ranger, for example, stated that `duplication of responsibilities, personnel and reports flowing to and from a Sydney office have inevitably resulted in gross inefficiencies'. The Committee is aware that the division of the Office of the Supervising Scientist responsibilities between Sydney and the Northern Territory is a cause of concern to several groups. These concerns relate not just to the possible duplication of effort, but also to the fact that decision making is located away from the mining operations themselves.

The Committee went on to recommend that the Government urgently consider locating all operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the Northern Territory. I would like to point out that the administration and decision makers within the Office of the Supervising Scientist are still located at Bondi, Sydney, even though a parliamentary committee; an independent consultant, Professor Geoff Taylor; the Northern Territory Government; and Ranger Uranium have very important bearings on this matter.

The report by Professor Taylor had 47 recommendations before it. Of course, the Government has chosen to ignore them because of the implications of publicly addressing that report on the review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, and the implications that it has on its own hidden agenda-secret agenda-with regard to uranium policies that have to be determined this year.
It is interesting to note that media reports of Labor's uranium policy review mention two options. Laurie Oakes's article in the Bulletin dated 16 April 1991 states:

One is a ``phasing out'' policy, under which no new mines and no new contracts would be permitted, resulting in the industry winding down over a 15-year period if Labor remained in office. The second option, ``conditioned and controlled mining'', would allow the development of new uranium projects as long as they complied with stringent conditions covering the interests of Aboriginal communities, the health of workers, protection of the local environment, economic viability of existing projects and, of course, nuclear non-proliferation and safeguard requirements.

I certainly hope that the Uranium Policy Review Committee will have success in reviewing the current discriminatory three-mine uranium policy at the Labor Party National Conference in Hobart in June this year.

Senator Collins has taken a very strong public stance on this particular issue and, as a colleague of mine from the Northern Territory, I welcome the public view that he has expressed with regard to the necessity to change this particular policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has done him no good.
—The Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory, Mr Brian Ede, similarly has publicly stated that he is prepared to go to the National Conference to argue for that sort of change.
—That will be fine.
—I am glad that Senator Faulkner recognises that. It is a pity that Senator Bolkus does not share his view in that particular regard.

—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I do not know how I ought to raise this within Standing Orders, and I seek your advise. The assertion which Senator Tambling has just made, that by not responding to his solicitation for an interjection I am disagreeing with him, should not be made and I ask you to ask Senator Tambling to withdraw it.
—There is no point of order.

—Just a few moments earlier, from the position where he was sitting in the chamber, Senator Bolkus interjected when I mentioned Senator Collins and said, `It won't do him any good'. Therefore, I certainly took his view to be at variance with Senator Collins.

—I raise a point of order again. I do not know what Senator Tambling is doing to himself. I have not moved from my position next to Senator Faulkner for some time, and I can tell Senator Tambling that if blindness is coming on, I would stop it.
—There is no point of order.

—It is well known that Senator Bolkus shares factional allegiances with the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Mr Warren Snowdon, in that they have, certainly from the viewpoint of the left faction of the Labor Party, taken a strong position to any change to the present three-mine uranium policy. Therefore, his sensitivity on this issue should be well recognised.

SPEECH.PARA: Similarly, I am concerned that the Australian Democrats have, of course, reflected a philosophy with regard to the changing of the uranium policy that can only properly be described as a doomsday type of philosophy. Similarly, they develop policies which can only be compared to an ostrich, with its head constantly in the sand and certainly no recognition of where we are going.

I was pleased to note a press release earlier this week by my Leader, the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, who made it very clear that he saw the only impediment to the uranium decision as being Mr Hawke. The incapacity of the Hawke Government to tackle the issues at the heart of Australia's uncompetitiveness has been very well documented, particularly with regard to this uranium saga.

The fact that we are left with nonsensical and restrictive policies, is the only way to define or describe the three-mines policy at the moment. It is a pity that in a time of economic consequences for all of Australia, the Labor Party continually denies and disallows any major change in these particular areas.

Uranium is now clearly established as a world resource for the generation of electricity. I was pleased to note the comments earlier today from Senator Parer in this regard. He adequately conveyed the point that the present ALP uranium policy has absolutely no influence on the use of uranium resources in the world. Of course, the Australian Government, over a number of years, has developed very good guidelines in so many areas-whether they are to do with our international obligations and treaties in this area, our localised requirements for the protection of the environment, or looking after the interests of Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

The present restriction on the number of mines should be removed. It is interesting to note that a recent report of the Industry Commission also commented on the unsuitability of the present three-mine policy when it said that the three-mine policy, and any price controls, should be abandoned so that there is no restriction on the number of uranium mines in Australia.

The proposed increased duty raised an additional $0.222m during 1989-90 and is expected to raise an additional $0.932m over the full 1990-91 financial year. In the 1989-90 financial year the levy raised $4.007m. Between July and February of the 1990-1991 financial year, $6.146m has been raised by the levy. Based on current projected exports it is expected that a further $1.066m will be raised during the March to June period, giving an estimated total amount to be raised during the 1990-91 financial year of $7.212m.

The provisions of the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1991 impose a discriminatory additional levy on the principal operator of a uranium mine in the Northern Territory. This is imposed at a time when Australia's uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive in the international marketplace, which does not suffer the same burdens. Senator Parer has indicated that the coalition will present an amendment in this regard, and I understand that Senator Crichton-Browne will also be addressing that issue. I certainly support their views at this time.

As I said earlier, it concerns me that the issues relating to the Taylor report on the Office of the Supervising Scientist were inadequately addressed in the Minister's second reading speech. There was only cursory comment with regard to the fact that Professor Taylor had conducted a review and that the 47 recommendations of that review had not been picked up. We are now seeing a financial impost without regard to the true facts.

I certainly challenge the Labor Party to look to the future, to determine a policy that scraps the three-mine uranium policy and gets on with restoring the Australian economy, not only to commonsense but also to a position that will guarantee a sound future and jobs for Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1991 amends the original Act in order to increase the duty on exported uranium concentrate mined in the Alligator River region of the Northern Territory from $115 a kilogram to $130 a kilogram. The duty will continue to be used solely to finance the various operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS), established by the Fraser Government in 1980 to monitor uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2 of the Bill provides that the Bill is to be taken to have commenced on 21 February 1990-over a year ago. The increase raises an additional $220,000 in the year 1989-90 and is estimated to raise an additional $920,000 this financial year. The estimated total duty to be raised from the duty in the current financial year is $7,200,000-odd dollars.

Since the Ranger mine is the only mine still operating in the region, this change effectively means that the mining company Energy Resources of Australia Ltd (ERA) will pay another 15c a kilogram in duties to the Government to finance the operations of the OSS. The OSS was established by the coalition Government for the purpose of monitoring the environmental impact of uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region to ensure protection, assessment and control, along with the provision of sound advice on the level of protection being maintained in the area.

The Office's activities include, amongst other things, tailings management, geomorphological studies to help with the necessary containing and isolation of tailings, and the development of strategies to help with the revegetation of decommissioned mine sites. The OSS is also involved in making sure that radiation exposure of workers and the public is kept to a minimum. The OSS spent $7.3m in 1989-90, up 11 per cent on the previous year, but much of that increase was due to the construction of an environmental radioactivity laboratory at the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute.

As the proposed changes to the export duty will raise over $7.2m, the OSS should become almost entirely independent of the need for government funding for the time being. I am sure that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber agree that the Kakadu National Park area is worthy of the utmost attention to ensure that the environment is not damaged to any significant degree by mining operations, and to that end I am sure that the OSS will continue to receive bipartisan support for the work it carries out in respect of the Alligator Rivers region. We on this side of the chamber are concerned that, while ERA is being forced to foot the entire bill of the Office, much of the research being undertaken by the Office is not directly relevant to the operations of the Ranger mine. As my colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) noted last week in the other place, this is not to say that the work being done is completely irrelevant, only that a strong case exists that ERA should not be responsible for financing all of it. This is something which we think the Government should take a good look at with a view to making it more truly a user-pays system. Until it does, export duty will continue to add something like 5 per cent to ERA's production costs at the Ranger mine, thereby having an inevitable impact upon the company's competitiveness.

The original duty as introduced by the coalition was not intended to have such an impact, and there is one simple reason why it has that impact today. That reason is the Australian Labor Party's three-mine policy. We will be moving an amendment calling upon the Government to review its uranium policy with a view to removing the existing policy, an amendment which we would certainly hope that the Australian Democrats would support and one which we should be confident that many members of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) will support as well. Many members of the ALP have insisted that the Government amend and review its uranium policy. Our amendment will be calling upon that, so we expect support from Government senators.

When we introduced the system, it was envisaged that there would be several mines operating in the area to share the burden, but because of the Government's continued ridiculous three-mine policy, which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself calls illogical, Ranger at the moment has to pay all the costs itself that are associated with the Office. If other deposits in the area such as Koongarra and Jabiluka were allowed to proceed, the cost to ERA would be substantially reduced but, true to form, the Government continues without any in-flight repairs to its pie in the sky uranium policy out of fear that it might lose its left wing altogether and crash sooner than it inevitably will.

While the person who seems to be the de facto Prime Minister, Senator Richardson, himself concedes that a three-mine policy is a disaster, he will not change the policy to keep the amount of blood on the floor at this year's national convention to the very minimum. The last thing he wants is a uranium policy change to send the Left running off to join Senator Vallentine and Dr Brown and the new Green Party which seems to be forming in place of the party formerly known as the Australian Democrats.

The last thing the Labor Party wants is to send its left wingers over to join this other left wing party. It would probably be good for Australia if it did that because it would then leave the right wing of the ALP to join with us in liberalising the country's uranium policy, thereby ensuring a return for the exports commensurate with our vast reserves of low-cost recoverable uranium. Until that happens, the country will slide closer to official Third World status and the people of this country will continue to watch with amazement the perennial conflict and indecision which this issue causes within the ALP.

My colleague Senator Tambling has mentioned that the ALP has chosen not to participate in this debate at all, a decision which is absolutely remarkable because of the importance of this Bill to Australia and because of the very many public statements that the ALP has made on the issue over the years and more particularly in recent weeks. One would think that, with all that public statement, the ALP would want to get up and talk about this Bill in this chamber of the Parliament of Australia, but again it has wimped out.

It has done the same thing that it did when we were talking about rainforest imports a few weeks ago. There was too much conflict between the Left and the Right and the Centre and the far Left wings of the ALP. It chose the easy way out-the way out that shows no courage at all and no intestinal fortitude, just by sitting mute and saying nothing. I hope that the people of Australia understand and accept that this Government is indecisive; it does not know what it is doing and it is not game to get up and say something about this very important issue.

The Labor Party has chopped and changed its position on uranium over the decades. I will not go through all of the various changes, but I cannot resist referring to the period from 1971 to 1975-a period when the uranium policy was something which the ALP changed almost annually. In 1971 the ALP platform urged early initiatives to build nuclear power stations. Then in 1972, upon coming into government, all new uranium contracts were stopped. Rex Connor, the then Minister for Minerals and Energy, imposed his export embargo, supposedly because of low world uranium prices. A year later, in July 1973, on the back of higher prices the ALP Federal Conference approved a strong pro-uranium policy similar to the one that had applied in 1971. By 1974 the pro-uranium policy gained momentum, but it soon became apparent that Mr Connor's embargo had more to do with government ownership of Australian uranium mining and processing than it did with world prices. As Mr Whitlam was besieged by foreign buyers, Mr Connor's embargo became an embarrassment. But, more importantly, the environmentalist rebellion was brewing within the Party and the uranium policy was turned around substantially at the February 1975 ALP National Conference. By June 1975 Mr Connor was saying that, `with adequate coal and hydro-power supplies, Australia was not prepared at present to consider its own nuclear reactors'-a complete about-face from the policy which the ALP had at the beginning of that decade.

I could go on charting the course of indecision from which the current three-mines policy was born, but I will spare the Senate that boredom and, possibly, humour. However, suffice to say that over the years the commitments from the ALP with regard to uranium have been about as rock solid as are ambassadorial posts to Ireland at the moment; or as rock solid as the governments in Western Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. They change at any moment and are as wobbly as they can be.

Rather than things getting better, things have become even worse as uranium has once again found its way onto the agenda. Internal ALP chaos and public outbursts are worse than ever, especially if one happens to be a Minister. Risky stuff, you might say, Madam Acting Deputy President, when the Prime Minister has just announced publicly that he will sack the next Minister to speak publicly about matters not relating to his or her portfolio. But as the Prime Minister realised that solidarity was beyond his control, he backed right away from his threat because it soon became apparent that if he sacked every Minister speaking out on the issue of uranium who should not have been he would have a Ministry of about one. The people of Australia want to know: who speaks on behalf of the ALP and the Government when it comes to uranium?

It is worth mentioning some of the more notable utterances made by Ministers recently, starting with Mr Hawke who calls the three-mines policy `illogical'. Next there is the Treasurer, Mr Keating, who, being a master of sleazy politics, has used uranium as his vehicle for gaining some support from the Left of his Party in his never-ending bid to topple the Prime Minister. According to Mr Keating, there is nothing magic about the three mines, as distinct from four or five mines, so the policy should remain. So who speaks for the Government? Is it the Prime Minister, who calls it illogical, or is it his deputy, who says that it is okay for it to stay as it is?
Should we believe the messages coming from the bona fide Left via Mr Howe who, before retreating on the Sunday television program this week, was reported in the Age as having said:
. . . no way could any member of the Left support a relaxation of the policy.
. . . no-one's going to bargain about it . . .

He has since cooled off and instructed his factional colleague, Mr Hand, to do the same publicly. But since the Sunday program Mr Hand has made it clear that he will not be shut up. He recently told the Brisbane Courier-Mail that he was:
. . . outraged and disgraced at attempts by some party members to hijack the debate on uranium.

He said that the Left would `take it right to the wire' and warned that any moves to axe the three-mines policy could split the Party. All of this is very prophetic and we will watch with some interest to see how strong Mr Hand is and how much he backs up his comments when he says that the Left will `take it right to the wire'. We will see how far away that wire is.

Do we believe Messrs Howe and Hand, or maybe we should believe the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, who I think is at least speaking on a matter that is within his portfolio? He has agreed with his own Department's submission which recommended that the policy be axed. It is interesting to rehearse some of Mr Kerin's quotes. Mr Kerin is reported as having told a committee of review in a leaked letter that the existing policy did nothing to meet the concerns about the environment, health and safety, nuclear non-proliferation, Aboriginal welfare and returns to the community. He is further quoted as saying that:

. . . a policy considering all nine proposals, with strict safeguards, ``would provide a basis for maximising the benefits to all Australians from our abundant uranium resources without compromising our position on the legitimate concerns of the vast majority of party members and most Australians.''

That is what Mr Kerin has said. It is rather a different statement to that of Mr Hand who said that the Left would `go to the wall' and that the Party would split. Obviously Mr Kerin does not believe in that too much.

Perhaps we should believe the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins-a self-professed supporter of uranium mining in Australia. Senator Collins is a member of the uranium policy review committee and he said last week that the three-mines policy should be scrapped and that it is `self-contradictory'. He said:
. . . there has to be a change. We're either mining uranium or we're not mining uranium.

Although I disagree sometimes with Senator Collins, he often has commonsense-a bump of sensibility-as he comes from the bush, and he is at least sensible when he talks about those sorts of things. He is right on track in relation to this matter: we either mine uranium or we do not. Whether we mine it from one, two, three, four or 100 mines really makes little difference.

It should be recalled that Senator Collins has been singing the praises of liberalising uranium mining in this country for some years. Maybe that is why Mr Hawke was so keen to take him from political obscurity in the north: to bring him down here to try to throw his weight around and get some political sense from some of his colleagues down here, who say that they will `take it to the wire' and split the Party over it. Senator Collins went to the point of issuing a research paper to his colleagues which concluded by saying:
This-
referring to the existing three-mines policy-
extremely detrimental position does not appear to be offset by any conceivable advantage to Australia from either an economic or an ideological point of view.

It is essential that the party take the next logical step, and allow Australia to develop its low-cost uranium resources in a manner consistent with both the market opportunities that do exist, and Australia's national interests.

Those are the words of Senator Collins, and I agree wholeheartedly with them. We then turn to Senator Bolkus. As he comes from the loopy Left we could expect nothing less than his outrageously naive statement about axing the three-mines policy. He is on public record as having said:
. . . there are no social or economic arguments in favour of axing it.

Only someone of Senator Bolkus's capabilities could be so stupid as to make a statement like that. It is absolute rubbish and I am sure he has been told that by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, who is at the table, and his other colleagues.

Speaking of the economic and social arguments in favour of the three-mine policy, we have not heard much from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, but it is worth noting that he issued a pro-uranium paper a couple of years ago in which he said that by 1992 Australia stood to gain 240,000 jobs and $5 billion if the three-mine policy were ended. I repeat that: Mr Bilney, a Minister in this Government, said that Australia stood to gain 240,000 jobs if this three-mine policy were ended. That is more than a third of the enormous number of Australians who are suffering on the unemployment queues at the moment. They could get jobs tomorrow, according to Mr Bilney, if the ALP had the courage to end its stupid three-mine policy.

Who speaks for the Government? Is it Senator Bolkus with his ridiculous statement about there being no economic arguments in favour of axing the policy; or is it Mr Bilney, who says that axing it would gain 240,000 jobs, more than a third of those currently employed, and give Australia $5 billion in foreign money, which we so desperately need at this time? For a quote that really sums up the Party's pathetic position, one need go no further than Senator Tate. He said:
I think the points of tolerance have been reached and if the Party is to retain a wide spectrum in its embrace then I think it's important to hold these people in-even at the price of logic . . .

That sums up the confusion, does it not? I commend Senator Tate at least for his honesty, if not his logic, in speaking as he did. He is saying this: despite the fact that the change is logical and that Australia would be better off as a result, the ALP will not risk losing the loopy Left fringe by changing its three-mine policy. That is Senator Tate's position.

If the Government does change its position, it is not only doomed to electoral defeat, but also to facing extinction as a party. That probably would be appropriate in the one-hundredth anniversary of the foundation of that Party, because it is not the Party it used to be; it is now a party of people from funny positions who cannot seem to understand what is best for Australia. Again I ask: who speaks for the Labor Party? Which Minister in this Government speaks for the Labor Party, or do we have to go to the back bench to get the ALP's real position?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner will speak!

—He does not speak too many other times; I am not sure why he would bother this time. He will not because the ALP is running scared on this. It is not going to have even one speaker in this debate because it is so split over the issue that one speaker would encourage another speaker and then there might be a free-for-all and a bloodbath in this chamber.
—The left wing wouldn't support what the right wing said, anyway.

—Of course it would not. Is ex-Minister Reynolds speaking for the Government when she says that she wants to ban all uranium mining? She wants all mines to be banned-not just one mine, three mines or 100 mines. Possibly Mr Courtice, the head of the Prime Minister's country task force, is speaking for the Government when he supports more uranium mines. Or does he speak for the Party when he says, `If the market is there, it means more jobs and exports'. I do not often agree with Mr Courtice, but in this instance Mr Courtice, Mr Bilney and Senator Collins are right. Of course it is in Australia's interest that something be done. Should we believe that the official Government position is represented by left winger Ms McHugh, the leader of the anti-uranium mini-faction of the Uranium Policy Review Committee, when she says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the market's declining, and we might as well phase out the mining that we're regrettably involved in.
Perhaps we should take notice of the honourable member for Kennedy, Mr Hulls, who has nicely displayed his pro-Keating credentials in the past week by echoing his idol's `two bob each way' sentiment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe he hopes to be a Minister.

—He has been promised that his seat will be rearranged to include some of the Aboriginal vote and so shore him up at the expense of Mr Gayler. But that is another internal ALP factional deal that will be interesting. Mr Hulls, following his idol, Mr Keating, said this of the three-mine policy when he spoke to the North West Star:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . current policy balanced the ethical, moral and economic arguments . . .
He further said:
In the current environment the policy is appropriate.

Mr Hulls need not be concerned because there are no active mines in Queensland, but if we are to believe Senator Reynolds, Mr Goss, the Premier of Queensland, has taken an anti-uranium stand and he will make sure that there are no uranium mines in Queensland in future. Not only are the Prime Minister, Ministers and backbenchers all singing different tunes, but ALP premiers are also calling the shots when it comes to uranium. We wonder just who is speaking for the ALP and for the Government on this particular matter.

Until we find out, the ALP's snail-pace of change in its attitude to uranium within its Party will continue to keep Australia from taking the place it deserves in the world uranium market. The opportunities being missed by Australia because of the three-mine policy are enormous. Australia has some 30 per cent of the world's low cost recoverable uranium reserves and 50 per cent of reserves in the Western world; and yet we have only 10 per cent of the market. Contrast that with Canada, which has 10 per cent of the reserves and 30 per cent of the market, and it is easy to understand the current estimates that Australia is missing out on some $750m a year because of the three-mine policy.

Despite the ignorant rambling from the ALP Left about demand for nuclear power being on the wane, it is worth noting that as the world turns away from fossil fuels to reduce greenhouse gases, it is estimated by the International Atomic Energy Agency that overall global demand for uranium will increase significantly over the next 10 to 15 years.

That makes one smile at the naive `fairies at the bottom of the garden' approach that the Democrats have to this issue. I heard one of them speaking before about the causes of cancer and how dangerous uranium is. I did not hear him say that if we stopped uranium mining that would stop cancer, because it just means that Canada and all the other places that produce uranium would take more advantage if we pulled out of the market completely. It would not make one iota of difference to the consumption of uranium around the world.

As has often been said, Australia has a good record in its sale of uranium and in the safeguards it puts in place, but the `fairies at the bottom of the garden' Party would have us pull out of that and leave it to someone else who possibly does not have the same concern that we do that uranium is used properly.

The big growth areas for the use of uranium are in the Asia-Pacific region, as countries in north-east and south-east Asia turn to nuclear power for environmental reasons. Again I make passing reference to the Democrats. If they had their way, we would not be able to use uranium for power. They do not want to countenance hydro-electricity power in the Tully-Millstream area; they do not want fossil fuel power and coal mines operating; but they want to go out every night, flick the switch and get electricity. I wonder how we are meant to do that if all the reasonable, sensible and logical forms of power use are not agreed to by the Democrats. But that is typical of their `pie in the sky', `fairies at the bottom of the garden' attitude to all real policy issues in Australia at this time. We on this side of the chamber have made it quite clear that we would abolish the three-mine policy and allow for both an increase in the number of uranium mines and in mining itself. In doing so, we would treat each new proposal on its merits, taking into account before a decision is made any adverse impact on the environment. If, in any case, it were shown that dangers were to be too great, the project would not proceed.

I wanted to mention some of my reservations about the Ben Lomond uranium prospect near Townsville where one of my electorate offices is based. Unfortunately, I have run out of time. I simply precis what I was going to say--

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you mean reservations? You have had no reservations so far!

—Senator McLean would not understand. Typically, he would not understand. But I have concern for Ben Lomond in accordance with coalition policy, which the Democrats would not understand because they are playing with the fairies in the back of the garden. The Opposition's policy allows uranium mining, provided it is commercially feasible and is environmentally safe. As I said, the Ben Lomond project is in the area where I live. I draw my drinking water from the Burdekin River, and the Ben Lomond uranium mine is in the headwaters of that river. Some environmental impact studies have been done. They are not conclusive at the moment, and that would be something that we would look at very closely before giving a licence.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McLean interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not that; we are happy to have it anywhere that it is environmentally safe.
—Anywhere but in your own backyard.

—If the honourable senator wants to say something he should put his name on the list. He is not game to do that, so why does he not let me finish my time in peace? In concluding-I have run out of time owing to the attempts by the Labor Party to stop me speaking as it stops its own speakers-we certainly ask the Government to seriously have a look at its current policy and to do something about getting rid of the ridiculous three-mines policy and to support the amendment which we intend to move which is the one asking for review.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1991 amends the principal Act so that the duty on uranium concentrate exported from the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory is increased from $1.15 to $1.30 per kilogram. It is a significant measure-one which goes, in a sense, to the heart of the uranium debate. The Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) is the direct user of the funds raised from the levy proposed in this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to commend Senator Macdonald for the way he has just taken this debate up, having just come in. He has been saying all of the right things and, obviously, he knows a lot about it. He has actually taken the fight up to the Australian Democrats in what they have been trying to do with our export industries and also to some of the left-wing members of the Australian Labor Party who obviously would not be very happy at all with the amendment that has been moved in this place by Senator Parer. The Labor Party is having quite a formal debate following on the recommendations of a committee of that Party to proceed with an expanded uranium policy, and with uranium enrichment.

I expect that between now and the special conference of the Labor Party, there will be a wide-ranging debate in the community at large. The Left will continue to go berserk on the issue and the Ministers will continue to speak up on the issue way outside the ambit of their particular portfolios. It is good to see the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, here tonight as a representative from the Northern Territory. Obviously, he has a big interest in the uranium debate because of what it does to help his territory-the Northern Territory.

The duty involved in the legislation was imposed by the coalition Government in 1980 in recognition of the special costs incurred by the Commonwealth for environmental monitoring and research activities related to uranium mining in the Alligator Rivers region of the Northern Territory. According to the Government, the increased rate of duty reflects its position that costs associated with protecting the environment from the potential adverse effects of uranium mining should be borne as far as practicable by the industry carrying out that mining activity and not by the ordinary taxpayers. It is the Office of the Supervising Scientist that carries out the Commonwealth's responsibilities in that particular area.

I support the principle of user pays. It is only right that the users of the OSS should pay for its operation. However, at the moment, through the Government's ridiculous and illogical three-mines policy, the burden of the duty falls on just one company. Under a coalition government, there would be no impediment other than the necessary environmental controls to the Koongarra, Jabiluka and Coronation Hill mines, sharing the burden with the Ranger mine and creating significant export dollars for Australia in the process. We would lift the three-mines policy, and that is a very big difference between us and the Labor Party.

The duty provides approximate cost recovery for the operation of the OSS, which has an appropriation of around $7m per year. However, the duty raised only $4m in 1989-90. With the proposed increase in the rate of duty, the total duty recovered is expected to be some $7.2m in 1990-91. This will provide a small surplus to balance a low return on the previous year. There will be an increase in the volume of uranium sales which happened to fall into 1990-91. The duty is raised only on operating mines in the region. The OSS provides services to other organisations and is of potential benefit to mines that will begin operation in the future. Therefore, the funding structure for the OSS should comprise appropriate payments from all users.

The Industry Commission, in a recent draft report, recommended that the charges to cover environmental monitoring be levied on all users of the region. The injustice of this duty falling on one company because of the Government's absurd three-mines policy is only highlighted by the fact that uranium prices are falling and the market is depressed. Yet, Energy Resources of Australia, the operator of the Ranger mine, must compete in the international market-a market which does not suffer the same tax on its products as we have in Australia.

The three-mines policy must go now so that when the upturn of the uranium market comes, as projections by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has forecast, Australia is able to gain its appropriate market share, and the market share should be considerable. Australia, as has already been mentioned, has 30 per cent of the world's low cost reserves of uranium but has only 10 per cent of the market. What an indictment of us in Australia. Canada, on the other hand, has only 10 per cent of the world's low cost reserves of uranium yet it enjoys 30 per cent of the market. With the current mismanagement of the export industries and the external debt by this Government, it is imperative that the three-mines policy go now so that potential mines, including world class deposits in the Northern Territory-this is Senator Collins's territory, and I am sure he would agree with this-get their share of the cake when the mines are opened up in the future. The development, the interests and the standard of living of all Australians will rest on our export dollar in the future.

Equally, in accordance with the international safeguards, we have to have proper environmental guidelines being complied with. Nobody would disagree with that. Changes in the rate of this duty are achieved by an extraordinarily complex process. It amazes me that that process is necessary. In brief, a gazette item is published, followed by a customs tariff proposal being introduced into the Parliament. This allows the new rate of duty to be collected. Although the customs tariff proposal must be backed up by legislation, such as the Bill under consideration, the customs tariff proposal will lapse if legislation is not passed within 12 months or if Parliament is dissolved.

In the present case, a previous customs tariff proposal for the rate increase now under consideration lapsed at the end of the last Parliament. Accordingly, the companies concerned will have over $200,000 returned to them, being duty paid at the higher rate until the end of the last Parliament. Usually, if there is an outstanding customs tariff proposal, when the intention to dissolve Parliament is known a validation Bill is passed in the last days of the Parliament. However, it was decided not to recall Parliament to pass a validation Bill. So the Government became liable to a refund claimed from the companies paying the levy. The Office of the Supervising Scientist, as the body expending the funds appropriated by the duty, must be both efficient in its work and must perform appropriate work.

The most recent review of the OSS, the Taylor review, was tabled in Parliament in December 1989 and the Government has still not responded. The Government stands condemned for that. One of the recommendations of the review was the transferral of staff from Bondi in Sydney to the Northern Territory. Although I understand that there may be problems in recruiting appropriate staff to work there, I believe that it is ludicrous that the Government has not yet acted on that particular recommendation. I understand the complexities involved but it was a firm recommendation of that report and I cannot understand why the Government has not acted on it.

The Government's inaction on this issue and the provision of a response to the Taylor review inevitably brings into question its seriousness and competency in providing appropriate reform for the Office of the Supervising Scientist. It is still happily located at Bondi, of course. It is a long way from the Northern Territory, from the Kakadu National Park and from the Alligator Rivers region, to which its work directly relates. The Taylor review found some serious inadequacies in its performance, including the lack of a published research plan and the lack of published environmental standards to guide the mining industries in their operations. These two items would seem to be absolutely basic to the credible functioning of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The Government has to be condemned again for failing to respond to the Taylor review in a sensible time frame so that these reforms could have had Government backing.

The Industry Commission, in its recent draft report of its inquiry into mining and minerals processing in Australia, found that there were substantial problems in the administration of mining activity in the Alligator Rivers region due to overlapping responsibilities held by the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. However, there is no point in commissioning reviews which arrive at significant findings such as these if the Government does not act upon recommendations that are given to it.

This Bill highlights some serious flaws in the Government's policies, including the underlying absurdity of its three-mines policy. There is a potential for an upswing in uranium demand. Unless we move more quickly Australia will miss the proverbial boat. The Northern Hemisphere will be bringing new reactors on stream in the next 10 years. I believe it is essential that Australia be able to supply this market, because if we do not, someone else will and Australia will have missed out on a vital export income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome any attempt to have the costs of environmental monitoring and research activities to protect the Alligator Rivers region met by the industry rather than by the taxpayers, as the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill intends. A large proportion of taxpayers, of course, are not in favour of uranium mining, and the vast majority of them do not favour uranium mining within any national parks.

SPEECH.PARA: I have several reservations about aspects of the Bill and comments made in the second reading speech. While endorsing the comment in that speech that, `The significance of the Alligators Rivers region should not be underestimated', I am not confident that the Government has realised the significance at all. If it had, there would be no question of mining either at Ranger or at Coronation Hill, both of which, of course, are inside the Kakadu National Park, a World Heritage listed area.

My reservation about this Bill, however, is that it does not acknowledge the environmental and health and safety costs associated with any uranium mining operation. There is, for example, no equivalent body to the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) monitoring the effects of the Olympic Dam site at Roxby Downs. This is where I must take issue with Senator Brownhill, who says that the Ranger uranium mine is bearing the total cost of the user pays policy. That is fair enough at that particular location, but there is no equivalent monitoring of the largest uranium mine in Australia, and some say the largest uranium mine in the Western world, at Roxby Downs. So it really is not a logical argument.

I note the estimate of $7.212m to be raised by the levy for the full 1990-91 financial year. This is slightly less than the 1989-90 budget for the OSS, which of course accounts for only part of the cost borne by the Commonwealth as a direct consequence of the mining operations in the area. So there appear to be grounds for the levy to be increased still more to meet the true costs to the taxpayer of mining within this significant area, although I would argue that the true costs are never really borne out by any dollar figures. This area should not be mined at all.

I am well aware that the last time the uranium export levy was increased ERA-Ranger, ably supported by the Australian Mining Industry Council and the Coronation Hill joint venturers, embarked upon a campaign to have the OSS discredited and disbanded on the grounds that, if ERA were paying for it, the OSS should be working for ERA's benefit. The industry criticisms of the OSS have been dismissed by an independent review of the organisation, the report of which was tabled in Parliament, as Senator Brownhill said, at the end of 1989.

I have spoken in the Senate previously in support of the work done by the OSS, and wish to repeat now that the Office of the Supervising Scientist deserves the strongest support, including strengthening of the Commonwealth environmental requirements, to ensure compliance by Ranger and amendment of Commonwealth-Northern Territory arrangements so that the OSS is able to carry out its regulatory role more effectively. It has often been referred to as a toothless tiger. I think that situation should change and the Government should implement some of the recommendations that were made in the report.

There are grounds for expanding the role of the OSS to cover all uranium mining operations in this country. I trust that there will be no more than the two at present-this includes Roxby Downs, of course-and that these will be phased out as current contracts expire. But I would also include so-called exploration sites such as CRA's operation at the Kintyre uranium deposit at Karlamilyi or Rudall River National Park, where there is a large field camp and significant drilling activities, the products of which are delivered across the country to be assayed in Melbourne. There is no regulation whatsoever of that camp's activities, which have been set up by CRA for quite a number of years. I visited the site in 1988 and it had a certain air of permanency about it, which was very different indeed from the Aboriginal communities inside the boundaries of the national park, which I visited on the same trip.

As at Kakadu, the Kintyre deposit occurs on land of the highest significance to the traditional owners of the land. The Martu people lost their `resource security' many years ago and are the forgotten part of this story. They have returned from the reserves and mining towns to which they were forcibly removed in the past and are absolutely united in their determination to preserve their cultural integrity by remaining on the land to which they belong. They do not want their land mined. There is no question of royalties or jobs being accepted as a trade-off. The Martu are resolute in their determination to preserve their land and their lives: the two are inextricably linked and neither is compatible with mining.

This brings me to one of the points mentioned in the well leaked letter by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, recently when he wrote to all members of the Australian Labor Party's uranium review committee. He mentioned five particular points, and the Aboriginal claim was one of them. He said that Aboriginal interests are being looked at at every level. That is patently not true. They are certainly not being looked at as far as the Kintyre deposit is concerned, and this deposit would be one of the very first to get the go-ahead if the three-mines policy were changed to expand the uranium industry. It would be the first in line. The Martu people will not stand for that and neither will the Western Desert Support Group, which is considerable and Australia-wide. We should ask the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, what he thinks about this particular deposit. In the run-up to the last election, when he had responsibility for this portfolio, he said, `No way will that Kintyre deposit be mined, because it is in a national park. It is uranium on Aboriginal land'.

We should also ask the Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, her views because before that election she also said that that would be off-limits. Yet recently the Western Australian Government foolishly declared that it was going to excise areas from the Rudall River National Park, from the D'Entrecasteaux National Park and from the Hamersley Range National Park in order to allow mining to go ahead. Carmen Lawrence is on record for many years as being opposed to uranium mining and being a supporter of Aboriginal issues in general. It is really quite difficult for people in Western Australia to understand how on earth she can make such a change to policy to allow uranium mining to go ahead with bits of the national park excised. Mind you, there are many things which the Western Australian Government has been doing recently which are difficult for the people in Western Australia to understand.

I come back to the five points that Mr Kerin mentions in his well publicised letter. The letter was very well timed in its leaking because it means that his arguments can be demolished successfully one after another. First of all, he talks about non-proliferation and says that the issue is not a problem any more. I cannot imagine where he is getting his advice from.

We trade with the French, who are not signatories to the non-proliferation treaty (NPT). The French used to trade with the Iraqis and they are about to resume trading in nuclear materials again. The French also trade with the Israelis and Pakistanis, who also have not signed the NPT. It has been very clearly demonstrated that Australian uranium, which goes to France and then goes on its merry way through the nuclear fuel cycle, cannot be separated out. Our uranium could be ending up in Iraq, in Israel or in Pakistan; all countries which are threshold countries and not signatories to the non-proliferation treaty.

I do not know how Mr Kerin can say that there is no further concern about that. He is obviously referring just to glasnost-the situation existing between the two former superpowers, the United States and the Soviet Union. Glasnost may have had a very small impact on the nuclear weapons stockpile of those two nations. Most of the plutonium which is being removed from ground-based nuclear weapons is being redeployed onto Tomahawk cruise missiles. There is not a reduction in the amount of plutonium on nuclear weapons between these two superpowers. In addition, neither Britain nor France has placed their nuclear weapons on the negotiating table. As I mentioned, there are so many threshold countries-including those that France deals with, and also South Africa and India-which have not signed the NPT but which are, presumably, going on apace with their nuclear weapons programs.

It was interesting that on the same day that Mr Kerin's letter was leaked it was disclosed that the Western Mining Corporation, Pancontinental and the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, had been in Taiwan-another non-signatory to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty-trying to scrounge up some deals, seeing if they could help gear up some uranium sales in the future with Taiwan. When I asked a question about that yesterday, the Government was so confused that it may also be trying to line up some deals with Taiwan. There are not too many other deals going. That is the first of John Kerin's arguments totally demolished.

Secondly, Mr Kerin says that nuclear safety is better now since Chernobyl. How can he say that? There has been a lot of talk about that particular accident being discredited because of inferior Soviet technology. Mr Kerin may make those claims but there was an accident on 9 February in Japan-which, of course, was denied by the industry until several weeks had passed. However, it shocked the Japanese Government into reviewing its program for an atomic energy future.

When this accident happened on 9 February, it was not until radiation in one section of the plant had multiplied 10 times in five minutes that the technicians felt sufficiently bothered about a possible meltdown to try manually lowering output from one of the station reactors. At 1.50 p.m., as what turned out to be a leak from the primary cooling system into the secondary system sent radiation levels to 1,250 times normal, computers automatically shut down the plant's number two reactor and poured huge quantities of water into the reactor core, thus averting a possible meltdown. This is Japan, which is meant to have superior state-of-the-art technology. I remind Mr Kerin and anybody else in the Labor Party who cares to listen, as they anguish with this issue yet again, that this incident occurred on 9 February this year. The worst nuclear accident in Japan was four times greater than officially reported. This is typical of the lies, the deception and the secrecy that the nuclear industry regularly adopts.

There was also a great deal of concern in Czechoslovakia about a possible meltdown when, one year after an accident, contamination of ground water was finally admitted. Across the border, the Austrians, who know full well post-Chernobyl that the nuclear cloud knows no national or international boundaries, have demanded that the Czechoslovaks shut down the reactor at Jaslovske Bohunice. So many accidents have happened that they are scared of the big one. A very difficult situation exists between those two Governments. People are very worried and scared, an accident having been proved to have happened one year after it did happen-it not being acknowledged officially that the ground water was contaminated was bad enough-that there will be an even greater accident.

There have been many instances of the nuclear industry covering up and lying about the problems that it has had. In the United States things have not fared much better. Clean-up costs for the crippled Three Mile Island reactor have risen from an initial estimate of $US100m to $US4 billion and the clean-up is not complete yet. There are so many instances that Mr Kerin's ridiculous claim that nuclear safety has improved since Chernobyl has been demolished totally.

Mr Kerin talks about worker and public health as though that, too, has been allayed. Senator Coulter early in the debate today made quite a number of comments about that. I remind the Senate that the International Commission on Radiological Protection is constantly issuing new guidelines downgrading the amount of radiation to which workers can be exposed without danger of permanent health risks to them. The levels have been dropped from 50 millisievert per annum to 20 millisievert per annum, which is a two-and-a-half fold reduction. There are more reductions on the way. Yet the Minister says that worker health and public safety is okay. Mr Kerin should ask the people who live not only in the Ukraine but also in Byelorussia or the Russian republics: they know only too well that public safety is not looked after by the nuclear industry.

Then, of course, there are the Aboriginal interests. In the Kintyre deposit, Aboriginal interests are not being looked after. These people have gone back to their own territory. In 1988, which was meant to be a year of some sort of national celebration of 200 years of European settlement in this country, all that the Kintyre people could think about was that they had no security over that land. Yet CRA Ltd, with its camp just outside the national park border, had absolute security and absolute permanency. CRA is just waiting for a change in Government policy, which of course we are now seeing in danger of unfolding. Aboriginal interests have not been dealt with.

The next reason that Mr Kerin gave for changing his mind was the supply and the burgeoning market. Mr Kerin cannot deny that there is an oversupply and a glut of uranium on the world market. There are stockpiles all around the world, including at Roxby Downs, which is at the moment selling only 60 per cent of the uranium that it is mining; it cannot get rid of the stuff. So why open up more mines when some of the Australian uranium that is already here cannot be sold? The burgeoning market that he talks about is an absolute furphy-because there is no evidence. I demonstrated this yesterday very clearly when I asked a question about the Minister's exaggerated figures on Japan and the calls by Korea for nuclear power stations in the next 20 years. The Minister did not have the backup for the allegations that he had made in his letter. He was unable to confirm them. There is a huge discrepancy between what he said about both Japan and Korea and what is the reality. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
