SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to tell the story of a shipyard. Many of you will have read or seen on television at the weekend the launching of the last ship from the Hunter shipyard, Carrington Slipways Pty Ltd. This last ship, the Searoad Tamar, was built for the Australian National Line (ANL).

SPEECH.PARA: The last workers at Carrington Slipways said that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, should have attended the launching. They said that he always was to be seen at grand finals. Sadly, this was not a grand final but something reminiscent of T.S. Eliot's The Hollow Men:
This is the way the world ends
Not with a bang but a whimper.

One has to ask why. Why was it the end for Carrington Slipways? Why did it all go wrong? Carrington Slipways was founded by the Laverick family in 1959. It was not a large shipyard. The modern flow-line facility was established in 1972 on a site acquired in 1969. The company early established a reputation for stability not matched by some of its contemporaries.

One of the major contracts awarded in 1983 to a Carrington subsidiary was for part of the minehunter project for two fibreglass hulls. A $12m fixed-price contract was awarded to the German firm, Krupp Atlas Elektronik, to supply mine- hunting sonar equipment for the vessels. However, according to a report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade last year, the Krupp sonar system did not satisfy fundamental tests. As a result of the contract for the minehunters, Carrington developed a glass reinforced plastic facility at Tomago. This facility was purpose built for the minehunter project.

The major contract in phase two for the provision of a ship building facility and two prototype minehunters was let to Carrington Slipways in 1983. Two have been built, but an order for four more has been postponed. There would appear to be a question mark over the persistence by the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) with the Krupp sonar system, which was found to be faulty. This has resulted in a catch 22 situation. Because the Navy insisted on the Krupp system and the system did not work, it then rescinded the order for the minehunters beyond two prototypes. If the faulty system had not fouled up the minehunter project, the project would have gone ahead for the other six minehunters that were originally planned and Carrington would still be operating.

Then in 1989 began the saga of the Anzac frigate contract. A consortium was established to bid for the latest frigate tender to be built in Australia. The consortium was titled Australian Warships Systems Pty Ltd and consisted of the Australian companies, TNT Ltd, AWA Ltd, Carrington Slipways, and two overseas companies. The consortium was offered a Dutch-designed M class frigate to be built principally in Newcastle but with some subcontracting let elsewhere in Australia. The hulls of the warship were to be built by Carrington Slipways and most of the technical work, including installation of the defence systems and masts, was to be carried out in the old State Dockyard in Newcastle.

More than half the value of the construction was to be made up of sophisticated electronic equipment. The winning bidder for this would have gained a very solid base for future industrial development in high technology.

To quote a newspaper at the time, Newcastle was `sweating blood' to secure the RAN frigate contract. The people of Newcastle even placed thousands of signatures on a white bus which was driven to Canberra; it was probably one of the most original petitions ever received by this Parliament.

There was no doubt that Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) was offering the cheapest ship, but that Australian Warship Systems was offering better value for money. Despite all the lobbying and all the efforts, the contract was finally awarded to AMECON, but with the promise that some of the work would be contracted interstate, and especially to Carrington Slipways. Promises are promises. Since that day not a single piece of work has come to Carrington or, for that matter, to any other shipyards in the Hunter.
It was reported last May that Dr John White, the managing director of AMECON, said that his consortium did not intend to set up a shipbuilding operation in the Hunter. He said:
AMECON is committed to spending $700m or more on shipbuilding work in Newcastle but that will be done on a sub-contract basis.
Possible subcontractors included Eglo Engineering Pty Ltd and Carrington Slipways. In May last year Dr White said this:
I am very confident that Carrington Slipways will be involved in the project. It has capacities that we do not.

Since that statement, no work has been negotiated with Carrington Slipways. Just to indicate what Newcastle lost and Williamstown gained, I point out that the awarding of the Anzac frigate project to AMECON will create work for the Williamstown dockyard in Melbourne for more than 15 years. In December 1990 the only major subcontracts let by AMECON were for the hull and superstructure units by its subsidiary, Eglo, in Newcastle and Adelaide.

Carrington Slipways has been highly regarded for its shipyard building work. Just to indicate what some of these projects are, I will go through some of its most recent projects. Last year it completed an $11.6m dredge, the David Allan, for the Maritime Services Board. In addition, it has been Australia's largest supplier of tugs.

When the demise of Carrington Slipways began to look more of a reality than a mere threat, the people of Newcastle did all that they could to try to save the yard. The Port Stephens Shire Council unanimously passed a recommendation to support any feasibility strategy that would save Carrington Slipways and keep it operating as a shipyard. There were discussions between the New South Wales State Development Minister, Mr John Hannaford, and Senator Button, but the future continued to look bleak. Where now was the famous government support that saved Kodak Australia?

Senator Button met a Newcastle delegation consisting of Hunter Valley parliamentarians, the Newcastle Lord Mayor and a number of union officials. Nothing happened. All Senator Button did was issue a press statement in which he said that he was looking to have a viable shipbuilding operation in the Hunter region in the long term. Of course `in the long term' was no use to Carrington Slipways.

At the time the blame was laid with the Australian tax regime, which was a great deterrent to potential investors in the shipyard. There was hardly any inducement to investors to become involved in the yard when their return was equivalent to leaving the money in the bank. There is a real need for inducements for investment in this country in high-risk projects with the enormous potential of Carrington Slipways.

The final blow for Carrington came with the foreclosure by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia on the outstanding loans owed by the shipyard. The company went into receivership last year. The yard finally collapsed on 21 December. Its assets were placed in control of the agents-in-possession by the Commonwealth Bank. The Australian National Line leased the shipyard assets to complete the 8,500 tonne ship, Searoad Tamar. ANL negotiated with the unions to employ on a casual basis some of the 429 employees.

Did the Federal Government offer any last-minute reprieve for Carrington? The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) uttered a pious wish for a buyer for the shipyard, but he ruled out any assistance from the Federal Government. Mr Vernon Broome, the Executive General Manager of the ANL's marine management services, paid tribute to the shipyard's efforts in building the Searoad Tamar, which was started in December 1989. He particularly praised the cooperation of the unions and workers in the months since the collapse which allowed the ship to be completed. He said:
This shipyard has been fitted out as a very modern yard. It will be a pity to see it just disappear.

The way in which the Government has, through bungled planning and playing political favourites, allowed a major manufacturing and export facility like Carrington Slipways to collapse is a tragedy for the Hunter and indeed for Australian industry. Every month we have evidence in the balance of payments that Australia cannot pay its way in the world. This Government claims that it wants a more diversified economy; a halt to the decline of the manufacturing industries; the development of high technology industries; a boost to manufacturing exports.

Yet, when a successful, innovative, high technology manufacturer, such as Carrington Slipways, fulfils the Government's wants, the Government destroys this valuable company with bungled contracts, political favouritism and heartless financial constraints. People in high places need to answer certain questions. Let me put some of those questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-six million dollars worth.

—I thank Senator Collins for that interjection. Perhaps he could answer some of these questions. Who in Canberra influenced the decision of the Commonwealth Bank to pull the plug on Carrington Slipways when the yard had assets in excess of $20m? What organisations or companies now control the total naval defence spending budget for the next 20 years? Why were repeated representations by Carrington Slipways management requesting the Government and the Department of Defence to consider fitting an alternative proven sonar system to the mine hunters ignored, thus affecting possible orders to the Middle East and South East Asian countries? Why did AMECON not fulfil its pledge that 27 per cent of the work associated with the ANZAC frigates would come to the Hunter? What factors influenced the decision to award the frigate contract to AMECON?

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem for Newcastle and the Hunter now, as in the past, is government neglect. Labor did not care because it could not lose in the Hunter. Up to 1988 the Liberals did not give the region preference because they could not win it. Labor should not be so complacent now about its political future in Newcastle and in the Hunter. I invite the people of the Hunter to send in submissions to the forthcoming House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology which is conducting an inquiry into the future of the shipbuilding industry. The Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Dobell, Mr Lee, will be conducting sittings in Newcastle to hear submissions about the collapse of Carrington Slipways.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the inquiry into the banking industry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration was established last year I was hoping that this ritual would end and that I would not have to stand night after night speaking on the adjournment pursuing the question of bank malpractices and corrupt practices. Unfortunately I have to continue to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators are aware of the fact that I have been in the practice of tabling affidavits and supporting documents as case studies of how ordinary Australians suffer at the hands of banks. I seek the leave of the Senate tonight to table two such affidavits, accompanied by supporting documents, as further evidence of how these things unfold in the daily lives of ordinary Australians, namely, in relation to Dr Catherine Nemeth, who has been in dispute with the Commonwealth Bank in a very spectacular way for quite some time, and in relation to Mr and Mrs Smith of Manypeaks in Western Australia who are in a less spectacular but nonetheless worthy dispute with the Rural and Industries Bank of Western Australia in that State.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, from our point of view we do not object to leave being granted, on the understanding that Senator McLean has given us a note to the effect that none of these documents is sub judice.

—I gave assurances early in the day that the evidence I am tabling is not at the moment sub judice. It may well be before the court at some future time. In some cases, it has been before the court previously, but it is not at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak about the case of the Smiths briefly because I sent details of their case to every Federal member of parliament some months ago. These ordinary people find themselves in quite an extraordinary situation. They have been in dispute with the bank for 10 years. Twice during that time they have been granted legal aid to carry their case to court. Twice that legal aid has been withdrawn because they have been unable to get the bank into the court in the necessary period of time. Their letter was one of despair from ordinary Australians. It was for that reason that I circulated particulars of their case to all members of parliament some months ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall now return to the case of Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd. People have asked me why. I shall just relate to the Senate my experience of having appeared before the banking inquiry. As I said, I was hoping that that appearance would put an end to this ritual on my part. Indeed, it has not. On the occasion that I appeared before the banking inquiry, as I mentioned two evenings ago, I tabled 3,000 pages of documentary evidence, a good deal of which related specifically to the Huon Valley Springs case. I considered it to be a classic case of targeting and asset stripping. From a statement by the Chairman of the Committee, Mr Stephen Martin, it is apparent that the Committee at large-certainly Mr Martin but I believe he claims to be speaking on behalf of the Committee at large-has chosen to ignore that evidence. In fact, Mr Martin publicly stated that I did not provide it. He must have failed to have seen it and certainly he has failed to peruse it. I am left with no option other than to return to that evidence.

In the course of my three and a half hours before the inquiry and in the course of speaking to those 3,000 pages of evidence, one of the members of the Committee asked whether I could reduce it a few paragraphs; whether I could possibly reduce the concept of proof of targeting and asset stripping to a few paragraphs. I did not laugh at the time but, in retrospect, it is quite a laughable suggestion.

On the last occasion I spoke on this issue, two nights ago, I attempted to establish, to prove, for the benefit of the Committee and others, the fact that senior officers of the Commonwealth Bank in relation to this case perjured themselves. I was asked in relation to this and other cases what anybody had to benefit from the processes which I described. A lot of people stood to benefit from the processes I have been describing; sometimes the banks, sometimes the clients of the banks, but seldom the person who was targeted-in fact, never the person who was targeted. That is the essential situation which I have been attempting to describe and will now return to in the case of Huon Valley Springs.

In the course of this presentation I shall be citing and quoting from 39 pages of evidence, the evidence that Mr Martin says that I did not provide and has chosen to ignore in all of the 70 cases that I have cited during the past two and a half years. I shall be quoting from 39 pages of documents. In advance, I seek leave to table those documents, with one exception.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I return then to the subject of Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd. The company conducted a mineral water bottling plant upon land owned by Durna Pty Ltd. It is significant that it conducted its operations on land that it did not own. The principals of Durna were Maxwell Reynolds, Anthony Sofia and Dominic Vizzone. Durna leased the land to Huon Valley Springs. The lease provided that, if receivers were appointed to the assets and undertakings of Huon Valley Springs, Durna could there upon terminate the lease. The Commonwealth Development Bank held a registrable, equitable mortgage over the assets and undertakings of Huon Valley Springs with the power to appoint a receiver.

SPEECH.PARA: What that means is that if Huon Valley Springs failed to pay the instalment of interest due to the Commonwealth Development Bank on 1 January 1986, the Commonwealth Development Bank could appoint receivers. Durna would then cancel the lease and the receivers would be prevented from selling the business as a going concern. The Commonwealth Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank, as the bankers to Huon Valley Springs, would then stand to lose heavily. Durna, on the other hand, stood to purchase the assets from the receivers on favourable terms. If the Commonwealth Development Bank appointed receivers, Messrs Reynolds, Sofia and Vizzone would inevitably be the beneficiaries. Therein lies the essence of this allegation and the rebut, of course, suggests the necessity to prove it.
The Commonwealth Bank of Australia recognised the inevitable. In a diary note dated 6 December 1985, the Deputy Chief Manager of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Mr J.J. Vanner wrote:

Rural Officer Hobart, Terry Cracknell, visited the Cygnet factory this morning . . . at this stage he doubted if the operations would have any value to an investor or a larger company. Mr Cracknell said that in the event of the show closing Reynolds would be the principal beneficiary.
. . . A very considerable loss is in prospect and CBA has little alternative but to count its losses.

I have tabled the document from which I have quoted. By an extraordinary coincidence, the diary note was written the day after the first shipment of contaminated product was dispatched to Sydney. The contamination of the mineral water crippled the cash flow of Huon Valley Springs. Reynolds was in charge of quality control. In a memorandum dated 13 January 1986, Mr Vanner wrote:

Yes there is a marketable product there and, with proper financial management and adequate equity backing, it would be brought to a profitable level of operation. Just who might do this is terribly difficult and an offhand comment some weeks ago that Reynolds will be the principal beneficiary of all that has happened seems close to the mark.

I have tabled the document from which I have just quoted. The Commonwealth Development Bank was in a similar predicament to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. In a memorandum dated 31 December 1985, which I have previously tabled in this place, Mr K.I. Whatson of the Commonwealth Development Bank Head Office wrote:

What we would do if the factory closes down is not immediately obvious. First step would seem to be to get hold of what book debts there might be . . . There is a risk of loss of most, if not all, of our investment of $500,000.00.
In a memorandum dated 8 January 1986, which I have previously tabled, the Commonwealth Development Bank State Manager, New South Wales, Mr J. W. Thompson, wrote:

. . . it now appears that the company may not be able to reach a position where its product will generate sufficient cash flow to service its commitments. We understand that the CBA is in the process of making demand for payment of its debt if this happens it seems to us very likely that the company will have no option but to close its operations. In this event, there would be little worth in our R/E/M security (that is, Registered Equitable Mortgage security).

What this means is that officers of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia had painted the bank into a corner by imprudent lending practices and were about to drag the Commonwealth Development Bank down the drain with them. At this stage there was no suggestion from the Commonwealth Development Bank of appointing receivers. The memorandum continues:

We have prepared in draft form notice of demand including fixing our charge in respect of R/E/M security. We have also prepared in draft a notice to individual debtors requiring funds due to be paid to CDB . . .
The Commonwealth Development Bank resisted approaches by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to appoint a receiver. In a memorandum dated 15 January 1986, Mr Thompson wrote:

Mr Vanner of CBA was in touch with us on 15th January . . . It was put to us that having in mind the supposedly substantial value of this stock CDB may wish to consider appointing a receiver to dispose of it. I told them we would be unlikely to wish to entertain such an arrangement as this may precipitate the folding up of the company which would not help CBA in the present investor negotiations and is unlikely to help CDB's case.
I have tabled the document from which I have quoted. In a memorandum dated 21 January 1986, Mr Thompson wrote:

We were telephoned yesterday by Messrs. Robinson and Vanner of NSW Branches Administration, CBA. . . . The CBA representatives suggested that CDB may care to take action under its R/E/M with a view to taking possession of and selling the stock said to be on hand. Whilst we did not reject that suggestion outright it was made clear we were not terribly enthusiastic . . .
I have tabled the document from which I have just quoted. In a memorandum dated 24 January 1986, Mr Thompson wrote:

Mr Vanner of CBA informed us this morning . . . We were asked whether CDB has thought any more of acting under its securities and appointing a receiver. I said we had not done any more regarding this and in fact we may have no cause to do so as we believed borrower is proposing to pay arrears of interest which is the only default under the CDB R/E/M at this stage . . .

I have tabled the document from which I have just quoted. The Commonwealth Bank of Australia even pre-empted the appointment of a receiver. In a memorandum dated 21 January 1986, Mr P. J. Shoebridge, an officer of the Commonwealth Development Bank wrote:

Miss Batiste went on to say they had just undertaken discussions with Mr Neil Sim (General Manager NSW Branches Administration) regarding CBA's position . . . Mr Sim also indicated that CDB were reviewing their position and in fact were considering Appointment of a Receiver! Mr Sim stated in regard to the above, ``I am at liberty to disclose that! This lead to the conclusion that CDB was on the point of taking action under its securities. Miss Batiste was informed that at this point in time CDB had not reached a decision as to appointment of a receiver . . .

I have tabled the document from which I have just quoted. The statement by Sim was a blatant lie. That lie was told by the General Manager, New South Wales Branches Administration-the right hand man to the then Managing Director, Mr Vern Christie. Then, again, that revelation should not surprise us because Peter Poppett committed perjury in Wilfred Taylor's case-a case which I have similarly unfolded here. Geoffrey Kyngdon committed perjury in Tony Rigg's case, which I have similarly exposed. Jim Vanner committed perjury in Donna Batiste's case. Senior management of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia used the lie told by Mr Sim to influence the Commonwealth Development Bank's decision to appoint a receiver. In a memorandum dated 5 February 1986, Mr Thompson wrote:

There have been considerable developments throughout this week in relation to this account. On Monday 3rd February we were telephoned by Head Office with the message that the Managing Director (that is, Mr Vern Christie) had said at the 9.30 meeting that something must be done about this account without further delay. I was asked to arrange an urgent meeting with General Manager NSW CBA Mr Sim and this discussion took place immediately after lunch when Messrs Robinson and Vanner were also present.

It was clear from that, that Mr Sim's understanding was that CDB had virtually given a commitment in the previous week to take action. This was not as we understood it. Be this as it may however, it was clear that the time for action had arrived . . . Subsequently the case was reviewed by Deputy General Manager CDB, Mr Wright, Ken Whatson and myself. It was decided later, on the afternoon of 3rd February that CDB should move towards appointment of a receiver as quickly as possible.

I have tabled the document from which I have just quoted. I suppose the question then arises: why did Mr Sim lie to Miss Batiste? I would contend that Sim lied to pressure Miss Batiste into selling the business. Senior management knew that Miss Batiste was endeavouring to sell a share of the business to pay out the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. In a record of interview between Messrs Robinson, Vanner and Simington and Miss Batiste dated 16 January 1986, it is stated:

The sale package they are offering is 49% of the company with Miss Batiste staying on in the company. They are negotiation for total cover of the Bank debts (company only) for between $1.5Million and $2Million for a 49% share . . .
I have tabled the document from which I have quoted. I return to the memorandum of Mr Shoebridge dated 21 January 1986 which I have also tabled. It states:

Miss Batiste went on to say that they had just undertaken discussions with Mr Neil Sim . . . there are three people stated to be interested in purchasing the business. Negotiations are proceeding but nothing has eventuated.
I contend that Miss Batiste passed this information to Mr Sim, and he then lied to her.

The question arises: why did Sim, Robinson and Vanner hold an urgent meeting with Mr Thompson? Why did they influence the Commonwealth Development Bank to appoint a receiver? Robinson and Vanner knew that Miss Batiste was negotiating with an Italian syndicate. Robinson and Vanner knew the terms of the negotiation. Robinson and Vanner knew Miss Batiste's attitude to those negotiations.
I return to Mr Thompson's memorandum dated 21 January which states:

We were telephoned yesterday by Messrs Robinson and Vanner . . . They had shortly beforehand interviewed Brian Wickens who was the director of a borrower company . . . Wickens mentioned also that Batiste is believed to be trying to sell the company to an ``Italian syndicate'' for $4Million. The Italian syndicate is believed to be somewhat interested, provided Batiste is out of the company altogether. She is not impressed with this and wants to retain a 49% interest but with herself to receive $2Million in cash for sale of the 51% interest.

On 24 January 1986 a meeting took place and a deal was struck. In a memorandum from Max Reynolds to the Sunday Telegraph relating to that meeting, which I have tabled previously in this place, it is recorded that an offer was to be made to Miss Batiste as follows:
That the offer would be made to Donna Batiste and that the money would come through the ICLE bank via a group as follows:
ICLE...20%
AEFC...20%
D. Batiste...10%
Durna...30%

Honourable senators will recall that `ICLE' refers to the Instituts Nazionale Di Credito Per Il Lauore Italiano All'Estore, an Italian resident merchant bank owned by Banca Nationale del Lauoro of Italy.

The reference to AEFC refers to Australian European Finance Corporation Ltd, an Australian resident merchant bank then owned by the Banca Nationale and the CBA. The reference to ABC refers to ABC Property Planners Pty Ltd, 25 per cent of which is owned by AEFC. What this means is that if the deal was consummated, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia would have carried equity in the project.

Honourable senators will also recall that the ICLE bank was the banker for the Italian syndicate's company, Durna Pty Ltd. The Commonwealth Bank of Australia had a material interest in the deal, as part owner of AEFC. The ICLE banked with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and loaned money to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. I have tabled the audited accounts of the ICLE bank as at 31 December 1984 showing loans to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. The ICLE would have informed the Commonwealth Bank of Australia of the deal.

Senior management of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia would have reason to believe that Miss Batiste would reject the offer. Senior management of the CBA had reason to believe that Miss Batiste would pay the arrears of interest to the Commonwealth Development Bank. Senior management of the CBA knew that the CDB did not want to appoint a receiver. I contend that the best senior management of the Commonwealth Development Bank could hope for was to consummate the deal and take its carried equity in the project. I contend that Sim, Robinson and Vanner used Sim's lie to influence the Commonwealth Development Bank as part of a corrupt deal to defraud Miss Batiste.
The ICLE bank wanted to take over Huon Valley Springs. In a letter from Messrs Sofia and Vizzone to ICLE Finance Corporation dated 31 December 1987, the Italians wrote:

We believe that we were duped and forced into entering into the Huon Valley Springs mineral water venture by the Bank's over zealous General Manager, Dr Giorgio Draskovic. Dr Draskovic, we maintain was driven by his own personal ambitions and desire to achieve status within your own corporate structure and also amongst the wider banking community.
In grandiose terms he-
that is, Dr Draskovic-
said that he was about to show the Australian banking community how Italian banks operated and in the process use HVS as the spearhead for IFC (ICLE Finance Corporation).

. . . Draskovic continued to stress the importance of Huon Valley. He recounted the story that at a congregation of the banking fraternity i.e. amongst his peers, that the Federal Treasurer, Mr Keating, had singled IFC and himself as a model for other bankers to follow. Mr Keating has specifically mentioned the fact that he (and IFC) had picked Huon Valley springs when other banks did not want to touch it.
I seek leave to table the letter from which I have just quoted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Collins

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, yes, but I point out that the letter, as would be obvious from the quote, is in fact, without question, defamatory of Dr Draskovic. As is his absolute right, the honourable senator has quoted from it. I simply rise to make the point that we will grant leave but I want it on the record that Dr Draskovic, pursuant to privilege resolution No. 5 of this Senate, can of course seek to have a response made to the President should he wish.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that I previously named Dr Draskovic some months ago. At that time I alerted him to the fact that there were privilege procedures available to him, as Senator Collins has quite rightly stated once again. The question arises: how did Giorgio Draskovic, the model banker, take control of Huon Valley Springs? I return to the letter from Messrs Sofia and Vizzone:

SPEECH.PARA: Naghten (the Managing Director of ABC) structured a proposal which effectively took over all assets and liabilities of HVS Pty Limited.
He told us the revised share structure would be:
- 50% Durna
- 20% IFC
- 20% Australian European Finance
Corporation
- 10% Batiste

The offer was presented to Miss Batiste, who rejected it. A meeting was then arranged with Draskovic, Naghten and ourselves to review the state of play. In spite of the offer being rejected Naghten and Draskovic were confident we could take over HVS Pty Limited. We were advised that they had already taken such steps through their contacts in the Commonwealth Development Bank to have the ``plug'' pulled on Batiste. A Notice of Demand was being served on Batiste almost at the moment. We were further advised that Mr Naghten would be taking Miss Batiste's percentage of the equity. We don't know what actually transpired but almost immediately HVS Pty Limited went into receivership . . .

What was the consequence of the action taken by Dr Draskovic? The answer is obvious. The inevitable happened. In a memorandum dated 14 February 1986, Mr J. E. Healey of the Commonwealth Development Bank head office wrote:

Mr Naghten said Durna Pty Limited had terminated Huon Valley Spring's lease of the factory property on the grounds of appointment by the Bank of a receiver and also non payment of rent. In view of this situation it must be acknowledged that Durna Pty Limited can effectively prevent sale of the business as a going concern to anyone else.
I have tabled the document from which I have just quoted. Messrs Sofia and Vizzone summarised the position as follows:

The appointment of a receiver meant that Batiste contravened her contractual obligations and lost both her mineral water extraction rights and the lease on the factory buildings. Effectively the receiver had nothing to sell, as Durna owned the water and the factory building.
This means that Reynolds, along with the Italians, became the principal beneficiaries. The Italians recorded this comment, and I am quoting from documents which I have just tabled:
Channel 10 and Batiste were pretty close to the mark over a conspiracy to get her.

That is a statement they made in a documentary produced on this incident by Channel 10. In closing, I return to the fact that it is this type of evidence which the Martin committee has chosen to ignore. The Martin committee ignores it, as does the Attorney-General of Tasmania, whose attention I drew to this evidence some months ago. I can only say that they ignore it at their own risk and at our peril because the Huon Valley Springs case, I am convinced, is a classic case of targeting and asset stripping, of fraud, of rank corruption and of malpractice-call it what you like-the type of practice for which it is the responsibility of this Senate, and me personally, to target and give evidence of. It is our responsibility to call upon the responsible authorities in this country to take the necessary action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a short reference to a rather unfortunate speech that was given in the other place earlier this evening by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson). He spoke about East Timor and, in doing so, about a parliamentary delegation to Indonesia which visited East Timor. He then proceeded to go on to other things. The contents of that speech were, in my view, quite outrageous, misleading and inaccurate, and the timing of the speech was improper, contrary to what I understand to be the ethics of this Parliament and unfortunate in the extreme.

SPEECH.PARA: I dissociate myself entirely from the remarks of the honourable member for Moreton. I want to make it clear that, whilst the honourable member for Moreton mentioned the delegation, in no way could what he said in that speech tonight be taken as being my impression as a member of that delegation.

I intend to speak on the delegation's visit to Indonesia, and I want to do that at greater length at the appropriate time which is, I understand, when the delegation's report is presented to Parliament. I will be speaking in a very positive way because the delegation was a very positive exercise and one which will do much to cement relationships between our nearest neighbour, the Indonesian republic, and the fine people who live in that nation, who looked after us extremely well and were very kind and helpful to us on that delegation.

I was somewhat shocked to see on my in-house monitor the honourable member for Moreton speaking as he did about East Timor and about the Indonesians. He said that he had recently been to the United Nations as a member of a parliamentary group for East Timor. I assume that he was sponsored by the Australian Government, although I do not know. It seems that the things that he said were simply not correct in anyone's view. He made some quite outrageous statements and, whilst I do not want to enter into a debate on those, I simply want to say that I find them quite improper and incorrect and, as I say, quite unfortunate. He spoke about our being surrounded by troops all the time we were in East Timor, which is quite improper and quite inaccurate.

I concur with many of the remarks that the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Riggall), who is also a member of that delegation, said when he was, I think, shocked into getting to his feet immediately to respond to the outburst from the honourable member for Moreton.

I might say, without going into any detail, which I will certainly do at another time, that I am sure that Senator Sherry, who was also part of that delegation, will speak. He will have a slightly different view or a different angle on the visit from mine, but I am quite sure it will not be the approach that the honourable member for Moreton adopted tonight.

I found that while there were some problems in East Timor, the Indonesians were doing all they could to improve the health and the education of the people there. Massive amounts of money are being poured into it. The Indonesians generally are trying to do the right thing. There are reports of civil rights abuses. Whether they are accurate is a matter for debate, and I do not want to do that today. But I do not think there is any debate on the fact that the Indonesian officials there-the Governor and the Military Governor-are doing their best to ensure that there are no civil rights abuses and that the welfare of the people is enhanced.

I might say I was absolutely flabbergasted to hear the honourable member for Moreton praising the Portuguese Government and talking about how the Indonesians had invaded and thrown the Portuguese out, how the Portuguese were the rightful rulers of that country and how the people of East Timor wanted the Portuguese back. That is absolutely outrageous and incorrect. At the time the Indonesians came into East Timor, East Timor was in a state of civil war. The Portuguese had left, had walked out on the East Timorese people and left them to a blood bath that had 40,000 East Timorese moving over to Indonesian Timor, which was West Timor.

It is universally recognised that no matter how bad the Indonesians might be-and I do not think they are bad-the Portuguese were far worse. They did nothing for health, they did little for education, and their civil liberties record I think would not stand the test at all. For the honourable member for Moreton to get up and praise the Portuguese, and say they are the rightful rulers of that country, I find too much to accept.

At another time, at the appropriate time-at a time which is in accordance with the ethics of this Parliament-I certainly wish to speak a lot more on that particular subject. But I did want to put on record tonight that I totally dissociate myself from the comments made by the honourable member for Moreton in the other place earlier this evening.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 21 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What amount of money has been spent, or will be spent, by AUSTRADE on overseas promotions, fairs and exhibitions in 1987-88, 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91, and in which locations.
(2) How much money spent on these exhibitions referred to in question (1) does AUSTRADE recover from Australian exporters, and how much from other individuals or businesses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date was the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade advised of the existence of an application to export defence equipment to the value of $450 million to an undisclosed location referred to by the Minister for Defence in the Senate on 13 February 1991.

(2) Did officers of the department provide advice about whether or not the application should be granted; if so: (a) what is the public service title of the officer who provided the advice; and (b) on what date was this advice provided.
(3) Was the Minister for Defence consulted in relation to this deal; if so, on what date or dates.

(4) Did Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade members of the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports make a recommendation to the Committee about whether or not the application should be granted; if so: (a) on what date was this recommendation made; and (b) what was the department's recommendation.
(5) On what date was the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade informed that the Minister for Defence had rejected the application for export and who informed the Minister of this development.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Defence, under existing defence export guidelines, routinely refers to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and other departments represented on the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports (SIDCDE), export applications for particular destinations.
These applications are commercial in confidence and regularly touch on matters of foreign policy sensitivity. For these reasons I do not intend to divulge details of those applications.
The Minister for Defence has portfolio responsibility for defence export controls and may, as appropriate, provide details of particular applications.
The proceedings of the SIDCDE are, for the reasons I have given, also confidential. A quarterly statistical summary of applications and approvals is provided to all SIDCDE members.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 5 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date did the Soviet Embassy open in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea.
(2) Is the Embassy cross-accredited to other member states of the South Pacific Forum; if so, which states.
(3) How many members of staff with diplomatic accreditation are attached to the Embassy.
(4) Who is the Ambassador.
(5) What island member states of the South Pacific Forum have diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China (PRC).
(6) What island Forum states have resident missions from the PRC.
(7) In each case, how many members of staff have diplomatic accreditation.
(8) What are the names of the PRC heads of mission to the island states of the South Pacific Forum.
(9) What island member states of the South Pacific Forum have diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
(10) What island Forum states have resident missions from Taiwan.
(11) In each case, how many members of staff have diplomatic accreditation.
(12) What are the names of the Taiwanese heads of mission to the island states of the South Pacific Forum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Soviet Embassy in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, was opened on 20 March 1990.
(2) The embassy is not cross-accredited to other member states of the South Pacific Forum.
(3) The Ambassador and five other staff with diplomatic accreditation are attached to the Embassy.
(4) The Ambassador is His Excellency Mr Evgeny F. Rogov.

(5) The island member states of the South Pacific Forum which have diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China are the Federated States of Micronesia, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea, Kiribati, Western Samoa, Fiji, the Cook Islands and Niue.

(6) The island Forum states with resident missions from the People's Republic of China are the Federated States of Micronesia, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea, Kiribati, Western Samoa, and Fiji.

(7) The numbers of staff with diplomatic accreditation in each of the PRC's missions in island Forum states are as follows: the Federated States of Micronesia-2; the Republic of the Marshall Islands-2; Vanuatu-4; Papua New Guinea-5; Fiji-16; Kiribati-l; and Western Samoa-7.

(8) The names of the PRC's heads of mission to the island states of the South Pacific Forum are as follows: In the Federated States of Micronesia the Charge D'Affaires is Mr Lu Fengding. In the Republic of the Marshall Islands the Charge D'Affaires is Mr Si Cong. In Vanuatu the Charge D'Affaires is Mr Sun Baosheng. In Fiji the Ambassador is His Excellency Mr Hua Junduo. In Papua New Guinea the Ambassador is his Excellency Zhao Wei. In Western Samoa the Ambassador is His Excellency Mr Yue Junqing. In Kiribati the Charge D'Affaires is Mr Wu Zhonghua.
(9) The only island member states of the South Pacific Forum with diplomatic relations with Taiwan are: The Solomon Islands; Nauru; Tonga; and Tuvalu.

(10) Taiwan has resident diplomatic missions in the Solomon Islands, Nauru and Tonga. Taiwan's representative in Tonga is also accredited to Tuvalu. Both PNG and Fiji, which do not have diplomatic relations with Taiwan, host Taiwanese trade missions.
(11) The numbers of staff with diplomatic accreditation in each of Taiwan's missions in island Forum states are as follows: Solomon Islands-3; Nauru-1; Tonga-2.
(12) Taiwan's Ambassador to the Solomon Islands is Dr Shi-Cheng Chang. Taiwan's Ambassador to Tonga and Tuvalu is Mr Hugh O'Young. Taiwan's Charge D'Affaires in Nauru is Mr George Hseih.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March, 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made in planning for a National Defence College.
(2) What options are being considered for the College's location.
(3) When will the College be established.
(4) What will be the College's primary function.
(5) What would be the anticipated number of staff involved in research and instruction in the College.
(6) Is it anticipated that civilians would be involved in research and instruction in the College.
(7) What effect would the College's establishment have on the existing service staff colleges.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In May of last year the Chiefs of Staff Committee agreed that a project officer should be appointed to investigate the feasibility of a National Defence College for Australia. The project Officer (Brigadier D'Hage-now the Director General of Public Information for Defence) is due to submit his completed report to the Chiefs of Staff Committee on 17 April 1991. Until such time as that report is considered by the Chiefs of Staff Committee and recommendations are forwarded to me for consideration, I am not in a position to provide any detailed answers to the honourable senator's questions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister bring up-to-date the information contained in the answer to House of Representatives Question on Notice No.1334 (House of Representatives Hansard, 16 June, 1989 p.3706); if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The information provided in the answer to House of Representatives Question on Notice No.1334 of 16 June 1989 reflected the previous accounting approach of providing detailed information on the costs of the input items such as fuel, rather than relating the cost of such inputs to the achievement of specific Defence objectives.

The changes resulting from the introduction of Program Management and Budgeting has rectified this problem. Defence expenditure is now presented by Program and sub-program which, in effect, gives the same overall level of details on expenditure but from an objective and activity perspective rather than one based on input costs. There is no readily available means of relating these two approaches. Between 1988-89 and 1989-90 there was a further change in presentation as Defence moved from an initial Five Program Structure to an Eight Program Structure.
